Slick, slightly sugary but a solid feel. Medium bodied, light carbonation. Lovely beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2007 vintage, bottle from Bierkompass!

Pours dark brown with reddish tinge, foam is creamy, brown and long-lasting. Smells malty-roasty, sugary, with lots of dark fruits and licorice. Starts sweet-malty, very fruity, with dark red fruits, slight alcoholic touch in the middle part. It is also slight chocolatey, with some toffee. Finish is very perfumy / alcoholic with dark fruits, licorice and some pepper and lots of raisin. Overall very complex, but also very alcoholic-warming.

2007 Vintage
Aroma is very rich and malty with lots of sweet toffee and dark caramel. Some burnt sugar, light chocolate and faint roast and toast. Light fruitiness of raisins, plums and figs. Hint of alcohol spice and phenolic spice. 
Pours brown with some burnt amber notes. Head is big and thick, tan with a reddish note to it. Similar color to what I look like after being in the sun too long. 
Flavor similar to aroma with lots of dark caramel and toffee. Moderate burnt sugar notes, light chocolate, roast and toasted bread notes. Some medium light fruit notes of plum, fig, prune and raisin with a hint of cherry. Light peppery clove note. Medium bitterness and medium light alcohol spice in finish. Starts very sweet but the finish isn't sticky at all. 
Mouthfeel is medium full bodied with medium low carbonation. Low astringency and medium alcohol warmth. 
Overall a very enjoyable beer. Very nice malt complexity married nicely with the flavors you would expect from Belgian yeast. The caramel has varying layers of darkness which adds a nice complexity. Sweet without being sticky or cloying. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2011 bottle. Pour is a very murky dark brown with a small light tan head. Quite sweet and fruity nose, dark fruits, candy sugar, caramel, and hints of booze. Lots of caramel on the taste, some toffee, dates and figs, candy sugar, slight hint of oak, and some booze.
2011, rood/bruine kleur, niet helder, bijna geen schuimkraag, ruikt en smaakt fruitig, beetje alcohol, zoet/zuur en een beetje waterig
UPDATED: JUN 5, 2013 Brune foncée, fine pétillance, bien maltée, goûts de caramel, réglisse (léger), pain grillé, ametume présente avec un arrière-goût sucré-fruité. Un délice!
Bottle from Rehills, Newcastle. This is a dark red-brown beer with a sweet red fruit and candi sugar flavour, slight sour fruity notes, currants, whisky notes and a warming creamy vanilla finish.

Bottle courtesy of Deanso. Poured a deep mahogany with a frothy tan head. The aroma is big red berry fruit and liqourice. The flavour is rich, sweet, fruity and alcoholic bitter. The palate is lovely rich and smooth. A super beer as expected from Struisse.

2007 vintage bottle shared from Deanso.  Pours hazy dark brown with a small tan head.  Aroma of toffee, caramel, malt, overripe fruits, raisins.  Flavor is heavy sweet.  Full bodied with soft carbonation.
Appearance. Rather dark brown bordering on black hard to see in the dark. Aroma of dried fruit taste sweet and long on the palate
Batch 2010. Dark bordeaux red color. No lasting foam. Smell of candy and ripe cherries. Taste of ripe dark fruit. Certainly family of the Struise Pannepot.
Aroma: Liquor, sweet dried fruit, raisin  Appearance: Nice off-white thick foam (Struise!)  Taste: roasted malt, boozy, currant

Bouteille 330ml (2010), courtoisie de YULbier. Nez de levures fruitées (petits fruits confits, prunes, notes de figues) aux notes épicées (poivre doux), de caramel aux notes rôties, léger de sucre brun et de noix avec des notes de houblon herbeux et de réglisse rouge. Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen ainsi quune texture aux notes crémeuses et sirupeuses. Goût de levures fruitées (prunes, léger de figues, notes de petits fruits confits, notes de raisins) aux notes épicées (poivre doux) avec un mélange de réglisse noire et rouge lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût de caramel légèrement rôti et aux notes terreuses avec des notes de sucre brun et quelques traces de chocolat puis en finale lon retrouve une légère amertume dalcool doux (aux notes réchauffantes), de houblon herbeux avec des notes de noix grillées. Post-goût long, composé dun goût résiduel de malt sucré et légèrement rôti avec un goût de levures fruitées (pelures de prunes) légèrement épicé ainsi quavec une légère amertume de houblon hebreux et dalcool doux.

Bottle from Stirchley Wines, Brum. Smells leathery and well worn - comforting. Irresistibly delicious: light, balanced, super-drinkable. Strong Belgian malt flavour, tobacco, roots et Alan. Compelling.
33 cl bottle from dranken Geers in Oostakker. Dark brown with beige head. Aroma of roasted malts. Taste is sweet caramel, roasted malts, chocolat. **
dark brown pour.  dark fruits and roast in the aroma.  taste is dark fruits, spice, and a bit of chocolate; finishes on a very nice sour note.  excellent.

Gently roasty aroma with bundles of Dried fruits.  Dark chocolate mixes with raisin and prune and is followed by more chocolate notes.  Flavour is a symphony of varied notes, dark chocolate with hints of vanilla then a touch of peppery spice and may be a hint of oranginess.

Precious dark brown colour with a tiny head, shortlasting. Aromas and tastes to plums, sweet wine, prunes, cinnamon and a nutty hint. Perfect structure and development. Elegant, complex, delicious, unforgettable. In my opinion, one of the best beers worldwide. Colossal.

Pours dark brown with slight darker mahogany tint in the light, med head. Smells..dark fruit, raisins, malt, liquorish and some spice. Tastes..dark fruits and spices. Malts, liquorish and some candy. Yum.
Much like Pannepot. Didn't really get the difference. Super smooth, creamy and strong. Had at Herman, Berlin. Would have again in special occasions.
2007 vintage from Blue Max. Sweet prune and citrus aromas and flavors. Very nice!
Brewed in 2010. Sweet, some roasted malts and some chocolate to go along with the usual spices and dark fruits of a Belgian Strong ale. Excellent!!

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2015 Nera e densa con soffice schiuma beige. Aroma speziato ed erbaceo con sentori più dolci di caramello e frutta; gusto complesso, maltoso con note di frutta sciroppata, cacao amaro, spezie, zucchero di canna e un finale asciutto e legnoso. Corpo medio-abbondante, liquorosa ed intensa, è una birra piuttosto impegnativa e strutturata, da sorseggiare con calma.

Pours very black colour with a light brown head. Aroma is malt, fruits, chocolate, tobacco, brown sugar and spices. Taste is medium to high sweet of fruits and chocolate leading to a sweet spicy finish. Bloody good.
Dark brown red color.  Aroma of dark fruit.  Cherries some grape.  Taste has a mild belgian spices some sweetness and a touch of sour cherries.  Pretty good stuff and im not a belgian fan.

2011 vintage tasted alongside 2009 Pannepot Reserva and 2009 Pannepeut. 33 cL bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, served in a stem glass. Pours hazy chestnut with a tiny tan head that fades to a few bubbles. The nose has notes of dark fruit, apples, caramel, oak and subtle earth. The flavour is quite sweet with chocolate, molasses and fruit, along with caramel and subtle spice. The finish is long and malty with molasses and subtle spice. On the palate it is medium-full with a smooth, milky texture and soft carbonation. Overall, a great chocolatey fruity spicy strong ale. 2013-03-14

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2013 Shared with Mathieu87.
33cl bottle. 2010 edition.
Appearance: white foam, dark black beer.
Nose: caramel, burned malts, sugar, little coffee.
Taste: burned malts, sugar, syrup. alcohol

Geruch fruchtig-opulent, Weintraube, Feige, Schokolade, Orange. Antrunk süßlic-malzig. Mitte schokoladenmalzig, ledern, Tabak, gleichwohl fruchtig. Abgang weinartig, schokoladig, malzig, nachbitternd. Sehr gutes Bier.

Pours dark brown with a small head.
Nose shows cocoa, caramel, soft spices, nutmeg, bready malt and grainy notes.
Flavours include cocoa, burnt fig, bitter roast, astringent spices and booze.
Carbonation could be lower.

Sumptuous aroma of dark fruits, herbal notes, molasses, and floral undertones. Very well layered and enticing. The taste is a bit more one-dimensional, with a mild, fruity sweet being run over by malty bitter. Medium-to-thin mouthfeel, with subtle carbonation and a runny palate. Dont get me wrong, though  somehow, it works. It must be that beautiful nose.

( Pannepeut - 2007 ) Stesso aspetto della Pannepot nel bicchiere (bruna-mogano con schiuma fitta e persistente color beige). Aroma ugualmente molto simile, forse lunica differenza è che è un pò meno dolce della famosa Pannepot. Le note olfattive che si distinguono sono quelle maltate, speziate, alcoliche, fruttate (frutta secca, fichi) Al palato le cose iniziano a cambiare. Al beershop mi hanno detto che la Pannepeut e la Pannepot sono la stessa birra ma con etichettatura diversa. Non è così. Al palato la Pannepeut è complessa si, ma si beve con un pò più di facilità. Si può mandare giù una sorsata più sostanziosa per intenderci. Risulta anche meno densa di sapori della Pannepot Reserva 2007. Resta tuttavia una birra di incredibile livello qualitativo. Il palato, differenze a parte, è caratterizzato da un ingresso vellutato, denso, con note maltate. Lalcol la riscalda e la rende suadente. Il gusto è complesso (cioccolata al latte, mandorle, fichi, malto, etc). La chiusura viene pulita da una piacevole e lieve luppolatura. Buonissima.

Empieza con un aroma dulce afrutado y luego un sabor con componentes dulces donde predomina el café, pero quizás le falta algo de cuerpo. En resumen, buena cerveza qué tomaría otra vez pero qué esta un poco por debajo de su hermana la pannepot.
Draft at Maxs. Tastes like raisins and dates. Slightly sour but very smooth. Dried fruit smell. Pretty tasty.

Tap. Pours dark brown with thin, creamy off-white head; short retention and minimal lacing. Aroma is plums, raisins, black cherries, cookie and caramel malts, floral hops, and light leather. Flavor is sweet malts forward with heavy dark fruit esters and some light supporting floral hops and light roast; dry finish. Medium body and low carbonation.

Bottle, 2010 vintage. Poured dark brown with red hints in the depths. An initial head disappeared very quickly. Alcoholic whiff, plus fruit (christmas?) cake and molasses. Initially tasted quite sweet, a little boozy but also figs and prunes. Then some yeast, spice and a fairly decent hop finish, a little dry roasted malt, has a moreish finish. Quite a serious beer.

light brown color,super nice foam.
sweet dark fruits aromas, dark fruits, caramel, a bit of cocolatevon taste with a bready, yeasty aftertaste. the alcohol is there, but not super strong.
a very very good beer
Pours a dark brown, but nowhere near black. Dark fruits, plum, figs,  raisins ans ocean ( salt water). Moderately sweetbeithouy a cloying finish. Palate has dome boozy notes.
An excellent Belgian. Very rich and malty with a sweet caramel, toffee and dried fruit flavor. It is slightly bitter at the finish. It pours a lovely dark brown. Very smooth.

33cl bottle @ home. Rated on 07.05.2010
Aroma is somewhat sour with earthy notes, some vinegar, spices, malt and ripe fruits. Flavour is quite spicy and sour with ripe fruits, some vinegar, oaky notes and distant earthy notes. Somewhat messy and this lacks that something that basic Pannepot has. Worst of the Pannepots Ive had so far. But still good.

2010 bottle as Pannepeut.
Hazy to opaque reddish brown with a beige head.
Aroma: toffee, hard candy, malty, licorice.
Taste: hallonremmar, salty licorice, toffee, red berries, mint, light sour.
Medium bodied+.
This was nice, but competes with some very tasty beers with similar names. Its my least favourite.

Bottle at home 2010 PNP #5, Noel Cuveliers, 13/01/13.
Obscured chestnut brown with a thin off white/light tan head that retains as an off centred film.
Nose carries dark fruit notes, malt, raisens, dark brown sugars, touch of wood, spice, tobacco.
Taste comprises dark fruits, raisens, plums, dates, brown sugar, spice, light yeast esters.
Full bodied, soft carbonation, a little booze in the finish.
Well balanced and complex it comes into its own as it warms a little.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Serving: 330 ml. 2011 vintage bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours a cloudy dark brown with a small off white head that doesnt last long.  The nose has a bit of dough, alcohol, dried date, and raisin.  The flavor is a bit brash with obvious alcohol, plastic, dough, apple cider, and dried fruit notes.  It seems very green.  Perhaps the flavors will evolve and mesh more later, but right now its not all that enjoyable.  Medium body with average carbonation.  I wasnt too impressed with this one.

Somewhat odd aroma, with bread, toffee, vegetables, and a little funk.  Flavor is bready and a little sweet, with fruit and tobacco.  Some spice, fruit, and bitterness in the finish.  Lots of interesting flavors, but a little on the harsh side--definitely a sipper.

2010 bottle at tuulensuu, tampere. Dark brown almost black color, small white head. Temptating aroma of plums, sweetness, oak. Balanced full body taste of sweetness, some hops, hint of citrus, plums, oak. Fantastic struise again. Only that fantastic taste could be longer.

330 mL bottle. Dark, murky brown with a small, tan head. Aroma of heavy caramel, plums, resin, and bitter chocolate. Slightly sour, sweet, and medium bitterness. Medium body, sticky, heavily acidic, and clingy. Overall, this is a flavorful, complex, and interesting beer, but the mouthfeel is a little harsh.

2011 bottle. Hazy, rich brown color, but very little head. Rich aroma to match: molasses, licorice, almond, hint of spice. Alcohol is rather prominent on the palate. Tobacco, bitter, a bit of the almond again. Flavor is not nearly as refined as the aroma. Dry finish.

Pannepeut 2010: When I pour it out in a nice "De Struise" glass it has a nice beige header. A Very dark beer, but clear. The carbonation is not very lively, but average.  A slow drinker that lasts a while with hints of coffee and dark chocolate. Fairly (not too) sweet and a slightly bitter taste at the finish (lasting).

2010 bottle, 13C. Very dark but clear brown, a finger of beige head thats never less than a coat. Aroma of prunes, raisins, polished leather, chocolate, licorice, light spices. Silky texture, gentle carbonation.Never more than mouthfilling - a slow drinker, not a forbidding sipper. Fairly sweet with dried fruit and chocolate, a little coffee. Yeast notes are there - bread and a little leather - but not heavy. A little porty, some overt alcohol. Bitterness and light spices again lighten things. Not as intense as it might be, but supple and good.

botte [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ pours dark brown with small off white head. plums.belgian yeas in the aroma. medum body. smooth, spicy flavor.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2014 
Tap @ Gastropub Tuulensuu.
Pours dark red color with a small head. The ripe fruits and caramel feels a lot sweeter here, lots of molasses and brown sugar, toffee and mild licorice also present. Sweet lingering plum aftertaste with a subtle alcohol burn at the end. I like this better.

33 cl bottle @ Gastropub Tuulensuu, Tampere. BBE 20.11.2016.
Pours dark hazy red color with a small head. Aroma of yeast, ripe fruits, caramel and some belgian toffee. Flavour of licorice, ripe fruits, yeast, spices, caramel malts and toffee. Medium CO2, sourish fruity and malty palate. Nice.
Rating: 8-3-8-3-15
3336
141212. Bottle at Tuulensuu, Tampere. Pours clear amber with a minimal head. Aroma Belgian yeast, licorice, caramel. Sweet licorice taste. Not Bad.

2010 vintage, thanks tommy. pours hazy brown, red tint, with a nice beige head, some retention and lacing. complex dark caramel malts, dark fruits, mostly dried sweet ripened dark berries and cherries, candy-like, heavy and complex blend of spices. lively and soft carbonation, warming alcohol, medium body, very nice medium long grassy-citrusy finish.

2011 vintage

Poured a murky brown with almost no head, but many suspended bubbles. Even leaving a quarter inch of beer in the bottle, there was significant floating suspended yeast. Nose is full of chocolate, figs, and bready malt. Flavor starts with sweet dried fruits, then the hops hit you a moment later for a bit of a dry finish. Despite the high ABV, relatively little alcohol is present.

As a huge fan of the Pannepot, I definitely dont consider this beer its equal. Its a fin strong ale, but not up to the standard set by the Pannepot, which is perhaps my favorite beer.

2007 bottle, pannepeut. Wow this one stole the show for me, its nose was lacking and offered only a flat glimpse, but this beer was awesome, the balance and subdued sweetness present coupled with the belgian flavors and hiding 10% made a real treat, 5yrs old and just awesome.

De color oscuro y espuma marrón claro. La espuma al principio es densa pero tiende a desaparecer quedándose una fina crema hasta el final. Olor a barrica. Poco carbonatada. Sabor a chocolate, café y miel. Mejor no demasiada fria.

Somwhat clear, glowing brown body and creamy foamy beige head. Raisins, dried figs, bay leave, humous and cinnamon. Not as sweet as I remember the Pannepot. Taste is rich, spicy, dry malty and with forest and berry like bitterness. Long aftertaste. Many complexities to be found here! Almost as good as the Pannepot, and with its own character. Not cheap though. (33cl bottle, from De Bierwinkel Leiden)

A - pours rich amber brown with no head. S - very bready(raisin bread)  alcohol up front. Notes of dried fruits, caramel malts, grains, brown sugar. Astringent. M - medium bodied, nice full palate. Watery up front. Thicker syrupy end. T - sweet doughy breads up front. Brown sugar malty. Dark fruits, caramel, apples. Yeasty bready. O - very very bready. Like a doughy sweet roll. 7-

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The third of the pannepots that Ive tried.  Slightly murky, dark brown in color, and a small slightly off white head.  Not the prettiest of beers.  Smells like the sweetest and booziest of the 3 variants I have tried.  Lots of fig, raisin, toffee, and caramel dominate the aroma.  Fairly boozy.  Pretty thin on the tongue, and pretty damn boozy.  Sweet candy sugar, caramel, and booze soaked raisins.  I absolutely love pannepot and the reserve, but this really isnt nearly as good.

Good but not great, not even close to the normal pannepot.  Although mine might have been rotten, it tasted more like a sour than a belgian strong.  Nonetheless it is a very tasty beer, with the usual grape, sugar, cherry, bread and raisin notes, with extra raisin in this, almost like a doppelboch (frankly its touch to nail down what style this tastes like).  It was good, but if your store has this, it surely has the original and theres frankly no comparison.

From 33cl bottle.Dark brown colour, good but not great brown foam.. Taste really complex, giod carbonization on tongue, little alcohol and fruitness and then caramel & hoppines at finish on palate.. Just great at all!!

--- The Server

Bottle at Craigs 271012
Very dark brown, hazy, big frothy off white head, big gusher
Aroma - rich fruity malts, raisins, dark malts, caramel, soft sherry, great aroma
Taste as aroma, dark caramel malts, fruity raisin. dark fruity malts, soft belgian yeast
Palate - medium carb, medium to full body. Finish as main flavour, warming alcohol at the back end

Bottle courtesy of Dany in exchange for that thing I did with my feet and a jar of mayonnaise. Pours a softly hazed milky brown with a medium sized beige head that deflates quickly.  Big sticky malt and a touch of oxidization and fruit.  Medium bodied, chewy malt and toast, warming alcohol soft and supple.  Long chewy malt and more oxidized notes followed by a lovely bit of chocolate and yeast.  Nice and smooth while waiting through hurricane Sandy.

Bottel at home. 
Aroma spicy, alcohol, sweet. 
Hazy brown color
Taste of hay, sugar coffe?
Nice fine small bubles. 
Nice ale! 

Bolton Brew Rocks !!
2012.10.26 - bottle 33cl - dark red brown beer with creamy head - nose : roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolat - mouth : coffee, roasted malts, hints of vinegar and roasted malts in the end

Pours very dark brown, almost black, with a fairly short tan head. Aroma is abt/quad with tons of Belgian yeast, spices, cloves, some hay and barnyard. Very earthy and rough. Taste is surprisingly mellow up front, with just a fresh carbonation and a hint of malt, before turning into a red fruit, cask and yeast bomb. Finish is almost overly sweet, sticking in the mouth. Theres a lot of port character in the mouthfeel and subtly in the taste, yet it manages to remain remarkably fresh and drinkable.

330mL bottle purchased a couple years ago. 2007 vintage. Drunk 10/10, reviewed from notes

A: Very dark, opaque brown. 1/4" cream head. Decent legs.

N: Saturates the nose. Raisins and plums dominate the forefront. Some spicy pepper and mild chocolate. Lots of Belgian yeast and some toffee. Cherry components and a hefty bready/biscuity whiff. A little soy. 

T: Very spicy and flavorful. More raisin and plum. A little bit of smokiness. Very biscuity. Some bitterness in the back end to help balance the sweetness, and this never gets too sweet. More and more prune. 

M: Very well done. Viscous and full mouthfeel. Alcohol is well hidden. 

O: This has aged spectacularly. Rounded and complex while maintaining a great drink after drink simplicity.

(From notes 4 Oct, 2012) Bottle, 2010 edition. Color is a dark brown/amber. Foam is beige, but theres not a lot of it. Aroma is malty and sugary. Flavor is malty with a wee bit of coffee and alcohol. Feels smooth. Aftertaste is a bit sweet, and some bitter coffee (strange). Very enjoyable beer.

2010 edition

The beer pours a dark-brow body with a tan head that dissipates rather quickly. The aroma is of caramel, dark fruits and some roast notes. The taste is again of caramel and dark fruits but with a much more proeminet roasted characteristic than the aroma. The roastness here is not as strong as in a Stout but much stronger than in most trappist-style dark ales. Good body. Alcohol is not noticeable.

Bottle 33 cl, BBE 2016. Poured black in colour with a fluffy, quite fast disappearing head. Sweet, like candy or burn brown sugar along with some dark fruits hits you instantly in aroma. Second impression is more portvine and perhaps some licorice on the nose. Flavour was a slight disappointment, a bit dull and dry and slightly alcoholic at first. Some sweetness and then perhaps licorice and spices comes forward. A bit too sweet.

2011 vintage, 37.5CL in a snifter. Enjoyed at cellar temp in a snifter. Appearance is hazy dark brown with a 1 finger slightly tan head. Head fades faster than expected. Smell is full of very balanced dark fruits. Its a nice level of sweetness, licorice and almonds. Taste is very nice! Not too sweet but the candied sugar and brown sugar are nice. Some hint of apricots and some darker fruits. I get this hint of cheap candies. Finish is dry like white wine. heavy body, medium carbonation.

330ml bottle. Cloudy reddish dark brown colour with huge, frothy, lasting, minimally lacing, beige head. Dark malty aroma has notes of cocoa, milk chocolate, toast, raisin. Taste is fruity dark malty, vinous, with notes of dark berries, alcohol-soaked black cherries, milk chocolate, decent dry overtones with a touch of leather. Smooth palate, lasting finish.

2010 bottle from Utobeer. The pours a deep reddish brown with a small light brown head. The nose is rich christmas cake, raisin, big notes of milk chocolate and meaty red cherry. Runny, sweet caramel and lightly vinous cranberry. Big, complex aromas. The taste is tangy red raspberry and cherry. More caramel and mocha. Rich, sweet malty palate. Roasted, earthy grain. Raisin cookie. Medium body, slightly thin mouthfeel. Very easy-drinking for 10%. Overall, a very nice beer. Id love to do this side-by-side with Pannepot. I recall liking original Pannepot a bit more than this.
Poured from a bottle at home.  Pours a dark coffee brown with with a quickly collapsing tan head. Toffee and butterscotch aroma. Caramel and raisins in the taste. Lingering slightly bitter finish.

Murky brown with a thin, off white head. Deep nose with figs, cloves and currants. Full bodied, yet delicate and elegant. The palate is a mix of savory and fruity. Lively mouthfeel and a long, pit fruited finish.

Dark sweet and very drinkable belgian.  Nose is of fig.  Palate continues that an adds a yeastyness and some nuttiness and a lot of dark fruit, particularly cherry and blackberry.  Its got a dry relatively quick finish that makes it very drinkable for the abv.
De color oscuro y aroma fuerte. Sabe demasiado a alcohol para mi gusto. Se me hizo algo pesada.
Pours dark brown with a creamy head. Smell is of heavy roasted malt and brown sugar. Taste is sweet with a slight chocolate coffee bitter on the end. Great taste!

Smells oaky, earthy and boozy. There is blackcurrant as well as some cidery wild yeast smell. It pours dark brown, red with a little champagne-like yeast. Medium to low carbonation. Taste has some sweetness, bitterness and a bit of sourness all in that order - very full on the palate. Something like blackcurrant or prune in the aftertaste as well. Bottle from Winooski Beverage.

Tasted @home on 09/09/2012.
Pours with a good creamy head which dissapears quickly. 
Aroma is all that a belgium ale usually has, but with a stronger hint of alcohol.
Taste is again very boozy upfront, notes of dried fruits, intense malty sweetness, hints of bread, caramel and a just a tiny bit of hops.
Bottled in 2010, but alcohol is still overwhelming.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2010 vintage. Almost opaque black with a beige head. We are getting in BSDA territory here. Its been a while. Smells like raisins and caramel. First swish shows a lot of alcohol warmth and one can taste it a little but it is not out of place. Mouthfeel is lighter than expected but for sure that will boost drinkability. Bread and licorice is what I can taste. This feeeels so good to be back to the beers that made me go passionnate about beer. I can feel the alcohol calming me down, something you just wont get from a lambic (still love both styles tho :D). Seek it out!

Bottle @ home.. vintage 2010.... It pours clear dark brown with a small tan head......The aroma is light roasted malts, vinous and dark fruits.... The flavor is dark fruits, caramel, vinous and light hoppy.....
0,33 flaske delt med medbrygger Ovesen: Mørk klosterøltype med masser av smak av malt, krydder og tørket frukt. Pannepeut 2010:  et herlig øl!

Been a while since Ive entered a rating, but this is one that I wanted to rate to finish the set.  08 Bottle.  Pour is bilious brown yellow. Color of watery diarrhea.  By that, I man cola brown at the bottom, with golden highlights at the top, with lots of suspended chunks.  Nose is rich sweet malt and alcohol.  Sharp.  Taste is massive sweet sharp warming malt.  Ugly and lovely.  Long lingering leftovers.  Probably feel this one in the morning.

Bottle with Ben. Dark Brown with a slight reddish hue. White head. Aroma of booze and bubblegum. Flavour is plummy and slightly spiced with a very present alcohol. Slight aniseed. Sweet caramel malt leading to a light bitter finish. Very nice.

Bottle courtesy of cgarvieuk, thanks Craig! Pours darkest mahogany red. Aroma is quite tame, bubblegum, ripe fruits, caramel. Taste is a bit more robust, ripe fruits, alcohol, caramel. Sweet with a mildly bitter finish. Nice

Bottle @ home. Pours hazy dark brown with a fading offwhite head. Aroma of malt, candy sugar, sweet licorice, dried dark fruits, chocolate, hints of port. Flavor is rich malts, chocolate, yeast, licorice, plum and other dark fruits, light spices, candy sugar. Rich and very complex. Medium body, soft carbonation, alcohol well hidden. 270812

Bottle at Amundsen, august 18th 2012. Dark brown with a red tint, low brown head. Aroma of caramel, leather, grapefruit, malts. Delicious complex taste, roast, grapefruit, spices, yeast esters, dried dark fruit, sugar, wood, beautifully blended. Lasting sweet finish with distinct hop bitterness. I loved this one!

2010 vintage bottle from Ølkonsortiet Aalborg enjoyed at home
Dark dark brown, tanned head. Smells of dark fruits, figs, dried fruits, some yeast esters and caramel. Taste is medium to heavy sweet, some alcohol, quite of heavy dark fruits, some oak. Its all quite vinous. Moderate bitter finish, fruity bitterness. Full body, oily texture, soft to moderate carbonation. Very nice beer!!! Complex dark fruit aromas together with a heavy vinous body with hints of oak dried fruits and roasted malts. Struise really delivers here. And they say Pannepot is even better.... cant wait to try that now

The beer is dark brown and fairly hazy with an inch of thick, foamy tan head. Aromas include yeast, malt, caramels, figs. The flavor is a notch better. Alcohol content masterfully hidden. Really creamy and smooth on the palate with an elegant and graceful finish. Cheers to Urbain.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Donkerbruin tegen zwart qua kleur. Licht bruin/off white kop die lacing overlaat.  Smaak van koffie, aarde, hop, caramel, toffee, bloemen/gedroogd fruit. Lekker vol bier met een wat complexe smaak. Koolzuur gemiddeld en afdronk zoet en beetje bitter.

Aldus Huubs.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Absolutely a fantastic complex brew. Nose has all the characteristics of an old ale, dark fruit, raisins, alcohol. Flavors along similar lines with a nice spiciness to support. Carbonated wonderfully, just enough to lift the beer and clear the palate to let the next sip roll across fully. Wonderful body, an all around fantastic beer... Especially wonderful to find for 6.99 at Whole Foods

2010. Pours dark chocolate brown with a thin gray/tan head. Figs, dates, sugar, alcohol  in the nose. Taste is brown sugar, chocolate, yeast, big hops for the style. A little thin on the mouthfeel for the style.

2007 bottle. This was a gusher, I my floor is all wet now. Dark mahogany pour with light brown head. Aroma is dark fruits, dates, cinnamon, chocolate, some nice "dark" esters. Lots of chocolate, very good. Hints of tobacco. Very complex aroma. Taste is pretty similar, and it comes off more roasty than regular Pannepot, adding chocolate, cocoa nibs, and high ebc-malt. Shows a small sign of the age with a bit of oxidation. Other than that, pretty similar to Pannepot. And that's a good thing. Smooth and balanced.
33cl bottle from cervezalandia. Dark brown color. Medium large brown head. Medium head. Low to medium bitterness. Chocolate, banana, spices, water, alcohol, malt aroma.
This was a decent Belgian strong ale with a good spice and not too sweet, yet it just seemed rather blasé to me. Okay.

Big thanks to Allen for sharing this one.  Pours a hazy brown with an off-white head.  Nose is sweet malt, caramel, cherry, slight brandy, dates, and figs.  Flavor is similar with sweetness and dates and figs up front followed by a somewhat dry and yeasty finish.  Medium in body and an interesting beer.  No hint of the big alcohol wallop this baby presents.

2011 bottling. Dried fruit, raisins, subtle molasses and coffee, soft, smooth mouthfeel, low carbonation, short finish.. Enjoyable for the overripe, dried fruit nuances and soft texture, though not for much else.. Not my cup of tea.

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...

truely another beer than pannepot ( you would think of it more as a variety ). this ones a lot softer and has diffrent hints. also a very good brew , but you cant beat pannepot, my friends. this one is lighter ( tastewise ) so i now understand what they mean by  female version of pannepot . its not sweetened, its not more wattery, its just.. softer?
Deep ruby red color with tan head. dried pit fruit, melon, belgian spice aromas. Light to medium bodied with soft co2. tangy sweet dark raison, date, rootbeer spice, toffee flavors--good
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text:
This is the 2011 version.

Pours a murky, dirty looking coffee color. Head is tan and one finger tall. Lots of sediment floating around. Head retention is good and lacing is very good.

Smell is of roasted nuts, sugar cookies, and spice like ginger, allspice or nutmeg. Hops arent detected and smell of alcohol lingers through out. 

First taste Im getting is of a spiced rum cake or maybe some pancakes with maple syrup drizzled on top. Notes of candied fruit or nuts are also there. As typical to the style, no hops detected and alcohol is present but not overpowering. 

Mouthfeel is alittle thinner than I was expecting. Its not watery but I was hoping for a more syrupy texture. Head adds some thickness to body and beer is well carbonated. 

Overall this beer was good, not the best in its style but drinkable. Body was slightly too thin for the style in my opinion, flavors were just off the mark from being exceptional. Liked the beer but dont think Id pay another 8 bucks for it
33cl bottle at Schouskjelleren (tasted: 2010-11-19). Pours dark amber with tan head. Aroma of dark dried fruits and malt with just a hint of alcohol. Nice and refreshing and very tasty.

Deep dark murky amber and hard to see very much through. Aromas of big fruits of cherry, plum, fig, toffee, and caramel. Flavors bready, fig, plum, cherry esters, touch of raisin, caramel. Well meshed flavors that really produce a top quality belgian. Sweet but not too sweet and fruity esters are delicious. Has almost a nuttyness mixed in there to. Bravo.
At gollem biercafe in antwerpen. Very nice dark ber like the pannepot. Also a world class beer, chocolate flaavour in this one i think.

Bottle, vintage 2008. 

Brownish with a creamy head. Rather complex beer this one. Yeast, sugar, malt, dried fruit, on the sweet side. A nice beer!

2007 vintage. Pours a dark reddish brown, nice tan head. Sweet aroma of dark fruit, toffee, a touch of cocoa, and just a hint of alcohol. The carbonation of the finest I have ever seen. Wowow. Tastes just like it smells...delicious. Amazingly supple carbonation, a flavor profile that emphasizes the malty notes slightly more than the fruit, and even a little drying bitterness (after 5 years in the bottle (!)) at the end for good measure. Near perfect.

Purchased at a Nightshop in Brussels, bottle popped at tKeizershof. 

Pours a very deep brown with a big off white head. 

The aroma is plum and portwine with a rich nuttiness, raisins, and wood. The bouquet is very well rounded, rich, and features alcohol in a somewhat restrained fashion.

The flavor is intense and nutty with loads of dark chocolate, woody port, and warming alcohol. Some red wine flavors are in there but admittedly this is a pretty restrained flavor. Somehow elegant, bold, and intrusive al at once.

Tap @ Hair of the Dogs Day of De Struise...  Poured dark brown with a little head.  This had dark fruits, plums, molasses, anise, and candied malt sweetness.  Spicing and yeast esters.  Very effervescent.  Also, toasted sugars similar to caramel or toffee.  Light mouthfeel, soft carbonation.
Very dark brown colour. Aroma is malty and has dark, dried fruits and some sweet liquorice. Quite a thick sticky texture with low carbonation. Sweet flavour. Warming feel from the alcohol.

Bottle, Stirchley Wines, Birmingham. Deep dark brown pour with a small tan head. Nose had dark fruits, brown sugar and caramel malts present. Sweetish fairly complex flavour with some earthy malts and gentle spice. Decent stuff but falls short of the original.

My 500th rating! Was saving this one for a food occasion. Pours dark brown with almost no head or lacing. Nose is brown sugar, molasses and dark fruit. Mouth is similar with an additional coffee bit at the end. Mouth is a lighter body than expected with little carbonation. A really nice beer but 
Maybe I was hoping for too much.

Botella de 330ml (Etiqueta: Pannepeut 2010). Copa de Vino. Saboreada en jun´12. Color marrón oscuro y tintes ámbar oscuro a contraluz. Espuma beige y tupida que deja un collar en superficie cuando se disipa. Aromas de maltas tostadas, malta caramelo, trazos de chocolate, toffee e higos maduros. Aromas de especias clavo, vainilla y canela. El perfil de sabor repite los aromas. Malteado cremosa y bajo amargor. Afrutada y voluptuosa. Cuerpo pleno y leve carbonatación. Frutas maduras y frutos secos se muestran en el largo final. ¿ ABV?, ¿A quién le preocupa? 
330ml bottle (Label: Pannepeut 2010). Oversized glass. Enjoyed on jun´12. Dark brown color, dark amber to the light. Beige, close froth leaves a collar on top when dismissed. Toasted malts, caramel malts, chocolate hues, toffee & ripe figs to the nose. Spiced aromas clove, vanilla, cinnamon- Flavor profile as aromas. Creamy maltiness, low bitterness. Fruity & voluptuous. Full body, soft carbonation. Ripe fruits & dried nuts showed in a lasting finish. ABV?? Who, cares?

Poured at a good temperature with a small to medium size, light tan head that soon settled and no lace. Color is a hazy amber cherry with a couple slow bubble trails. Aroma is malt, burnt sugar, toffee, yeast, wine. Flavors like nose, subdued and dominated by mild sweetness and bitterness with little carbonic tang. Body is ok and carbonation is a little flat. Finish is like flavor, of average length, and kind of forgettable. Think I got a less than decent bottle.

2010 vintage, Tasted from lot with expiration of 20/11/16, fairly fresh bottle from deca in west-Flanders.  Dark brown pour with chocolate, two finger head. Aroma - light coffee, hint of chocolate and molasses. Taste - coffee like flavour, similar to their black damnation , that you can almost chew. Roasted coffee/ dark chocolate aftertaste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours dark brown with low to no light brown head.
Distinct aroma of liqourise, dark malts, some belgian yeast
Very sweet start with taste of liqourise, there is also a presence of caramel malts. Low carbonation, alcohol is pleasantly hidden.
This is a very fined tned smooth belgian strong ale. Nice!

330 ml bottle.  Pours a dark reddish brown with a small biege head.  Aroma of malt, caramel, dark fruit, and yeast.  Taste is caramel malt, dark fruit, yeast, brown sugar, and a bit of alcohol.  Very nice!
UPDATED: APR 18, 2014 Aroma is intense dark fruit/grapes/malts and has a note of alcohol to it.  The flavor is dark fruit/grapes/raisins, spices, a mild tartness and a warming alcoholic finish.

Bottle 330 ml. Brewed in 2010. Pours dark brown with a medium lasting beige head. Some lacing. Aroma: malt, belgian yeast, spices, fruits. Taste is malty, with notes of caramel and even bubblegum. Sweet well balanced taste with a slight bitter finish. Full bodied beer. Some pelasant warming alcohol.

Pour out of 11.2 oz bottle, side by side with the pannepot, reserva, and grand reserva is dark brownish red with fluffy tan/caramel colored head that lasts very nicely, great looking beer.  Aroma brings notes of big figs, raisins, caramel, burnt sugars, rum soaked raisin, green apple notes slightly come in, pretty nice.  Taste is big dark fruit with figs, raisins, some slight tart apple, touch of caramel, biscuit, burnt notes with some nuts, finishing pretty dry but sweet.  Nice.

12 ounce bottle.  No aroma whatsoever, practically no foam except for the 5 seconds worth of fizz upon pouring it into the glass, like soda. Very opaque brown-orange color, muddy.  It borders on tasting like wine, rather than beer.  Its a little watery and embodies the opposite of creamy.  Its easy to drink and has flavors of apple, pumpkin, nutmeg, and tartness.  Its not alcohol-ridden.  I had high expectations for this beer and its different from what I expected.  Its a little too watery and sweet/tart for me, but I can see why some people would like it, especially wine or cider lovers.

Bottle from the House of Trembling Madness. Pours a very deep, very murky brow, finger of head. Aroma is creamy and milky, with raisins and oak. Taste is similar, with dark fruits and something woody in there too. Full bodied, with a long, sweet finish. Mmmm. Yummy.

2010 bottle from House of Trembling Madness. Murky dark brown, thick bubbly beige head fades to a thin cap. Nice rich nose, oak, chocolate malts, vinous fruits, yeasty notes, slightly tart fruits, warm spices. Fruity yet dry and oaky, some chocolate, vinous juicy fruits, dried fruit, big raisin, soft rustic hop flavours also. Fantastic.

Color marron oscuro con un espuma blanca densay persistente.Aparentemente muy carbonatada. Aroma a maltas tostadas, frutos secos como pasas e higos. Sabor a roasted malts, ahumados con un final seco. El alcohol esta perfectamene integrado.

Bottle 341 ml. Dark brown with reddish reflects. Small quickly vanishing brown head with some lacing. Loads of dried fruits, brown sugar, raisins, spices (less than Pannepot), malt and belgian yeast. Taste is sweet with dried fruits, caramel, malt, liquorice and spices. Very pleasant warming alcohol. Body is full. Lengthy enjoyable finish. Alcohol is not hidden but is a perfect fit in this beer. Nice complexity and great balance. Amazing one!

Bottle. Dark brown pour with light head. Aroma of dried fruits, raisins, brown sugar, belgian yeast. Taste is wonderfully balanced, quite sweet, lots of dried fruits, good balance with the alcohol. The mouthfeel, however, takes the cake. Nice rich full body with good carbonation and just enough alcohol warmth. So delicious and fun to drink. Great to sit on a case.

2011 bottle was no good... None of the fruited notes that we came across when following with a 2007 Vintage. Dark brass color, minimal head. Nice fingers sticking to my glass. Balanced flavor profile with some heat on the back of my palate. Candied malt. Swee  mediumt fruits.

bottle from knightly. rich dark brown almost black but not. scattered lace. aroma rich and sweet, stewed raisins, mincemeat, dark sugars....tastes explode! the bready malts are incredible! havent had this flavor in so long...sticky toffee pudding, toasted granola. loverly!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

as with pannepot, a hefty amount of residual sugar here in comparison to other belgians. big and muddy and malty, slightly boozy in finish. Head doesnt last. Not that complex actually, the malt flavours take centre stage, with a small amount of subtle leafy hops, not much yeast character. Not cloyingly sweet, but not appealingly fruity and spicy either. Solid and tasty but short of spectacular.
330ml bottle.  Pours a very dark ruby brown with a large, frothy head.  Aroma is raisin malt and brocolli.  Taste has some raisin and veg to start.  Burnt cinder toffee finish.

Bottle 330ml vintage 2010 @ home
Pours deep reddish brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, dried fruits, alcohol and yeast. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and light to medium bitter with a long sweet fruity and alcohol finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

33cl bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo. Dark mahogany with dark biege head that fades to a nice ring around the rim of the glass. Belgian yeast, candied sugar, cherries, vanilla, plum, alcohol, raisin and some nice earthy malts. Moderate to high carbonation, decent body with a n underlying sweetness and an alcohol warmth. Malt, belgian yeast and dark fruit becomes stronger on the finish as the beer dries out - quite tasty.
Dark brown with a small, brown head. Malty with fruity tones. Malt, fruit and spices. Full body with a long, bitter sweet after taste.
Pours dark brown with nice tan head..creamy and silky mouthfeel.  Aroma dark fruit, cherry, hint of sourness and booze.  Taste is very nice...sweet malty, hint of caramel...dark fruit.
caramel, chocolate, vanilla, black, minimal head, medium body, soft carbonation, ...

2011 bottle from Knightly Spirits.  This pours a murky dark brown color with a thin head on top that mostly sticks around.  The aroma is strong and a bit alcoholic (not in a bad way). Getting big whiffs of raisin and figs, with tobacco, yeast, and licorice as well.  The flavors are smooth and not nearly as strong as expected.  Caramel and chocolate joins the party here, with dried sugary raisins, dates, and figs still kicking around, but the dark fruity aspect is a little less prominent than the scent.  The finish is slightly dry and a little sooty.  If there is any alcohol heat, its here.  Seems kind of like a mish mash of things going on.  Its good but isnt on the level as their Pannepot.
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 Bottle. Murky brown pour. Nose and taste of fig, raisin, and maybe a bit of booze. Yummy beer.

Bottle shared with friends. Pours a dark, murky brown body with thin lacing. Aroma is dark fruit, sweet Belgian malts, prune. Mouthfeel is carbonated with notes of raisin, fruit, prune, wood, Belgian sugar candy, and earthy malts.

Vegas Whole Foods bottle enjoyed in Ohio.  Pours like you would expect. Aroma is interesting because it seems slightly sour at first but then finishes with malt and classic Belgian yeast. Again, tastes like you would expect; pretty classic strong ale overall with some quad-like notes. Also hard to believe this is 10 ABV until you get a hint of it at the very end. Well done.

A rare find at Little Bear Los Angeles 330 bottle pours out a dark rich brown with a nice creamy 2" head. Aromas of ripened fruit figs plums and roasted malts. Tastes of a slight malt sweetness balanced with plums cherries and brandy. A quality brew and well worth looking for. Finishes long and satisfying.
smooth, gentle on the palette, mild but pleasant aroma, very light feel, lingering aftertaste

Thick and consistent head. Sweet and spicy aroma with just a hint of (fresh) sourness. Buttery and soft palate, medium body. Very refined malty sweet taste, with well hidden alcohol. The hops balance things out nicely. Top notch beer, well worth trying.
33cl bottle from the old school house. Pours rye bread brown with creamy beige head. Raisin, caramel and malt aroma. Very pleasantly warming raisin and toffee flavour. Excellent beer.

An awesome brew! I really cant wait to try the more from Struise. Nose of dark fruit, caramel, cherries, some slight alcohol, and more fruit. Wow. Body is dark caramel colored with a thin white head. Tons of fruits in the taste. Plum, raisin, cherry. Good stuff. A nice malty backbone with some light molasses and caramel mingling throughout. Nice stuff. Sticky and good.

A great find by OmegaX - thanks for sharing. Out pours this dark belgian ale with a very small off-white head. Aromas were full of yeast, caramel and black cherries. The taste was rich and full of yeast. Undertones of vanilla, molasses, raisins and alcohol. To say the 10% abv is well hidden would be an understatement... I could drink this stuff all damn day!

Biege head mahogany pour soft carbonation aromas dark fruits liquorice alcohol spice dried fruit caramel the flavours dark dried fruit plum raisin sultana rich alcohol liquorice mild clove sugary mild bitter sweet body the finish aftertastes sweet malts fruity hops and spices alcohol mild bitter good body nice on the palate

33 cL bottle into a Struise glass at the Cambrinus in Brugge.  Dark red with a good creamy brown head.  Rich, aromatic, alcohol and caramel aroma.  Smooth, fruity and complex, alcohol warmth, figs?  very tasty, just need to drink it slowly!  Dry finish, lots going on in the mixture, gets the taste buds working.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2013 Draft pours a very dark orange brown with a foamy head. Nice flavorful variation of Pannepot. Spicy chocolate caramel and medium dark red fruits. Tootsie Rolls. Black pepper. Overripe pomegranates. Raisins. Earthy truffels. Cinnamon. Salted caramels. Black cherries. Chocolate malted. Juicy red plums. Medium body. High ABV well hidden. Smooth finish. Like a wonderful brandied candy apple. Bit more spice and less dark red fruit than the Pannepot. Still a lot of variation year to year (and often keg to keg). 2011 vintage was great. Having the 2013 version on draft right now and it might even be better.

bottle, vintage 2007, dark brown coloured with almost nog head. Some wine look a like. Smell: very rich: dark fruits, plums, chocolat, vanilla, some yeasty Taste: dark fruits, plums, chocolat, vanilla,very sweet sugar, some yeasty aftertaste. I like this one a lot! But you cant drink this

330 ml bottle via Beer Planet. 2007 Vintage. Pours a cloudy brown with only a light head. Some malt and dark fruits to the nose. Tastes of spice, brown sugar, wood, and toasty malts.Complex.  Full bodied and warm as a 10%+ beer should be but well balanced. A great Belgian.

Hazy brown, with a thin white head.  Aroma is dark fruit and tootsie rolls, but fainter than expected.  Taste is just as it smells, but with a biting, almost tart apple-skin edge. Theres woodiness and alcohol into the finish, with a complex figgy swirl of flavors.  $10/330ml (S2GOT)

2011 bottle. I feel this beer would have improved with age but I picked it up while on vacation. Little head, notes of dried fruit and caramel, yeast. There is a tannic character I am not particularly fond of which I feel would dissipate with age.

Bottle from Beautiful Beers. Vintage 2010. Lack of aroma but develops a bit later into stewed fruit and alcohol. Small head with light lacing afterwards. Taste of fruitcake, sweetness, some oak and light spice. Liquorice and alcohol sharpness at end. Excellent beer.
2006 bottle.  Heavier than the Pannepot with more toasty grain and no spice.  Slippery with some juicy grape.  Finishes toasty with some concentrated sweetness.

Pours dark brown with a small beige head. Nose is raisins, plums, cloves and cinnamon. Flavor is sweet throughout. Not as much bitter as it's brother pannepot. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy with a long aftertaste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Nice strong ale that has an intense dark color and a little bitterish taste. The Pannepeut manages to be complex but also refreshing. Above average.

What a pleasure to do my first rating at ratebeer with that magical beer !!
Sorry to say that Im belgian... But in fact that one was doing first for the 
danish market. Thank you guys !! Hopefully the production is now general. One thing to say FIRST: go and buy that one. Its a pure mystery,
a real "monk mystery". Aromas come in the first nose exactly like an irish coffee, full of sensations, infinite in complexity, nearly a trappist ....
And the taste is extraordinary, full, nice, round, well balanced... 
What to say when you meet a prodigious beer. Try it is adopt it !!
I have tried very nice beers in my life, and Im not at all a guy to say that
a product is the best in the world, but in that case, Im really proud to
give the maximum note to that splendid beer.
Thank you very much everybody to let me give the first 5/5 for that beer on
ratebeer. For my first rating, Im very honoured that you let me do it.
And Im completely sure that others will follow...
(Note please that the label on the webpage is that of the "pannepot", but we are speaking here about the "pannepeut". Label of this one is with a
ship too, but in grey colour, on a grey sea. But its not grey in the glass !! )
Bottle. Dark amber with small beige head. Aroma is malt, yeast, dried fruits, caramel and toffee. Flavour is malt, medium sweet, yeast, dried fruits, caramel, raisin and a little vinous.
Vintage 2006. Hazy reddish brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, dried fruit, spicy and port. Flavor is quite sweet moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 130312
UPDATED: MAR 16, 2013 De color marrón oscuro y giste beige. Aroma afrutado y especiado. Sabor a caramelo, fruta madura, especias. Buena pero no tanto como la Pannepot original.

2011 bottle.  It is not as foamy as a lot of Belgians.  Yeasty, slightly bitter aroma with some floral undercurrents.  The flavor is likewise sweet and yeasty with some bitter notes - robust and almost meaty.  It makes an impact on the palate and creates a warming tingle.  I cant say I love it, but it is unique.  It was so yeasty that it made my belly swell up.  I may have gotten a weak bottle, because I didnt see any other reviews like this one.
2007 vintage from a bottle.  This has aged quite nicely. Mellow raisin, fig, and dark candi sugar. Flavor is smooth raisin and roasty malts. Age has softened this up, but is a bit thin.

Bottle, 2007 vintage, 03/01/2012.  Pours deep mahogany, two-finger head, great lacing.  Rich aroma of plum, raisins, spiced malts, chocolate toffee.  Taste is sweet with dark fruits, raisins prevalent, dark bread, cinnamon, other spices, earthy bitterness in the finish.  Palate is medium, smooth with little hint of alcohol.  Excellent brew.

Dark, dark brown pour. Big creamy tan head. Lacing left behind the slow fall. Alcohol nose with malt and raisins. Sweet malty flavor with some alcohol. A slight tannic bitterness on the back. A little thin and boozy but still good.

Awesome beer.  Aroma is figs/dates and spicy dough.  Taste is dark fruits and nice sweetness that finishes dry.  Also notes of leather and wood in there too but the dominant flavor really is the dark fruit.. Nicely done.

Aroma of raisins, figs, iron, and a nice toffee.  Pours ugly Belgian brown with a medium but lingering head.  Taste is more tart than expected.  Great note of dates, fresh raisin, and a hint of spiced rum.  Great Belgian ale.  A real treat.
2011 vintage. Huge huge plum flavors, high carbonation. Rich malty backbone. This is a mother ducking Belgian strong! Muscles from brussels!

11.2 oz. bottle, pours a murky reddish brown with a small off-white head. Aroma of dark fruits, coffee, spices, yeast and brown sugar. Flavour of burnt brown sugar, dark fruits (plum, raisins), light spices, yeast, chocolate and caramel. Very complex with a deep flavour profile. Delicious.

Plusieurs saveurs sont actives dans ce brassin. La mélasse, caramel, noisettes et la liste habituelle de fruits comme les dattes, figues et un kick de zest dagrumes en final. Lenrobage végétale des houblons est assez brillant. Belle personnalité.

Dark cider/brown color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, rich fruit, licorice, & spice; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, caramel/syrup, dark fruit (notably plums & figs), raisons, spice, and chocolate; The alcohol is fairly well hidden; Nicely balanced and complex; Overall, a bit sticky - but very tasty brew.

Bottle 33 cl. Pours hazy brown amber with a great creamy tanned head leaving laces. Aroma is very nice; good malty and bready body, add some sweetness, fruityness, caramel and spicy Belgo yeast to that and voila. Flavor is malty, a bit acidy, sourish, spicy, pungent, fruity and bitter. Very nice. Finishes bitter, dry and fruity.

10-02-11 Bouteille 2011: Cuivrée brune très foncée avec reflets rougeatres, légère effervescence et faible collet de mousse beige. Arômes de fruits rouges, de canneberges, de caramel, toffee avec une note acide et de chocolat. Asser sucrée, peut-être  unpeu trop, avec une amertume moyenne et une petite note surette. Corps moyen, mais plus léger que ce a quoi je mattendais. Texture moyennement mince et légèrement huileuse avec une asser forte carbonisation et une finale amer, sur des notes surettes et alcoolisées. Pas très facile a boire.
Part of the Belgian taster set at Davis Beer Shoppe. Probably the best out of the group. Tasted of dark fruits and malty goodness. Very solid beer.

2007 vintage. 

Pours a dark chestnut brown color with golden orange edges and a half finger light beige head that quickly settles into a lasting ring.  Spotty lacing left behind. 

Sweet, slightly earthy aroma with some zesty spice, estery yeast, dark fruit and sweet malt.  Peppery with cinnamon and peppermint followed by a slight medicinal/syrupy presence, bread and dark fruit notes. Hints of grape, raisin, fig and alcohol. 

Medium bodied with a nice balance of zesty spice, earthy hops, dark fruit sweet malt and alcohol.  Hints of pepper, cinnamon, peppermint and clove followed by a strong dark fruit character.  Hints of dark cherry, grape, fig and raisin before a slight boozy finish.  Some alcohol flavor but not much heat.  High abv relatively well masked.  More complex as it warms with a slight syrupy, medicinal quality but still pretty tasty.

Bouteille de 330ml. Millésime 2010. Bière acajou foncée avec une belle mousse brune, les bulles sont grosses et font beaucoup de bruit lors du versage. Le nez est composé dun mélange de fruits confits et de caramel épicé. La bouche est chaleureuse, ronde, épicée. Tout est en harmonie, lalcool se fait discret. Un délicieux produit.

33cl bottle. Almost black with a little brownish head. Nose : Caramel and roasted malts. It has a cheesy aromas. Nuts and coffee notes. Overall dairy and vanilla like. Some dried fruits there too. Sip : Medium to high density with almost no carbonation. Striking sweet with a little ester fruits aromas like banana, raisins and cherries. Followed by complex bitterness of goldnbrown gray toast and some coffee with it. The estery touch makes it closer to a Belgian quadruple beers made by monks in this country so I guess this could be one of the reasons its called "Monks Ale". Nice one.

(33 cl, vintage 2010)  Une robe brune acajou et son anneau de mousse.  Des parfums de caramel et de figues en confiture.  Un alcool à peine perceptible.  Dautres fruits qui sexpriment.  Des saveurs de malts grillés aux sèches consonances.  Un mélange intelligent et profond de notes épicées et fruitées.  Un alcool justement sucré qui manifeste une certaine amertume.  Une bouche bien tenue avec une effervescence modérée.  Une texture crémeuse.  Une finale maltée et épicée.   Un éberlué qui arrête son analyse à la con et qui profite des dernières gorgées.

2011. Cola brown body; frothy tan stoutish head. Deep sweet rummy raisiny aroma. Flavor - drier than regular Pannepot, more wood, chocolate mousse type flavors are absent. Rather this has some porter qualities; almost completely different beer. Very smooth; bit of heat in the back gives away the abv. I may like this better, and my guess is that this is a better candidate to hold on to.

330 ml bottle bought @ Etre Gourmet and consumed on January 26. Pours very dark chestnut brown with a rather small off-white that doesnt leave much trace while quickly dissipating. Smell is sweet, malty, fruity and spicy with liquorice root, figs, caramel, pumpernickel and some alcohol. Taste is sweet, slightly sour, spicy, and very malty with pumpernickel, cloves, liquorice, figs, plums and orange zest. Finish is sweet, malty and spicy.

2007 bottle at home. It pours slightly hazy mahogany brown, with a foamy beige head. The nose is caramel, gingerbread, dried fruit, cherry, marmalade and honey. The taste is caramel, brown sugar, milk chocolate, date, fig, raisin, nut, ginger, oak, roasted malt, some decent bitterness, with a warming, dry finish. Full body, moderate carbonation and slightly oily mouth-feel. A quality brew, but doesnt quite stand up against Pannepot.

Pours with little to no head. The color is A rusty nail. The nose has cedar/hickory, cinnamon and nutmeg. A bit gingerbready. The body is very light. The flavors are cherry, plum with a rich chocolate forest cake. Finishes with a crisp bitterness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

1/20/12. 11.2oz bottle from a trade... cant remember who for sure... sorry! Cloudy amber pour with basically no head. Surprisingly plain aroma with some dark fruits, yeast, and brown sugar. Yeasty Belgian flavor with lingering fruitiness and yeasty bitterness. Not bad!
Bottle at the brass tap, pours a redish caramel color with aromas of caramel, sweet malt, dark fruit, and a touch of spice.  Flavor is the same, really good beer that I cant stop drinking.
brownish read with minimal head. aroma of big caramel, fig, raisin, and sugar. flavor of sweet breads, caramel, fig, toasted sugar..nice

Pours dark caramel color with tan head. Aromas of dark fruits and caramel. Very sweet caramel flavor with raisins and figs with some candi sugar and Belgian yeast. Medium to full body with soft carbonation and a syrupy mouthfeel.
Tap. Taste is malt, intense caramel! Dried fruits, brown sugar, alcohol and spices, a bit of complexity.  Body is full and creamy. Very enjoyable.

On tap: aroma heaps of dark dried fruits, fig, raisins, plum, very fruity, grapes,  vinous, nutty, hazelnuts, very rich and malty, deep caramel. Smells almost like grape soda, thats a compliment! A bit dusty, light cardboard, brown sugar, molasses . Taste: rich, full mouthfeel, light oily, very fruity, dried fruits, raisins, plum, fig, high carbonation, some dryness, loads of sweetness, Belgian yeast,  banana, vinous, light fruity acidity, some grassy notes, smooth, very  complex!

Pours hazelnut brown with gold shine, with an eggshell white head. Nose: caramel, apple tart, raisins. Taste: sweetness of caramel and mocca coffee ice cream, some liquorice. Slight roast as well in the finish.

3oz tasting at DBS. Aroma is much less in this one than most Belgians. Tastes toasty and of dark fruit. Also has some earthy and funky notes. Great beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2006 vintage bottle shared by badnewsbeers. Ruddy sediment-laden orange-brown body, thin cream head. Nose of toffee and brown sugar, delicate and sweet with hints of rubber cement. Body reminiscent of an earthy apple cider, with spice, toffee, and candi sugar, balanced by leafy bitterness and hints of alcohol. This bottle held up nicely. That said, after my initial joy trying Pannepot for the first time, I have not been blown away by the beer or its siblings since then.

11.2oz bottle in a shaker.  Pours deep brown with a lacy, light beige head.  Aroma of spicy yeast, caramel malts, strong brown sugar with a little chocolate, and floral hops.  Flavor really strong on everything, hiding the alcohol well.  Smooth texture.  A really good beer.

Very black in colour, thick creamy longlasting head and out of this world aroma of coffee, caramel and Bourbon. The smell of this brew is super-complex and very fine.                                                                                       Great beer

Dark fruits on the nose prunes and dates with just a hint of spice.  Pouts a dark amber.  Caramelized malts with some richer molasses notes dark fruits like prunes and dates as well.  Anise notes develope as it warms.  Very nice to drink

33cl bottle from 2007, I know the new versions so there is quiet some difference between this 4 year old bottle and trhe new ones. Its very sweet, a huge fruit taste and no alcohol. It looks dark red-brown with a lot of sediment if you pour it out completely.

Sampled at the day after thanksgiving tasting 2011. Murky brown pour with no head. Raisin and plum are the keynotes here.  Quite tasty. Creamy body as the yeast was very roused on my sample.  Good stuff.
This beer has the taste and the level of the beer from De Struise. This is a little less good then the Pannepot. To be tried.

Courtesy of Footbalm, (I believe). Muddy, murky brown, tan film. Some spice and caramel up front, but rather light aroma. Again spice dominates the flavor profile. Decent malt backbone, light floral hops, faint sourness in backend. Decent overall.

This is a vintage 2007 bottle that was purchased at Star Grocery in Berkeley, CA.  I believe this was the last bottle they had.  Musty, minerally, and lightly spicy aroma.  Some sweet, fruity, and estery notes are also there.  Mild-moderate oxidation.  Mildly hazy garnet-amber body with a small-medium off-white head.  Sweet and metallic flavors are present to start, before this becomes rather minerally.  Has a good deal of fruitiness in the middle.  Finishes with more metallic character and a slightly ethanolic presence.  Seems a little thin.

33cl flesje uit 2010. Alcohol 10%
Ingeschonken in mijn test tulpglas. Mooie romige schuimkraag. De kleur van het bier is donker kastanje kleur bijna zwart. De schuimkraag kleeft niet tegen de wand van het glas. Bijna olieachtig qua vloeistof, vol van smaak. De smaak is abrupt. Ik proef accenten van koffie, toetsen van karamel en het broodachtige. 
De smaak is perfect in balans: niet zoet, een beetje bitter van de hop, niet zuur.  Een fantastisch geniet bier.
Bottle shared with northropfrye. I can taste the molasses in there. A thick sweet rich flavour. Chocolate and coffee at first. Theres a lot to it. I like it a lot.
2007 bottle in tulip glass. Dark brown appearance with brown head. Aroma is malty and fruity. Taste is malt, dried fruit, well masked abv, a bit of warmth.
33cl bottle. Pours hazy brown with a slight light brown head. Smells caramell malty, fruity, abit raisins. Tastes caramell malty, abit fruity, touch of raisins, abit cognac, lovely blend.

11.2 oz bottle from West lakeview liquors. 2011 vintage still too hot... Pours deep brown, off-white head that leaves good lacing. Raisins, plums and bread in the aroma. Full bodied, fruity flavor that sits well with the raisins and plums. I enjoyed this beer but not as much as the regular!

2011 vintage. Pours a two-finger cream head that fades slowly leaving some lace. Opaque dark brown color, ton of yeast left in bottle. Medium carbonation and medium bodied. Dark fruit nose and flavor is also dark fruit, some tartness with alcohol finish. Pricey at $7.99 for a 330ml bottle from Julios Liquors Westborough, Ma.

The pour is a very dark, muddy, ruby color with a fairly small, beige, creamy head which settles to a very thin froth and leaves some sticky, frothy lace.  The nose is nice with rich nutty English toffee, some mocha coffee notes, molasses and brown sugar, light date, wisps of alcohol, and faint herbal and fig.  The flavor is similar but darker and less rich; light molasses, herbal roast, some dry leather, dark chocolate, and still some date and toffee in there.  The palate is nearly full, soft to lively, slightly warming, and round.  The beer finishes long with nice roast, still herbal, fig emerging, and dry leather still on the tongue.  Certainly different from the original but nearly as complex and rich with great warming notes as well as a drinkable nature.  A very good beer from a brewery I am happy has made it to Colorado.

33cl bottle, 2009 vintage, tulip glass.
Pours a cloudy dark brown, with only a tiny ring of tan head, and visible sediment on the bottom.
Smells of caramel malt and dried fruits.
Tastes of honey, nuts, roasted malt, and some fruits and peppery spices.
Full-bodied, with a smooth carbonated feel, and finishes with a warming alcohol feel.

Simply an amazing and complex beer.

Bottle. Moderate to heavy roasted and cookie for the malt, moderate cooked orange for the hops, light dough and broth for the yeast, with hints of toffee, raisin, brown sugar and bourbon. Head is small, wispy with bigger bubbles, light tan with fair lacing and is almost fully diminishing. Color is murky reddish brown. Flavor starts heavily sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes moderately sweet and lightly acidic and bitter. Palate is on the fuller side of medium, creamy to syrupy, with a soft carbonation with a lightly alcoholic and astringent finish. Sweet and tangy and heavy, this Belgian Strong Ale has some bold aspect to it.

Pours deep red to brown or black. little head. Nose has elements of plums and raisins and immediate oxidation from the first whiff. Flavor is again oxidized less than sweet malts. thin mouthfeel. This one really missed its mark.

(bottle, 33cl, as Panepeut, vintage 2007) Hazy, dark brown coloured floaty-laden hue with a beige mid-sized foamy head. Rich and toasted malty aroma with notes of caramel, dried fruits, ginger-spices and a distinctively vinous sherry-like touch. Sweet and roasty bitter flavour, almost full bodied with a pleasantly carbonated mouthfeel. Toast-malty, caramely and fruity taste, again with noble vinous accents; sweet-bitter toasty and slightly fruity finish with a well-hidden alcoholic note that warms from the background. Very pleasant. 11.X.11

2007 vintage.  11.2 ounce bottle purchased a year ago at Holiday Wine Cellar ($7.99).  Pours a cola brown with violet highlights and two fingers of beige foam which quickly dissipates.  Complex aroma of bready malts, cherry, cinnamon (the aforementioned = "fruit cake"), brown sugar, and a hint of alcohol.  Flavor is also quite complex with notes of rich toffee, bready malts, cherry, raisin, other dark fruits, spice, and a hint of chocolate.  Definitely sweet but not cloying with a sticky syrupy mouthfeel.  The 10% ABV is altogether hidden.  An excellent beer...the fact that it is now four years old has probably brought out some of the nice complexities here.   Will have to look for more of this.  (626, 616)

06 version on draft at Mucho Chingon @Local Option, Chicago.  Pours muddy dark red with a beautiful off-white head and incredible retention.  Aroma is incredibly complex with notes of grape soda, leather, figs, raisins, spice, and a myriad of other notes I could not recognize.  Taste has a hint of biscuit, purple grapes, spice, esters, raisin, molasses, and virtually no alcohol presence.  Body is medium, sticky, low carbonation, long spicy fruity finish.  Overall, very unique, complex and intriguing.  Definetly my favorite example of this style so far.
lakrids aroma,dark brown, lightly bitter, light body, soft carbonation, fizzy, soft lakrids finish.
Bottle, very unique this one pours a nice dark, kind of sour smelling and tasting, bit stout like, got some chocolate in there, very nice drinkable brew
Bottle. Pours dark brown with tan head. Nose/taste of caramel, toffee, dark fruits and dates. Lots of carbonation. Medium body.

33cl bottle at Håndverkerstuene. Labelled as Pannepeut. 2008 edition. Brown colour with a small light brown head. Aroma is not hints of caramel, fruits, and hops as the label claims. Its loaded with caramel, malts and fruits. Notes pear, sugar and belgian yeast as well. Flavour is sweet. The alcohol is noticable, but soon buried within the caramel, malts, sugar, fruits and yeast. Faint hints of hops.

11.2 oz bottle bought in denver and opened into pint glass in San Diego.  Looks super dark nut brown.  Light slightly off white mocha thickness head.  Superbly carbonated for 4 years old.  Smells of old wood and roasted malts with tiny belgian style funk.  Tastes like the best damn alt or even double alt beer i have ever had.  On the palate it is pretty much dark thick old with some alcohol like a splash of awesome whiskey.   Definitely gunna be on my top ten list of beers for several years at least.  I wish this beer never ended!  Overall 9.5 of 10 ... seriously!!

Bottle of the 2011 release. Cloudy rusty brown with very little head. Aroma is fruit cake, port, spices, caramel. Medium body with a slick texture and a good balance. Flavours are raisins, caramel, plums, sour cherries, burnt sugar and a very subtle bitterness in the finish.
Bottle. Poured dark black with large white head. Sweet vanilla aroma with a hint of chocolate. Flavour is similar with a sweet finish. Very unique.

2008. 33cl bottle. Dark brown with a persistent and tall intense tan head. Malty aroma with hints of red fruits. Taste is sweet like a Porto with notes of caramel and belgian yeast, thats sure. Oily texture with flat carbonation.

Very dark red brown with a small beige head. Aroma is caramel malty with a bit of boozy fruit cake. Taste additionally gives a bit of cherry drop/cherry brandy,, caramel, sweet with a bit of spice. Slightly bitter finish. Smooth and full bodied. Nicely different to the regular Pannepot.

Tasted on 8/25/11 from a 330mL bottle purchased at Binnys Lincoln Park, 2007 vintage.  Pours an extremely dark brown-amber with a very thick tan head that shows excellent retention, while slowly receding to a nice layer of lace that sticks around forever, leaving a bit of lace residue along the inside of the glass.  The nose is very malty and fruity, with tons of intense lightly burnt caramel and brown sugar malt, along with sweet date, raisin, molasses, and dark fig and some spicy cinnamon and clove Belgian yeast.  The flavor is fairly sweet with caramel, burnt brown sugar, molasses, cola, candi sugar, fig, date, and raisin, with some lightly bitter notes and some spicy heat.  The body is full and oily with just lighter than average carbonation and a super long fruity, malty, and spicy finish.  The alcohol is hidden so well, that I feel like I could drink several of these.

Tasted at CAGarvies House, thank you!
Plum, parmesan cheese, fruitcake and rasins.

[500ml bottle, courtesy of cgarvieuk] Hazy brown pour. Tart, funky aroma, some yeast on the nose. Marzipan in there as well  certainly smells like a Belgian, with the candi sugar prevalent. Sweet fruit on the taste, leading into yeasty sweet finish. Good but didnt blow me away as I was expecting [19082011]

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2012 Bottle at Craigs. Pours a very dark red - brown colour with a lacy tan head. Lots of cinnamon on the nose and to taste. Aroma also plums, raisins, liquorice and treacle. Plum and raisin flavours again with sweet Belgian candy sugar. Moderate carbonation and a light CO2 prickle. Foamy mouth-feel. Port wine finish. Very nice but I prefer the Pannepot.

2009 Dark beer, reddish hue. Off-white head, rather thin but staying well. Aroma sweet, dried dark fruits and liquorice. Flavour quite sweet, malty, rather alcoholic. Liquorice and dried fruits come back. Caramel. Not bad, but could use some more balance.
(From 33cL bottle)

Bottle bought in bottle shop in Wollestraat in Brugge. A deep brown pour with a healthy beige head. Fruity, sweet aroma. Tastes sweet, caramel, mature plums, banana, sweet, sour, fruity. This one had a rather musty thing going on. Clearly a decent ale but not as good as the usual Pannepot IMO.
Ruby red to brown colour. Smells fruity, soapy alcohol and sweet. Tastes like sugar water, too sweet for me. Dull mouthfeel.
Hazy red/brown color, almost no head. Smell fruity, alcohol, sweet and sour. Taste sweet, sugar, alcoholic. Carbo decent, body medium. Bit dull.

Bottle @ home, courtesy of foppa78. Dark brown appearance with a brown head. Candy sugar, dark burnt sugar, belgian yeasty, raisin, caramel in the aroma. Burnt, caramelized, candy sugar, toffee, raisins, caramel, dark chocolate, quite sweet, dark belgian ale flavor. Lingering caramel and candy sugar aftertaste.

2006 vintage. 11.2 oz bottle into a chimay goblet and left on the counter for a half hour. The beer did gush upon opening. A - Nice mocha head that dies down to a solid layer of foam. Deep brown with some red tint. Theres some yeast sediment on the bottom of the glass. S - Candied dark fruits, brown sugar, malt, and light alcohol. This smells really great, very sweet and complex. T - Similar to the nose. Lots of dark brown sugar rich caramel and prune/dates. The alcohol is really well hidden but leaves some tingling. Very rich and moderately chewy mouth feel. O - Complex but not over the top. This is an amazingly well crafted quad. Glad I got a chance to try this.
2007 vintage.  Black brown colored beer with small off-white head and medium carbonation. Malty spicy aroma. Full sweet sparkling palate. Finish is malty roasted bitter dry. Nice one.

11.2oz bottle poured into snifter. 07 vintage. Dark pour with what looks like good carbonation. The aroma still has some booziness in there mixed with burnt brown sugar and malts. Flavor/mouth feel is a little low but still holds some strong qualities such as malt presence and dried fruit. Has worn out a little but still a nice drinking beer.

light sweet aroma with licorice, malt extract, alcohol, and candied fruit. pours a cloudy amber brown, small fine light tan head. flavor is very nice rich sweetness without being cloying. theres fruit, spice, malt, and a bit of grain.
medium body, silky smooth, lightly carbonated, long sweet grainy finish.

Vintage 2006. Shared bottle with2 friends.
Not much white head.  Clear amber pour.  Lovely
2007 bottle. Murky light brown body with a very small white head. Aroma has honey, spices, caramel and butter. Very smooth medium palate. Amazing sweet taste with caramel, brown sugar. Excellent.

2007 bottle: Aroma is a fantastic amalgamation of honey, yeasty walnut, and banana creme, a sublime baklava and moonpie treat. Opaque brown, thin yellow head. Drinks warm, warmer than even the 10% on the label. Mouthfeel is smooth and body is relatively full. Flavor is sweet cherries and stewed apples, decidedly less complex than the aroma, which was very inviting. Candi is present. Finishes with twigs. Good balance, but less complex than I hoped. If only it tasted as good as it smells, Id probably have two perfect ratings, and both would be from De Struise. Outstanding beer, nonetheless.

.33 L bottle. 2007 vintage. 
 
APPEARANCE: Dark brown. Hues of ruby. Opaque. Healthy dose of sediment. 
 
Head is 1-2 fingers, uniform, light khaki, short duration. 
 
 
AROMA: Dark roasted malt, red currant, tangy red stone fruit, faint vinous character, coffee, chocolate. 
 
TASTE: Almost like an imperial Abbey dubbel. Plentiful dried dark fruit such as dates, light prunes, and even some dried blueberry-like character. Belgian yeast, lightly toasted malts, dark bready notes with faint rye character, dark Belgian candi, nutty, caramel, coconut.
 
Roast bitterness (complimented by a hint of tangy vinous character) is especially evident on finish. 
 
 
MOUTH FEEL: Higher side of medium body. Semi dry. Slightly viscous. Semi sweet (complimented by subtle vinous undertones), yet far from cloying. Light alcohol warmth. 
 
 
OVERALL: Interesting tangy red stone fruit notes on nose. Became more enjoyable as it warmed up. Definite differences between nose and palate.
Aroma of caramel, toffee, anise, yeast, and nuts. Taste of sweet caramel, toffee, light roast, cocoa, nuts, smoke, with a bit of citrus, and light alcohol as well.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2011 Bottle: 2006: Clear red broen colour, creamy head. Aroma is Viny,wood, Camilla, caramelly, dark chocolate. Flavor: dusty, caramelly, chocolate, viny, Woody , medium to full body! Well done!!

Bottle. 2007. Pours dark brown, beautiful white head. Straw and honey molasses in nose, also apples and pear, boozy fruit par-fey. Fairly heavy body, low carbonation despite large head, yet drinkable. Burns boozy down throat, dried pears/other stone fruit linger on tongue. Dig it.

Bottle direct from Belgium and poured into a Captain Lawrence tulip. 

Pours a light copper color with a good, though slightly short-lasting, white head. Good spotty lacing on the sides of the glass and a collar throughout.
