The nose strikes me immediately as being pretty light on the dark fruits, with more caramel and malt coming through. Aside from that, a spicy character takes over and really sends a few good notes. Light hops there as well. Different, but quite nice. The flavor is along the same lines--nice light spice with some bready malt and light fruits. Hoppy character is there as well, and then combines quite well with the spiciness to form a beautiful finish. Medium body. Nicely done, Struise.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-11-2011

Vintage 2006. Shared bottle courtesy of tarjei. Escapes from bottle half a minute after opening. Fluffy, light brown head on murky, brown body, particles visible. Prune, spices and a hint of berries in the aroma. Sweet, acidic and bitter flavors with notes of toasted tobacco. Medium to full body. Light syrupy with medium carbonation. Finishes dry.

2007 vintage.  Dark iced tea pour with a nice offshore head.  Nose is very sweet and has the characteristics of a dubbel and champagne.  Lots of fruit and toffee.  I enjoyed the aroma  Taste follows the nose to a degree but it has a sweet wine flavor which I am not sure about.  Nice warming finish.  Nice beer.

2007 Vintage [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */: tasted alongside a 2009 Pannepot, this one had a lighter body and a more dominating liquorice taste, slightly lighter but still dark brown with very small dirty white head, overripe dark fruits, raisins, figs prunes, brown sugar, toffee, dark malt, hazelnuts, sweet with spices, good but a touch to much liquorice to me, preferred the 2009 Pannepot

Pannepeut 2008. Bottle (33cl) from Vinmonopolet (Vika), Oslo. Small, light beige head, good retention - settles as a fat film and sticky ring with a little lacing. Colour is hazy, watery golden brown. Nose is concentrated sweet fruity malt, figs, prunes, caramel. The nose was powerful, but appears modest compared to the mindblowing taste. Intense raisin-like malt, wonderfully balanced by sweet-acidic fruit and mild bitterness. Medium/full body, soft carbonation. Lovable.

03/08/2010 33cl bottle @ home  2007 - Thanks to Klaas for the bottle!
Aroma: (compared to the Pannepot) more cloves. Taste: much spicier, a bit more bitter, hoppier than the Pannepot.

11.2oz bottle, 2007 edition. pours a hazy, dark russet color with a thin, off-white head and light lacing. aroma is great with big dark fruit notes of raisin, fig, and prunes backed by sweet toffee, cider spices, and hints of honey wheat bread. flavor is delicious as well, perhaps not as smooth or elegant as the rest of the Pannepot crew but nice nonetheless with belgian yeast, brown sugar, orange peel, and light toast backed by candied raisins and fig newton filling. palate is medium bodied with crisp carbonation and a short, dry, dark fruit finish. overall, a very nice belgian strong.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 2007 bottle tasted blind at a top 10 quad blind tasting

A: Muddy brown, super thin off-white/dirty water head

S: Mild dark fruits, peppery spicing, and notes of caramel and brown sugar.

T: Similar to the nose with perhaps a bit more of the malt coming out.  Relatively indistinct and mild.

M: Moderate body.  Smooth, perhaps a little thin.

O: Good and plenty enjoyable.  Towards the bottom in the tasting though

I drank this from a 11.2 oz bottle from the De Struise web shop...The beer pours medium brown, like a quad should look but a little lighter of a brown than the pannepot. There are tons of yeasy floaties. The head is disappointing, only rising a little then gone right away...The aroma is really dark fruits, raisins, caramel with a slight hop finish...The taste is ok, doesnt quite live up to a great quad though. A little light in feel and a very alcoholic finish. The taste is in general is just kind of flat.

0.33l bottle shared with ClubGonzo. Pours a deep brown body with a thin almost non existing bubbly off-white head. Nose is strong plums, dried fruits, some really nice strawberry and brown sugar. Medium+ bodied and medium carbonated giving a near creamy mouthfeel. First sip gives off some alcohol at first along with sweet dark fruits, dried figs, yeast and a nice spicyness. Also some licorice and a light woodiness hidden in there. Sweet and sharp aftertaste that kicks in like a bomb in your throat a long time after you have swallowed. Quite complex, well balanced and really tasty.

2007 bottle Pannepeut - pours an opaque red-brown body with a tempting hue. Small but dense head. Soft aroma of sweet/sour fruit, hazelnuts. Taste is very complex, soft, wine-like. Lots of malts, spices, warm alcohol. A very savoury beer.

Bouteille de 2007. Belle couleur brune-rouge, clair si on ne verse pas la levure. Les notes sont fruits secs, prunes, pruneaux, figues. Tres agreable, le sucre de canne est present en arriere fond et rend cette biere ronde, la premiere impression est plutot fruitee et le finish alcoolise mais reste persistant.
Caramel, coffee, nuts, chocolate, brown, cloudy, licorice, one of the best Ive tried.
Picked up the 2007 bottle when I was in Belgium.  Pours hazy brown with an off white head.  Aroma of dark fruit, malt, Belgian yeast.  Nice sweet, well balanced flavor.
Light and sweet, dark fruit nose. Taste is lightly sweet, some toffee, raisins, candi sugar. Nice.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet, Valkendorfgt, Bergen. 2008 Edition. Pours murky dark brown with a big frothy off-white/tanned head.Aroma : Light roasted, complex fruity with some figs. Taste is medium sweet, nutmeg and even some liquorice, thick mouthfeel, raisins. Long sweet aftertaste, delicious.

330 ml bottle. 2007 vintage.
Pours a dark hazy brown colour with a foamy white head. Good retention. Aroma of dark dried fruits and dark malts. Flavour of caramel malts, chocolate, Belgian yeast and dark fruits. Medium bodied with a thick mouthfeel. Very good with a dry fruity finish.

330ml bottle from Bierkompass
2007 vintage - Pours light brown with a nice foamy head. Taste is smooth and malty and has hints of caramel. Not quite as good as the regular Pannepot.

Bottle 0,33 l from Willems in Grobbendonk (B). Brown with garnet reflections and tight creamy and beige head. Very malted flavors, dried fruits, licorice and molasses sweetness, rum, full of spices. The taste is a candy store with all the greedy flavours promised in the perfume. Unctuous, syrupy, it has a very dense body, supported by a hoppy note. A wealthy beer.

2007 bottle.  Big malty Belgian.  Lots of caramel, cherries, prunes and other fruity malt flavors.  Flavor gets a bit sweet but its a minor criticism.  Mouthfeel is smooth and rich.  Good flavor and complexity but not quite up to normal Pannepot for me.
2007 bottle. Nice retention, a gorgeous beer. Big figgy dark fruits, nice malty backbone with a touch of spicy yeast. A touch of tartness in the finish.

Bottle (2007); Pour is dark brown with a creamy , frothy tan/off white head. Excellent retention and lacing in this snifter - Dark Fruits, chocolate, sweet bread on the nose. Similarities to the Pannepot are striking - The raisins, figs, cherries, brown sugars, and fresh bread swirl together with the chocolate and belgian sugars in a fantastic way. There is a slight boozy element at times, like Rum. What can I say, I love the style, and I love the brew.

Bottle. Dark brown, cloudy, average and fully diminishing light brown head. Moderate malty and sweet aroma, fruity with dark berries and spiciness. Body is medium to full, malty and sweet flavor, fruity with dark berries, light acidity and alcohol. Finish is average, malty and sweetish, alcohol dries up the finish, some peppery sharpness due to spiciness and alcohol. Quite one dimensional sweet strong ale.
Really awesome brew. Pours dark brown, cloudy and thick. The aroma is very full of raisons, super sweet. Drinks really nice and smooth. Great brew!
Una mezcla absolutamente perfecta del caracter de sus elementos principales, pan, hierbas, tierra, aparece ligeramente humo de madera noble y vainilla.

2006 bottle. I cant remember who sent this to me, but thanks to whomever you are! The bottle gushes slowly as its opened. Pours a hazy very dark brown color with a medium sized creamy brown head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of big bready and caramelly notes, a good bit of raisins and dates, toffee, faint spice and a faint vegetal note. Even some chocolate if you look hard enough. Very faint oxidation notes. The taste is full of dried fruit notes... citrus, dates, raisins, figs, and huge malty notes as well. Bread, caramel, toffee. Very faint boozy notes. Full bodied. The fruitiness is a little bold for my taste, but still a damned good beer.

Bottle shared with Urbain, 2008. Pours deep brown, off-white head that leaves good lacing. Raisins, plums and bread in the aroma. Full bodied, fruity flavor that sits well with the raisins and plums. I really enjoyed this beer!

Doften är ganska diskret och har en lite stickande känsla av lacknafta över sig.
Smaken är också ganska diskret, men ändå med toner av plommon, tjära, tobak och undertoner av gräddkola. Eftersmaken hittar jag lakrits och arrak.
Trevlig öl, men tyvärr lite uddlös.

For my 800th rating a wonderful beer. Bottle 33cl from Allen 2008 vintage, many thanks. A brown beer with good head. Smell is caramel like and spicy. Aroma is a creamy caramel beer, very smooth, sweet, malty and with toasted notes. Some spices like cinnamon, vanilla, long finish still sweet with no acid notes. What a pleasure, rich body, texture is amazing very creamy.

A: The pour is a dark amber color with a fizzy khaki colored head with surprisingly poor retention.

S: Banana bread overwhelms the nose on the first sniff. Sweet caramel, dark fruits, and candi sugar come through next as do an array of spices. Theres (initially) a hint of alcohol on the back end that becomes more pronounced as the beer warms.

T: Sweet bananas, plums, and raisins provide some fruity notes while the caramel and brown sugar provide the base of the sweetness. The downfall of this beer is that there is just far too much alcohol coming through which makes it tough to drink.

M: The body is medium, not quite as full as I had expected, with a surprisingly "mid-range" level of carbonation. Again, more alcohol heat.

D: What a surprising let down. I thoroughly enjoyed Pannepot, so I thought this would be more of the same. You cant win em all...

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2013 Bottle 2007, bb 06/2013. A darkbrown beer with a medium and beige head. The nose is fruity, syrup, strawberries, raisins and some warming alcohol. Taste is also full of dark fruits, prunes, raisins, some roastiness, alcohol is disappered and it is there only with the warming feeling. The aftertaste is dryer and sweetness is not too much, also some spicyness nad chocolate appears to the taste. Typically with yeast, the taste is calmer and also bananas can be found from the already complicated taste. Smooth and pleasant to drink. Complex, fruitfull and smoothly enjoyable beer without weakness; definedly worth to try.

Sample at Borefts Beer Festival 2010. Pours a hazy brown beer with a weak offwhite head. The aroma is weak with malt. The flavor is malt, fruit, sweetness and alcohol. The palate is sweetness and some bitterness. Overall a good beer.

Pour from a bottle revealed a murky brown shade with a tan head. Aromas lingered of caramelized sugar, almond, and toffee. Nice rich mouthfeel. Flavors are abundant ; dried fruit, oak, and anise. Well balanced hop bite at the finish. Excellent long finish. Very tasty no doubt.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2011 Bottle: 2007 version:
Big light brown foamy head on top of a hazy brown beer.
Smell some cough syrup, dark fruits and spices.
The taste is once again amazing: some sort of a mix of cough syrup and sweet stout, or something... Light viscous and low carbo, bit tingling on the tongue, sweet bitter, delicious.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Pours cloudy copper with a large beige head. Aroma is malt and marcipan. Flavour is malt, sweet, fruit and plum.
Tulip glass. Very hazy brown. Yeast and fruits on the nose. delightful. For me this is something I need to try again.

Bottle from Bierkompass. 2007 Vintage. POured hazy brownish color with a thin firm white head that quickly disappears. Aroma is malty and sweet caramel and dark fruits, alcohol. Flavor is very complex, slightly sweet, berries, caramel and spcies. Incredibly smooth palate, like silk. No trace whatsoever of any alcohol. Very very enjoyable.

330 ml bottle shared by lushawn- thanks again, Shawn!  2007 vintage.  Pours a cloudy brown-orange color with a small off-white head.  Notes of Belgian yeast, earth, fruits (raisins, grapes, plums), sweet caramel malts, brown sugar, and a little spice.  Medium-bodied, with mild carbonation and a yeasty mouthfeel.  Finishes dry, with a ripened fruit taste.  Sweet and fruity overall.
2007 vintage bottle.  Chocolate brown pour with small off white head.  Sweet bruin beer loaded with raisin and other dark fruits, caramel malts, and toffee..
Bottle.   Aroma of raisin,  burnt brown sugar, honey,   and red wine.   Sweet caramel.   A bit too sweet.  Nice dark fruit charater.  Thin body.  Vinous sweet raisomn belgian beer.

Big frothy head.  Aroma is a light, almost dull combination of candied sugar, spice, cinnamon, and dough - still quite pleasant.  Flavor is consistent with the aroma with raisin, caramel, sweet malt, and a blunt alcohol tingle on the finish.  Smooth and light feel in the mouth.  Damn tasty but nowhere near the glory of the Reserva.

Relatively subtle aroma of raisin and other dried fruits. Very complex taste with similar hints as the aroma as well as blackberries, which stays as a long-lasting aftertaste. Similar to an Imperial Stout but more vinous.

Bottle 2007. Hazy brown colour with a medium-sized beige head. Malty aroma with dark fruits, toffee and alcohol. Flavour is sweet malt, toffee, raisins, liquorice, dark fruits and hints of alcohol. Medium-bodied, sweet and slightly bitter finish.

2007 Bottle thanks DalzAle. Pour is brown and cloudy with a creamy kahki head. Aroma is sweet malt and red licorice. Taste is dried fruit like apricots and rasins and black licorice. Palate is sticky with nice carbonation and finishs chaulky. Very good tasting beer, would like another!

Bottle (2007 label). Pours with a thinner, tan bubbly head; mahogany brown color with ruby highlights, and denser looking. Very raisiny aromas, bit of toffee, and pretty sweet overall.  Tastes mirror the aroma to a degree with sweet raisins, rich maltiness, bittersweet chocolate almost actually.  Very warming, sticky, and pretty dense.  Nice nightcap.

33 cl bottle, year 2008. Pours a opaque chocolate brown with minimal head. Nose is toffee, dark fruits, molasses and alcohol. Palate is sweet with raisins, brown sugar, vanilla and a touch of salty chocolate in the finish. Lighter mouth feel.

Nice red berries on the nose.I was expecting a bit more complexity. Good length and quite a lot of residual sugars.
Not bad but not great.
Dark amber with nice beige head. Aroma caramelmalt, dark fruits,dark chocolate. Taste sweet from malt, dark fruits, chocolate. Full body, smooth and creamy text. Finish long sweetness

330ml bottle.  Pours a cloudy dark brown color with a small light tan head that lasts.  Not lacking in viscosity.  The aroma is big, intense, and awesome.  Caramel, toffee, raisins and other dark fruits, molasses.  Big amazing flavor as well, up there with regular Pannepot.  Deep, rich malt notes, lots of toffee and some toast.  Prunes, dates, and raisins, molasses, and slight anise.  Thick and silky smooth on the mouthfeel.  Full-bodied with soft carbonation.  Despite the richness, finishing a sizable pour was easy.  This is another excellent incarnation of an epic beer.

Bottle from the brewery/shop at Oostvleteren; the very last, forgotten specimen of the 2007 batch, discovered by accident in a window shelve. :-) Pours a murky, dark oaky brown body with a solid dense, creamy white head. Nose is figs, raisins, wood and dark candy sugar with hints of alcohol. Beautifully composed taste: licorice, wood, dark candy sugar, sherry and hints of raisins. Warming alcohol with bitter licorice in the finish. This is a perfect winter warmer in my opinion, and among the most pronounced brews of the Pannepot series despite its three years of maturation. A truly excellent beer.

2008 version, bottled. Dark brown-orange color with a loose, high head. Tangy, fruity aroma. Flavor os raisins and caramel, tangy, fruity, somewhat sour. Nice tangy-sweet balance, big and dark. Flavorful and nice.

Bottle. Thanks to hobbersr. Pours hazy brown, thin to medium pale-tan head, spotty lacing. Nose is rye bread, fruitcake, lots of spice. Some real acidity in the nose too. Hmmmmm.... Palate us fruit, nuts, acid, spice, chocolate, cognac, really layered and lovely. rather light & balanced in the mouth. Damn solid.
330 ml bottle a dark brown black colored beer with a beige head aroma roasted malts caramel brown sugar dried fruits and spices taste roasted malts caramel dried fruits spices and some hops
Smells sweet, bread and fruits, not much on the head/lacicng but its a nice foamy, zay brown. Reminds me Rich and creamy and thick, it fades out with % and yeasty sweet malt, its quite taste.

2007 bottles courtesy of Jason, thank you sir!  Shared with Jason and Gotta.  Nearly black, medium tan head.  Aroma of raisins, prunes, licorice.  Taste is dark fruits, rich caramel.  Very nice stuff.Earlier Rating: 12/27/2008 Total Score: 42006 Danish label at Uber in Seattle Washington.  Dark maroon, murky.  Sourish caramel aroma, but much sweeter taste and a butterscotch finish.  Bizarre, in an interesting sort of way.
UPDATED: APR 6, 2017 Lovely. Rich spiced dried fruits and caramel but warmer than that. Serving: Bottle

Bottle 2007 vintage. Brown shiny colour, creamy small head. Nose is sweet, alcohol, chocolate and somewhat acidic. Taste is sweet candy with some sourness, dark fruit (prunes), wood and alcohol. Very rich, bit oily but overall smooth. Very pleasant and perfect for the colder days.

2006 bottle picked up at the Alvinne bottleshop.

A - pours a root beer color with a finger of tan head, leaves a sheet with spots of lacing.

S - dark fruits (raisin, figs), caramel, a hint of alcohol.

T - Not the most complex, but damn its tasty! Straight forward figs, grapes, yeast, and a caramel candi-sugar finish.

M/D - This is best regular version of Pannepot, hands down. Not even the 2005s I have are better (still too spiced and thats not really my thing). I finished this glass in record time because of the abrupt finish and lingering sweetness. I need another bottle.

Serving type: bottle
Poured dark brown, candied sugars, molasses, dark fruits, bready malts, alcohol, little spice.

Pannepeut.  Bottle 07.  Pours a deep stained wood colored. Solid gray head.  Nose of candy sugar, caramel, alcohol, deep refined malt profile and a touch a tartness sneaking in right around the edge.  Flavors are malty with some more of the tart edge..candy-like, warm alcoholic tones...some grape candy hints, very warming with some depth.  That being said...theres nothing here blowing my mind...a classy yeast and belgian candy sugar not an orgasm give me.

Light dry but sweet aroma.  Sweet/dry brown ale; complex dry fruit with a nice coating, lingering grain finish.  Dirty copper/brown color with an off-white head.

Notes: 2008 Vintage

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ 2006 vintage.

Apperance: Dark brown with a wee head.

Aroma: Ripe fruit, Candy sugar, Prunes, Port wine, Molasses. Fantastic!

Taste: Ripe fruit, Dark sugar, Prunes, Molasses, Spices, Malt.

Palate: Smooth as velvet. Quite sweet but not overly so. Very nice sipper that warms you up as you go.

Another fine beer from Struise. This beer is fantastic considering its almost 5 years old.

On tap. Poured a cloudy light brown with a light brown head that dissipated quickly to the edges. Aroma had notes of caramel and dark fruits (mainly plum, grapes and fig, cinnamon and some brown sugar. Flavor began sweet with candied sugar and caramel with growing spices and dark fruit notes, especially plum and fig.

vintage of 2008 
head: big, beige
colour: coca cola brown 
smell: candy sirup, anis, chocolat, malts, sweet fruits (peach ? ), little ashy/smoey 
taste: start is sweet, actually pretty sweet , dutch drops, some saltyness, bitter malty flavour, and a grassy kind of hop flavour, mouthfeel is oily
i like this much better than the "struise pannapot "

This 2007 brew has a very nice creamy beige head. I am personal not impressed by the nose, where rye is very dominant. But the taste of it combines dried fruit with soft malt, and it stay very long in your mouth. Nice beer

11.2 oz. bottle into a chalice. Pours dark brown with ruby edge, almost mahogany. One-finger tan head with good retention and an average amount of lacing. Nose reveals some licorice, dark fruit (plum, raisins, dates, figs), spices (nutmeg, coriander, cinnamon), brown sugar, grapes, yeast and brandy. Taste: At first very sweet then moves to a little tart with tastes of plum, cherry, grapes. Spices follow and a hint of chocolate. Finish is almost dry, almost oaky with some sweetness and alcohol warming. Beer is full bodied, creamy with heavy carbonation. ABV is certainly not obvious so sip carefully. This is an excellent brew with some sophistication and complexity. I will absolutely revisit it.

Bottle. The aroma is very malty, some spices, light alcoholic. The head is small, white and creamy with a normal duration. The body is light brown. A very malty taste with a soft sour note, some wine. The body is very cream and silky, medium strong with a soft carbonation.

small bottle.   dark red with a lasting light tan head.   rich dried fig, apple, and spiced fruit cake aroma.   sweet and full but with a pretty drying finish and some apparent alcohol, though not hot.   fig cake and spice with some cooked apples.   full with high carbonation, but not thick of chewy.   a sipper, but still pretty drinkable.   nice stuff; definitely a great beer to sit down with after dinner.   i wish i had some regular pannepot to compare it to, but alas, its been awhile.

2007 bottle. Pours dark brown with foamy head that dissipates fairly quickly. Caramel, spices, nutmeg, earth. Quite malty with a little bit of spiciness. Very smooth feel to it, almost creamy. Quite an interesting blend of flavors.

04-JUL-2010, 2007 bottle @home, from "Ølbutikken":
Oppened in the kitchen, and my glass was in the living room. I should have foreseen the problem:(
Bottle in mouth I run for the glass, and pour a small amount just enough to rinse out Southern Tier 2xIPA, and still Pannepøt runs out of the bottle. 
Trying to sip both the bottle and the glass, I manage to pour a glass of a very fine looking beer without to much of a mess.
It is murky brown with off-white lasting head. It does look inviting.
Nose is very malty dominated by dried fruit and moscovado sugar.
Slightly sour, high carbonation and alcohol can be noticed, but then it is 10% and it is not too present.
Very delicious beer. Cannot remember the Pannepot version, but I doubt that it was this fruity, but then again I think I have only had more "fresh" Pannepots.
Rebuy, no doubt.

Bottle as Pannepeut, 2010-07-02, Göteborg
AR: caramel, roasted malt, coffey
AP: dark brown, creamy totaly and quickly deminshing head
F: delicate coffey flavor, caramel, medium + bitterness, long suggary finish

Bottle, 2007 @ home. 
Deep reddish black, red glow, medium dense creamy head.
Aroma of liquorice, fruits, spices and a metallic sidenote.
Flavour is full sweet fruits and liquorice with a nice coffee and liquorice bitterness. Medium thick palate, lingers on for quite a bit. Very nice.
Tasted 2010-06-14. Bottle, 2007. Pours dense, dark brown with beige head. Aroma of dried fruits and wet wood. Ditto flavours. Sligthly acidic. Bitterness barely noticable. Very good.

330ml bottle 2007 vintage from IPB
Appearance : Slightly gushed. Dark brown big brown fluffy head.

Aroma : Very spicy with lots of licorice. Some red fruits and some nuts. Brown sugar. Some hops.

Taste : Quite spicy. Very sweet. Nice notes of sweet fruits. Nutty with some hops. Lots of licorice. Gets pretty warm as it heats up. Finish warm, sweet spicy and fruity. Finish is also slightly bitter.

Overall : A bit too spicy for my taste. A bit too much licorice also. Nice sweet and nutty profile. Very nice beer but a bit too spicy.

Pannepeut. 2008 bottle. Consumed May 2010. Opened with a pop. Pours an unclear brown with a small head that fades. The aroma is sweet, fruity with cherries being identified. The taste is sweet, bready, and more cherries which reminds me of the nice fruitiness that all Pannepot variants have. In fact it has a nice taste of black cherries. Very nice. The alcohol is extremely hidden and as it warms up its malty/bready character shows up more. I really liked this beer.

2007 bottle of Pannepot poured into a Duvel tulip glass. Poured a deep amber ruby brown color with a tan head that quickly dissapated. Dances on the tongue type of carbonation, maybe a little too much for my liking, almost champagne like. I pick up the booze taste pretty easily. Fruity type tastes as well.
I can appreciate the style but this beer just had too light of a mouthfeel for me.

Vintage 2008. pours dark amber with an off-white head. Aromas of dark fruit, raisins, apples, plums, young calvados. Soft medium mouthfeel with mild carbonation. Very balanced with malty sweetness, some candy sugar, toffee,  hops on the background. Finish dry and warming.. This is even better when aged a bit. Good stuff.

2008 bottle pour gives dark brown cloudy color with brief beige head.   Aroma typical Belgian dark fruits and yeast.  Complex taste initially chocolate giving way to dark fruits, citrus, yeast, spices.  Pretty acidic.  Alcohol well disguised.  Mouth feel thick and creamy.  Finish brief and a touch bitter.

Nice beer but I didnt like it as much as the Pannepot..

Bottle (Vintage 2007). Murky brown with a laced beige head. Aroma of chocolate, caramel and sticky date pudding. The flavour is chocolate, raisins, plum, dates, caramel and brown sugar. Medium bodied. Sticky mouthfeel. Spicy fruit in the finish. Not nearly as well rounded as the Pannepot but tasty regardless.

Bottle 33 cl - 2007 versie from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen. Have a glass ready or it will be all over the place. The pour is dark hazy red with an impressive almost orange fluffy head. The nose is malty with orange peel, raisins and pepper. Some of that West-vlandern sourness with alot of alcohol. The taste is huge and way more balanced than I remember it - maybe the aging have don a lot of good for this one. Alot of malts, brown sugar and dark dried fruit flavours. Some citrus peel with a sweet  and alco-burning finish that are really nice. Palate is medium with a nice oily feeling. Good stuff.. and one of the best I have had from these strise guys.

Thanks to someone for sharing this bottle at thirdeye11s recent tasting. Sorry I dont remember who brought it.

The beer pours a medium brown color with a khaki head. The aroma is brown sugar along with caramel malt and dark fruit. The flavor is very fruity: cherries, plums, raisins. There is also some lightly roasted, caramel and toffee malt. Overall the beer is pretty sweet. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Mild light herbal with slightly dusty malts. Hugely light an fruity. My God that is delicious. One of the best beers I have ever drunk; smooth, sweet, light and daring. So much under the initial flush. An absolutely phenomenal ale.
Bottle 330ml from Struise online store "Pannepeut 2007".Dark brown/red color with average head. Aroma caramel, sugar. Taste caramel, fruits, sweet, alcohol.

2007 vintage. First off let me say this is pure belgian yeast driven. While I am not a huge fan of this style of yeast I can appreciate what a well made beer this is. Nose is licorice and spicey yeastyness. In the mouth it is quite full and sticky, with licorice, pit fruit, spice and candi sugar vying for attention. For me this was very good, for some I could see it being life affirming. A crafty Chimay blue??

Bottle - Vintage 2007. Pours a hazy dark brown colour with a thin beige head. Aroma of chocolate, caramel, brown sugar and very ripe fruit. Flavour of chocolate, dark dried fruits, plums, caramel, brown sugar and spice. Nice and creamy with a wonderful sticky mouthfeel. The alcohol is very well hidden and the bitterness is low. It does lack some of the dark and roasted notes that are in pannepot, and although not as complex or rich as the original, this is still a delicious treat.

2007 vintage. Pours a translucent amber/brown with a nice, soft, off-white head that fades slowly, leaving a thin layer over the top. The nose is excellent, complex malt and spice character with plenty of sweet, deep, vinous fruit, spices like cinnamon and ginger, and some chocolate. The mouth is soft and smooth with initial deep fruits and spices, leading to prunes, cherries, some vanilla and a fair bit of sweetness on the swallow along with a bit of mustiness in the background. A little sweet, but not overbearing. It gains a decent light fruit character after I add the yeast sediment from the bottom of the bottle. I first had this one at Struises Old School, and it was a young batch that i found overly sweet. However, it has definitely mellowed out over the months and is much more well balanced. Delicious.

(bottle) pours a slightly hazy dark ruby colour with a quickly diminishing frothy off-white head. aroma of strawberries and sweet spices, caramel, grain and yeast, with some notes of alcohol. flavour is mostly toasted malts and yeast, with notes of bread, herbal hops and spices and a huge caramelly warming finish. very full body, though not sweet, with fizzy carbonation.
Dark red-amber colored beer with a small beige head. Complex aroma and taste. Some caramel, coffee notes and dark fruit. Alcohol warming present.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2010 Edit - Pannepeut 2007, bought from Alvinne. Brewed at Deca by De Struise. Poured into goblet glass. Strong presense of raisins; dried fruits, caramel malt, licorish, brown sugar and roasted malts. A lovely beer. Perfect for a Sunday roast which I will acompany it with. Pallet is smooth and drinkabilitiy is excellent. There is a sense of the alchohol on tongue but the alcohol is quite well hidden for such an epic beer as this. I love these beers and the De Struise brewers are world class masters. Cheers Carlo and Urbain. Dont stop the good stuff. I cant remember if I bought this at Alvinne or De Struise. Oh well. Edit. 14th November. Bags of plum; roasted malts, raisins, black liquorish, vanilla, coffee and a small portion of cream. Bitterness is awesome. Stunning.

Shared this one w/ SkyCop32. Pours a darkish red/brown. Aromas of spice, coriander, yeast, and alcohol. Flavor has an alcohol taste to it, mixed with a nice smokey dark fruit. Also has strong hints of spice and orange.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2010 Bottle at home, poured into a "Gulden draak" glass. Very dark brown-redish. Lighter then pannepot. Nice light beige head, big and holds for a good time. Moderate sweet, spicey a bit fruity aroma. Very nice. Feels pretty good oily in my mouth. Pretty thick substance. Very descent taste Some sweetness, very little bitterness, dark fruit, spices, caramel. Cherrys, malty. A nice complex but balanced brew!

Bottle, 2007. Pours almost black with a respectable white head that stays lacing for long. Lively carbonation in a dense, oily, medium body. Fairly complex aroma with lots of caramel, spices, chocolate, coffee, little bit of liquorice and dried fruits. Starts out sweet, but finishes with a dry, long-lasting hoppy mouthfeel. Alcohol is there, but barely noticeable. Will stay a favorite of mine for a long time to come.

0,33 l bottle from armando.
Appearance: Maroony brown with coppey-orange highlights. Limited yellowish off-white head with thick, creamy quality, and a bit lacing.

Aroma: Mellow dried-strawberries and a few raisins melted in syurpy, liquid, candi-sugary dressing. And spiced with a bit cinammon or vanilla. Almost tannic-like acid bouquet of some purple grapey, tart, estery(?) stuff.

Flavor: A very gentle and balanced composition of dried-berry fruity, yeasty esters, not cloyingly sweet syrupy, caramel-malty background, smooth, but definite dark grape accents. Very smooth and gentle flavor layers. Stays both fruity and spicy at the end.

Mouthfeel/Palate: Very smooth yeast viscousity. Medium body with totally hidden alcohol warmth. Gentle carbonation tickles the tounge.

Overall: Rich, multi-layered half-dark belgian strong ale. Perfect dried-fruity and spicy balance. An art-brewing product!

Sötét vörösessárga színű,amely érdekesen és ködösen gomolyog a poharunkba,aminek az aljára ült üledék darabok folyamatosan apró kis buborékokat eregetnek a felszín felé.A kitöltésnél keletkező hab közepes,sárgás és krémes,gyorsan illan vékony réteget hagyva az ital tetején.Illata olyan mint a fügeborba áztatott mazsolának meg egy kis csokoládé és élesztő.Íze édeskésen,gyümölcs likőrösen kezdődik,égetett cukorral,szárított fügével.Aztán átúszik egy komlós virágos kesernyésségbe,érezni benne egy kis zöld mandulát,barack magot és fűszereket.Elég sűrű és kellemesen élő,csípős apró buborékos.Utóíze keserédes,alkoholos és kicsit szurokfüves,száraz,szépen kitart.Fantasztikus egy sör,ami egy hosszú nap után könnyen mosolyt és nyugalmat varázsolhat megfáradt arcunkra.

0,33 l bottle, bought at Struise School, Oostvleteren, Belgium
Murky, deep brown with a nice creamy beige lacing head. Liqueric and fruity aroma with plum, fig and raisins, tons of caramel and chocolate, some toasted grains, nuts. Wow. Roasted/toasted flavor with a lot of fruits like plum, the raisins again, fig. Mild toffee with a nice liqueric-alcohol taste.  Roasted, fruity aftertaste with a bit of mild hop in the finish. Well balanced one, this is sweeter than the original Pannepot.

Pours a cloudy dark brown with a medium white head. Aroma holds lots of spice, plum, raisin, grape, dough, and a bit of alcohol; slightly lighter than the original version. Flavor holds lots of fruity esters, sweet malt, spice, and bread. Exceptionally drinkable palate. I love de Struise.

Bottle thanks to George. 750ml bottle, never seen a 750ml of this beer before so Im thinking its an older one. Certainly seemed like it had a year or so of age on it (in a good way). Pours a reddish brown with a fat almost tan head. Nose is bready caramel with lots of chewy raisin and prune notes. Flavor follows through with caramel and raisin and adds intense cherry pit and a light alcohol bite. Finishes very smooth. Similar to its cousin but with a slightly fruitier palate in my opinion. Another very good beer from Struise.

Pre KTG tasting with Oteyj and Craftycarl
Murky brown pour with a light offwhite head. 
Aroma is boozey brown sugar, yeasy with dark fruit esters.  
Flavor is moderately sweet and boozey, brown sugar abounds.  Nice presence of fruity esters, some dates, apple.  Great stuff

Dark brown cloudy pour with a lively white froth. The aroma is dark fruit, brown sugar, candi sugar, spice, dough, booze, and biscuit. The flavor is hugely sweet with wonderful dark fruit notes, brown sugar, biscuity dough, and caramel. The perfect proportions of each... The palate is rich thick and silky with pillowy effervescence and and supple finish. Mmmmm.

A decidedly unsettled bottle, 2007 vintage, pours a murky brown with a small and quickly dissipating soapy off white head. Soft and complex aroma is full of sweet fruit snacks, a touch of caramel, a light toastiness, and not too much else. Medium to thin body and lively but soft carbonation. Flavor shows more toastiness, some dark fruits, figs especially, and surprisingly a prominent noble hoppiness on the finish. This beer is really nice and mellow. Would be great for a cold winter night in front of the fireplace.

33cl bottle. Hazy brown to red color with a decent beige head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is malty with nice dry fruit touches. Taste is sweet with malt and caramel with some fruit, hop and a nice dry bitter taste. The body is full and the mouthfeel is soft. A very nice brew!

Pours out a muddy brown with creamy head. Smells sweet fruity yeasty. Taste is more of the same with some grain and spice. Flavors of dark fruits, caramel, toffee, malt, spice and booze. Smooth creamy mouthfeel. Good monk brew.

330ml, 2007 bottle, cloudy dark mahogany hue, with a big fluffy tan-colored head, yeasty, fruity, winey, chocolate praline nose with some toasted, caramelized, chocolate malt, plummy notes, and with some cookie dough, molasses, brown candi sugar accents with a nice spicy nutmeg, coriander aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a nice warmth, yeasty, fruity, chocolatey, fruitcake character, with some dark dried sultana raisin, date, fig and plum accents, with a faint molasses, burnt brown sugar, chocolatechip cookie dough flovours, with a mild liqueurish port-like note, leading towards a warming, chocolatey, plummy, raisiny, lingering sweet molasses, roasty bitterness finish.

Ive tried this in Pannepeut guise (cream label) and the Danish label version with the Ø. These are two very different beers. 
Danish version  courtesy of glouglouburp . This is no where near at the level of normal Pannepot. It loses the spiceness, richness, and depth that makes Pannepot a top beer in the world. This is more simple with too much brown sugar, peat, and tannins. More like Chimay Blue, which is relatively lackluster. 3.3
Belgium cream label version as Pannepeut  courtesy of Travlr . This has a boozy, spiced rum nose. Taste is raw cane juice, some raw earth, graininess, oatmeal. More like a very good Vienna or Doppelbock.  3.7

Bottle. Pours a murkey brown. Small espresso coloured head. Falls away pretty quickly leaving minimal lacing. Aromas of sweetish malt, toffee, spices and dark fruits. Aromas are quite sweet. Flavours show toffee, roasted malt and some spices. Finish is quite sweet with some bitterness. Some alcohol shows through also. Minimal carbonation. Mouthfeel is spot on. Great beer
Only slight remark I want to make thats it a tad, just a tad, too sweet. Otherwise its great.

Bottled 2007, Darker brown coloured beer with some light carbonation and a small brown head. Full roasted malty aroma with a full creamy palat. Finish is bitter roasted, with some creamy light alcholic touches. Special and strong

Bottle is Pannepeut, 2007 - PNP No.5, Old Monks Ale.  Pours a dark red brown color with a beige head with very small bubbles.  Aroma of roasted malts, caramels, some dark fruits like raisins, brown sugars and spices.  Flavors is complex and wonderfull, roasted malts, dry fruits, yeasts, caramels, liquorice, a hint of chocolate and spices.  Low carbonation, a little sweet and more bitter dry, full of strong flavors long lasting in mouth.
This is very close to some Trappist brew.  Very big beer and very enjoyable.

11.2oz bottle: Appearance is a very dark brown with a small almost tan head, Aroma of spices, raisins, candi sugar and caramel, Flavor again is a mixture of raisins, candi sugar and caramel, the spices are a little bit more hidden. It has been awhile since I have had the original Pannepot but I can say this one is not quite as good but none the less still a great beer.

Bottle, 33 cl. Dark brown beer with medium beige head. Aroma of caramel, chocolate, dried fruits and cane sugar, light sweet. Taste is at first coffee, caramel and chocolate, later on the spices, dried fruits and cane sugar come to the foreground, giving it a light sweet taste. Full body, but not a strong as the original Pannepot. Also a bit less in taste, but still a very great beer!

Pours hazy amber with a small head that quickly dissipates. The aroma is slightly faint, but is still quite complex. There is a malty base, with hints of raisins, honey and caramel. The flavor is just incredible. Extremely well balanced it starts off malty, with a sweet caramel taste, then slowly moves to a hoppy bitterness that lingers on in an extremely pleasant long finish. There is not much carbonation present, but that just does not matter at all with this beer. Just fantastic.
This beer is really one of the best I have ever tasted. You find everything in this beer.

( 330ml 2006 bottle) Pours murky brown with nice light tan head that goes away. Nose is raisins, alcohol, caramel and plums. Taste is raisins, dried figs, alcohol and spices. This beer is really nice and sweet. Lingers deliciously of more raisins, with nice carbonation. Quite mellow and the age has done this some big favors. No hint of alcohol whatsoever.
15th June 2008. Dark brown cloudy beer. A hybrid of pronounced bubblegum sweetness offset by a rich creamy malt with a hint of chocolate. Dry bubblegummy finish. Unusual.

Murky brown with a small beige head. Aroma is packed with fruity esters, caramell and chocolate. Flavour is similar with a extremely smooth mouthfeel and a close to alcoholfree finish. Nicely balanced.

11.2 fl oz bottle from Bieropholie, labelled as Pannepeut, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. 2007 edition. GUSHED  lost almost half the bottle.
App.:  Very deep reddish-brown with a large orange-tan head.
  
Aroma:  Quite tangy, vinous and fruity, lots of sour cherries and other fruits, plenty of brown sugar, deep malts, molasses, also plenty of organic acids, a touch of wood and vanilla, dark dried fruits, orange peel/citrus, some yeast notes, quite sweet.
  
Palate:  Medium+body, moderate effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Lots of orange peel and tangy fruit, plenty of brown sugar and molasses, sour cherries, organic acids, lighter woodiness, a touch of vanilla, warm spices; quite sweet with some alcohol and a lingering aftertaste of orange-flavoured dark chocolate.

I dont like it as much as the original, but still a great beer.

Bottle. Sweet aroma of portwine, figs, raisins and spices. Deep clear redbrown colour with huge light brown head. Sweet spicy flavour of malt, ripe fruits, caramel and luquorice.It contains some of the sweet secrets of life as apparently the monks were well aware of.

The label on my bottle has the Ø with the slash through it, so Im rating accordingly.  (The labels on this site are very ambiguous.  My bottle says 2006 while the label for the non-slashed-Ø has 2006 on the item picture for that version of this beer.)  Delicious stuff, definitely thick on the brown-sugary, figgy aspects.  I actually dont pick up a whole lot else though.  Just a very pleasing flavor.  Little bit of grassiness, just a touch, there on the finish.

Bottled 2007. The structure of the aroma reminds of excellent wine or champagne. Dark cherry fruitiness with notes of herbs and bitter chocolate underneath. Very malty and complex. Pours dark brown with a small, off-white rim. The flavour is again sweet malty, the spicing is very evident, resulting in a cuvée of flowery and herbal flavours. There are slightly smokey and roasty components, but a fine caramel maltiness is the most prominent. Lovely bittersweet finish. Mouthfilling, with a bit too much residual sweetness for my liking - otherwise a damn good beer.
2006 bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  Chocolate with a cream head.  Nose is yeast, spices and light chocolate.  Nice on the palate with a smooth flavor of spices and dried fruits.

Bottle 2006. Pours very dark brown with thick beige head the eventually fades. Nose is dark red fruit, very strong, some belgian yeast notes and alcohol. Flavors follow with a good emphasis on raisins, plums and caramel. Very strong flavor, not bad at all.

Cuvée 2007. Bouteille de 330 ml dégustée au Cheval Blanc (Montréal, QC). Apparence: La couleur est brune opaque. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de petits fruits foncés et dépices avec une pointe chocolatée. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement vineuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement fruité. (Rating #2596)

Bottle. Frothy off-white good mostly deminishing head. Dark red-amber colour. Powerfull fruity aroma. Prune notes. Powerfull fruity flavor. Rasin and prune notes. A little alcoholic. Oily palate. Long cloying finish. A big disapointment.
dark brown black coloured body with a off white head a malty spicy fruity aroma a little roasted malty spicy sweet fruity taste with a malty sweet alcholic bitter finish

33cl bottle. Pours a cloudy ruby-brown colour with a large cremy light-brown head. Good lacing and mostly lasting foam. Aroma is quite complex: lots of malt with bread, cookies, cereals. toasted malt and nuts, some wood and alcohol too. Hints of spices. Flavor is very good, also if less complex than his sister Pannepot: bitterness at the beginning with some sweetness and tartness; long finish with little sweetness and a prevailing sensation of acidity and botterness. Medium-full bodied with creamy texture. Fizzy carbonation. Soft alcoholic aftertaste. Great beer, even if less complex than his sisters Pannepot and Pannepot Grand Reserva. Aniway it makes it more refreshing and esier to drink.
Black brown coloured beer with small off-white head and medium carbonation. Malty spicy aroma. Full sweet sparkling palate. Finish is malty roasted bitter dry. Nice one.

2006 bottle at Sorbon, Bromma.

Pours redbrown with a small yellowish head.

Licorice, sweet malt and dark fruits. 
Very complex.
Bottle. Ap: Red-brown golden head. Ar: Fruity sweetness, spices, chocolate, licorice. Fla: Chocolate, fruit, licorice in the end. Ov: Quite lot of carbonation. Medium bodied.

2006 Vintage
12/04/2008:  Pannepøt looks thick and creamy on the pour.  It is dark mahogany in color with a beige-tan head.  The aroma is sweet and spicy and contains caramel, a tringe of alcohol, and port-like characteristics.  This beer also tastes sweet and malty and has additional flavors included such as chocolate, chickory, earthy and herbal hops (mild), vanilla, and a dry finish.  The flavors stays with you long after swallowing.  The beer has a medium-full body and feels soft and creamy in the mouth.  It is quite delicious and warming.
11.2 fl. oz. bottle (10% alc./vol.).  Rating #468 for this beer.

(2006 Vintage)  Thin head with light carbonation.  I expected more carbonation from this brew.  A bit on the flat side.  Rich aroma with lots of spices, sweet malts, caramel and some ripe dark plums.  Color is a cloudy dark mahagony red.  Very soft and velvety palate.  Chewy malts, caramel, raisins, more spice and some yeast.  Lots and lors of malts.  I had the other Pannepot earlier today and a must say that I like that one much better. More complex and less overwealmed by malts.  Noticable alcohol presence but does not seem hot at all.  Finishes creamy and smooth and malty.  A very tasty malt bomb.  Pretty good but not as good as the other Pannepot.

33cl bottle at home. 2007 in a white box on the label.
dark brown, large smooth creamy thick light brown head. supersmooth. 4+
mild aroma of raisins, sweet malts, dark fruits, candi sugar.
flavor is sweet, spicy, raisins, dark fruits, good alc. punch , throat burning, faint sweet malts. you can´t really taste the alc, only feel it. this one you cant drink quick, its a sip by sip experience. very nice belgian.

A faint, chocolaty aroma of belgian yeast and spices. Taste is complex, sweet and vinous, and contains spices, dried fruit and yeast. Palate is fizzy and oily to some extent. The finish is a bit acidic and dry and the alcohol comes through a little bit. A good brew in its complexity and well-balanced sourness, but it is a little bit overwhelming in its spiciness. Aging maybe?

Original review date 5/6/2008...2006 vintage for the Danes into Cab glass

Beautiful dark chestnut body with ample carbonation. Chewy, maple walnut ice cream-colored head dissipates quickly and exhibits sufficient lacing.

Mildly soapy hop presence - brown sugar cinnamon with ginger and sarsparilla - a little tin presence when cold.

Creamy - almost like ice cream with strong spice profile of cinnamon, ginger root, sarsparilla in the chewy braised-like malt. Tough to shake the tinniness but after a while warming it starts to dissipate. Slight smoke and wood chips emerge with warmth.

Extremely hearty and chewy mouthfeel...like a warm caramel apple sundae. Tight grip, almost tangy.

Overall very enjoyable parts of the offering but they arent necessarily synced up with each other as well as would be desired; strong effort nonetheless.

33cl Bottle from De Bierkoning, vintage 2007. Deep dark brown colour, initially big light beige head. Aroma is very malty, dark fruits, some marzipan and cherries. Flavour is sweet, malty, raisins, liquorice, a hint of spices. Fullbodied, smooth and creamy mouthfeel. Even better than Pannepot imho, reminded me a lot of St. Bernardus Abt. Good, very good.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2011 (bottle, 6.12.2009) a beautiful mahogany hue and decent head.  The intro is quite spicy, but it tails off pretty quickly.  Taste of dried raisins/dark cherry.

(330ml bottle, 2007 vintage).  Pours a cloudy mahogany color with thin tan head.  Some floaties.  Aroma has rich caramel, port, raisins. Wow!  Just incredible.  Smells every bit as good as an aged rochefort 10.  Taste is similar to the aroma.  Lots of caramel and dried dark fruits. Full bodied with a sticky texture.  Smooth finish with warming alcohol, but not in the taste.  This beer, or my tastes, have changed quite a bit in the last couple of years because I find this beer to be quite remarkable compared to my first try.

The bottle looks really good, the beer in the glass also. Starts strong-malty, not roasty, notes of liquorice and marzipan. A bit spicy finish, well balanced and warming. Really good beer! Thanks to Bierkoning for the bottle!

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2010 Pours black brown with an dissapearing tan head.  Aroma is dark and  spicy, yeast and some alcohol.  Taste is sweet, spicy, cinamon, cumin, dark fruits and roasted malt.  Finishes moderately alcoholic.  Tried this before trying the Pannepot the day after, and this seems slightly inferior, but an excellent beer nonetheless.

2006 Bottle pours dark brown with off white head.  Aroma is dark fruit and sweet caramel.  Has a lot of carbonation.  Flavor follows the nose.  Finishes a bit sweet.  My least favorite in the pannepot line.  Still a nice beer though.

Bottle from Brad, thanks my friend!! Cloudy mahogany pour wtih a very small head that disappears quickly.  Aroma is yeast, raisins, booze, fruit, and caramel.  Flavor is fruity, yeasty, a tad tart, caramel,. and a bit of delicious booze.  Damn good.  2006.

Bottle. Pours a glossy red cider brown, with a small beige head. Nose is fruity, grape juice, faintly bready. Flavors are dry grape juice, dry red wine,  moist whole grain oat bread. Reminds me a bit of the wine from church as a teen. Very carbonated but not overly. This is an excellent beer. I cannot wait to try the Pannepot!!

Bottle.  Very dark brown and red with a large beige foam.  Aromas are bready yeast and raisins with chocolate and vinous notes.  Soft spices.  Flavours are sweet malts with yeast and peppery spices.  Raisins and berry fruit with a boozy, dry finish.  Very nice.

Vintage 2006 from bistro lAutre oeil. Dark brown with a thin beige head with good retention. Aroma is dark fruits, red fruits, grapes, raisins, ueas, malt and sugar. Flavour is similar to the aroma with more raisins, caramel and molasses. Full body. A very good belgian strong ale.

2006 Vintage.  11.2 oz. bottle courtesy of a trade with GAManiac. Pours a dark brown that only allows a few glimmers of light to pass through with a moderate off-white head that lasted until mid-glass and left partial lace.  Very pleasant aroma of malt, raisins, prunes, molasses, and caramel and a bit of alcohol.  The flavor is similar to the aroma with malt, raisins, prunes, molasses, and caramel along with just a hint of brown sugar.  Smooth and silky on the palate while at the same time lightly effervescent with ever-so-tiny bubbles that creates a liveliness that I am enjoying very much.  This is a very enjoyable beer that I like just a touch better than Pannepot.
I liked this better than the other Pannepot.  A nice tasty spiciness up front blends into some delicious maltiness.

2006. 11.2 oz. Dark red-brown pour with a thick tan head. Lot of carbonation at the opening. Little floaties. Sweet malt aroma with hints of dark fruits, brown sugar,  and spice. Has the taste of the fruits in the aroma followed by some dryness, like a sherry. Head clings to the glass. Very tasty.

11.2oz bottle. Pours a murky, deep brown-garnet colored body with bits of particulate floating around. Finger-width, dirty tan, soapy head that leaves a swirling surface of foam and a soapy lacing. Has a very atmospheric-like aroma to it. Light Belgian spicing and booze mixed with some brown sugar, fruit cake, and caramels. Flavor is a little more rich than the aroma hints at. Moderate malty sweetness and a good amount of Belgian spicing and yeasts. Moderate caramels and toffees along with some more of that fruit cake flavor initially. Mostly dark fruits such as prunes and dates. The mild spicing comes in during the middle and becomes more noticeable in the finish. The finish is where the complexity of this becomes evident. Brown sugar, toasted toffee, and a hint of dark chocolate accompany the spices and dry, malty finish. Nice lingering spicy malt taste. Palate is medium bodied and hides the 10% very well. The booze just barely comes through in the finish and comparably lighter than the aroma. Overall, a nice tasting beer that grew on me more and more. Not as exceptional as some people have scored this, but a nice beer nonetheless.

11.2 oz bottle Pours a dark murky brownish copper red with a thick pillowy off white dark head. A nice soft dark fruit nose with plenty of spices. Interestingly slightly tart and deeply malty with a rich balanced character. Flavor has a big fruit flavor, just a boatload of dark fruit, raisins, prunes, plum, nuts, Belgian yeast, and a slight red wine like character, as I noticed 17thfloor said, some metallic notes that dissipate after some airing out. Medium to full body and a perfect carbonation. Excellent beer all around.

Raisins dark fruti, spices, alcohol.. The spice blend doesnt seem as good as in the regular one, the taste is not nearly as complex. This is more like an amped up bruin or something, simple and it works but not even close to the original. It doesnt even look pretty, the head is weaker and the color is muddy.
Bottle @ Skortila. Dark brown colour, beige head. Aroma of sour fruits and chocolate malts. Flavour of cherry, raisins and plums. Chocolate malts and brown sugar.

This dark brown ale poured with a nice tan head, eliciting a malty aroma. The flavor is marvelously complex with a predominance of chocolate malt, but otherwise quite balanced. The alcohol is well-masked, and the flavor just keeps getting better as the glass empties.

330ml bottle, vintage 2006, bought at Ølbutikken in Copenhagen, May 08. Huge, off-white head with gushing foam. Hazy, mahogany body with a dark, reddish tint. Spotty lacings on the glass. Sweet, malt-fruity aroma added by a spicy touch. Rather comprehensive taste with a bit of everything. Sweet, succulent prunes up front supported by apricots, anise, late fruits and spices. Some bitter yeast and alcohol in the aftertaste as a counterpoint to all the sweet ingredients. Velvet texture. Medium bodied. Flavourful beer without being top-notch  (celebrating VIF-TIL 2-4 at home in Tromsø, 06.04.2009).
Poured brown with a white head. Aroma of fruit and spice. A little different compared to the other. Not as much fruit flavor in this. Spice in the finish. Still good.
Bottle: Cloudy brown with much of the same characteristics as the  American version.  This one seemed to have a thinner feel and a bit more tangy.  Not bad.

Bottle vintage 2006 Pours out a dark brown topped with a small sand head. Aroma was of sweetness, lots of chcolate and spice.  Also picked up some of the belg yeast and caramel. Tast was nice more of the sweet chocolate and spice. Plenty of the pit fruit tast. Very nice. But I think I like the Pannepot a little more.

2006 Bottle from mashmaster.  Aroma has notes of yeast, toffee, red vino, sherry, and syrup.  Very dark brown hue with a small off-white head that left no lace.  Flavor is extremely sweet and cloying.  Palate is very full bodied and syrupy soft.  Unbelievably thick and quite cloying.  Decent flavor but too cloying and syrupy.

0.33 l bottle, thanks Hannu N! Hazy dark brown color with big beige head. Sweet, toffeish, caramelly, nutty and vinous aroma with vanilla, gooseberry, sherry and perfumed alcohol. Sweet raisiny, nutty, vinous, toffeish and caramelly flavor with chocolate, some yeastiness and hint of sharp alcohol. Nice dessert, this could be  called  Belgian barley wine if such style existed.

Bottled 33cl. Courtesy of bierkoning. Aroma: Quite a lot of coconut. Flavor and palate: Spicy with coconut, maple syrup and caramel showing up. Hints of marmite. Very pleasant. Thanks a lot bierkoning.

33cL Bottle at Monks Cafe. Noses with some insane molasses-dense caramels and lots of well-caramelized kettle sugars. This really pushes through with some astounding brown character. Layered on top is a delicate spicy yeast note that puts out some pear brandy, plum sauce, and light pineapple on top. Amazing and enticing. Pours in an eclectic paler teak and sienna, with a range of colors, and a silky lacing in tan. Flavor is just as flavor-powerful and rich as the nose, but in different ways. It throws off browned sugars, graced lightly with molasses, in a whole bevy of baked goods, from oatmeal cookies to brownies. Theres a really depth and richness to the malt and sugar profile of this beer. Alcohol deftly concealed, but adding. This is a little sweeter than I expected, but the bright, yellow-colored fruit flavor that sits on top of the malt, adding complexity in banana, passionfruit, and coconut makes this delightful and rounded on so many levels. A truly expressive and delightful Belgian.
bottle,  dark brown color with solid tan bubbly foam, aromas of old cherry, white raisin, brown sugar, flavors of sour cherry, spiced cider, molasses, finish is light to medium

2006 Bottle.  Pours a ruddy brown with a very thin light tan ring of carbonation.  Big prune aroma, some caramel and lightly spices.  Taste is a honey like sweetness, more prunes, grapes, cherries, fruity maltiness.  Smooth creamy body and a nice alcohol and spice finish.
Honey in there.  Hides the alcohol well.  Fruity.  Dark amber in color.  Good beige head.  Fruits, dark fruits in the taste.  Some caramel. Apricots, pears.  Smooth mouthful.  Good beer.

ZBF 2007 
Fruchtige Geruchsnoten verbinden sich hier mit malzigen. Sehr komplexer Antrunk, anfangs fruchtig, dann eher ins (tief) malzige gehend halten sich diese beiden Aromen in Balance. Dabei istdas ganze leicht süß Gehalten, was wirklich im perfektem Einklang geschieht. In diesem Verältnis geht es weiter, alle Aromen werden, im richtigen Verhältniss zueinander, stärker, wobei das Malz nach und nach die Überhand gewinnt, es wird überaus würzig. Dies ist ein fast perfektes Bier!

2006 33cl.  Very murky amber with a thin off-white head.  Malty, dark sugar, bread, slightly wood/paper, and spicy.  Sweet malt, a little banana, with alcohol presence throughout.  Not as complex as I might have hoped.  Decent bitter finish.  Had dinner not long before I tried this, which took a little from my appreciation.

33cl bottle, dated 2006, with thanks to ygtbsm94 for the excellent bonus.  Pours a hazy brown/amber with a one finger tan head that sticks around forever, with good lacing as well.  Aroma is candied dark fruits, spices, and some bready yeast.  Flavor is more dark fruits, yeast, and light spice, with a sweeter finish.  Palate is creamy and full with a lasting finish.  While not quite to the level of the "regular" Pannepot, its another good one from Struise for sure, thanks again Brad!

11.2 oz bottle.  A pleasant, mellow, airy aroma with a little bit of an alcoholic twinge to it,  a variety of medium sweetness fruits, brown sugar, toffee, cake mix, and some other subtle spices.  Huge and thick sandy cream head on the pour that didnt stick as nicely as i wouldve liked, very hazy with a good amount of particulate, bloody auburn in color.  Flavor profile is fairly complex with notes of a good variety of spices and sweetness.  Minor bit of alcohol comes through a little as well.  Strawberry-banana cream right at the start, caramel-toffee hard candy, some toasted marshmallow, and a dry spicy brown sugar malt finish.  A very nice drink that is not too far off from being truly excellent.

Bottle shared by cschwaz. thanks Craig. The aroma is very vinous, lots of dark fruit, kind of wine like to me. Brown beer with a thin foamy ring. Sweet dark bread, dark malts, vinous fruit, toast. Drinks very smoothly with medium carbonation and a slight warming effect in the finish.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2009 Bottle. Hazy dark brown body, with a medium tan head. Aroma is malt, lots of spices and alcohol. Flavor is sweet fruit, again lots of spices, syrup and a warming finish from the alcohol. A really good beer.

07 bottle from 515 in Santa Cruz. Poured into a goblet. Dark opaque russet with a slight reddish tinge. Creamy beige head leaves some lacing. Aromas of black cherry yogurt, a dusting of coriander, brown sugar, and caramel. Flavors of dark toasty caramel, maple syrup, brown sugar, nutmeg, cherries, berries, and coriander. Nice complexity and insane smoothness. No trace of alcohol. Body is a couple notches thicker than medium. Well-attenuated and so easy to drink. Great beer.
Bottle, pours dark brown with a tan head.  Aromas of carmel and dark malt.  Lighter body with lots of spice and fig.  Has a dark fruity finish.  Great beer.

bottle.  The map Room in Chicago.  Deep hazy dark deep chestnut with a large caramel colored head that fades to leave a good centimeter covering that lasts. Aroma is sweet and crammed with dried fruits, taste is sweet.

Bottle at the KW tasting, thanks to Jan Primus.Hazy dark brown, small hazy brown head.  Sweet aroma, spicy.  Very sweet and spicy taste. Surprisingly very easy top drink.  Not near the complexity of the 05 we had, but still a damn fine beer.

11.2 oz. bottle.  Poured deep brown with next to no head.  Strong nose with tons of dark fruits present.  Slightly lacking carbonation.  Sweet sugary, caramel flavor with more dark fruit:  raisins, plums, and prunes.  Finishes spicy and a bit smokey.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Not as good as the other Pannepot.

Bottled. An unclear brown beer with a thin tan head. The aroma is sweet malty with strong notes of brown sugar and spices as well as notes of alcohol. The flavor is very sweet with strong notes of brown sugar, alcohol, spices - especially coriander and thyme, leading to a dry spicy finish finish.

bottles shared at tupalevs KW group tasting. pours dark ruby with a small off white head. nice malt forward nose, fruity and boozy. probably something i would have enjoyed more futher into the tasting. the flavour was well balanced with a nice spiciness, yeast, dark malty fruit. very drinkable despite the 10% abv. a nice brew overall and one id like to revisit.

2006 bottle at Tupalevs hosted KW tasting. Thanks to whoever brought this. Much paler than the 05 GR Ive had, but more or less the same aroma of bizarrness. Flavour is lighter than the 05, very fruity, peachy, tart and with a finishing lemony zing. Quite a nice little beer but for me it suffers just like its darker, older brother from the fact that it just isnt really my sort of thing. Still a good one, surisingly drinkable and Im glad to have tried it.

Vintage 2006

Pours garnet brown with amber edging, and a chill haze with fine particulates in suspension.
A solid two inch head of dense, beige foam reluctantly settled to a thick skim coat and plenty of whipped lacework.

Aromatics lead off with spice-dusted raisins, dark rum, and chocolate-drizzled grape jam.
Hints of coriander, nutmeg, white pepper, cloves, and anise. Some brown sugar steps forward as well as a trace of bannana.
Finishes with a mild vineous note.

Medium bodied, with a creamy mouthfeel and tacky. Lightly chewy and sticky.

Grape jam, ripe fruit, rich malt, and spiced rum start the pallet. A warming boozy note quickly steps forward and warms throughout.
Tangerines, grape bubblegum, sugar-crusted cloves, plump raisins, and doughy malt follow through.

Finishes with a lingering warmth, tacky sugars, and fading spice.

I think this one could improve even more with a couple more years in the cellar, minimum. 

Very much looking forward to the new version, which will be unspiced, and as I recall, a bit drier.

[1769-20081011] 11.2floz bottle. Brown banana and vanilla ice cream aroma with malty caramel, some wood and some sweet yeast. Murky, dark red brown body with a long-lasting creamy light tan head. Wood caramel flavour has sweet toasted yeast and is boozy but not overwhelming. Full body is sweet and boozy. Smooth and big. (Vintage 2006; w/ jerc)

malty aroma with subtle tart sour notes and herbs.  poured a deep brown color with a decent white head and thin lacing.  complex flavor a hint of chcocolate followed by sour cherries and dried fruits and loads of maltiness.  the mouthfeel is medium to heavywith tons of CO2 action.  the finish lingers with roasted flavor and mild hoppiness.

Deep hazy dark deep chestnut with a large caramel coloured head that fades to leave a good centimetre covering that lasts. Aroma is sweet and crammed with dried friuts, taste is sweet with a deffinate liquorice hit.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2010 In short: A inferior version of the regular Pannepot.  Less cohesive.  Feels sweeter.
How: Bottle 330ml.  Vintage 2006.  Consumed when over 1 year of age.  Side by side with regular Pannepot (same vintage).  Bottle given to me by Drewbeerme, thanks a lot Andrew.
The look: Many small particles in a cloudy brown body topped by a small beige head
In long: Rather than describe it the beer Ill compare it to the regular Pannepot that we all know and love (both were vintage 2006).  The Pannepøt has a much stronger liquorice candy and barley candy flavour.  The fruity notes of the regular Pannepot are more like sweet fruits concentrate in the Pannepøt.  Feels a lot more sweet than the regular Pannepot.  Similar spicy nature, similar earthy note but the nice floral character of the regular Pannepot feel turns into something that taste like sucking on tulip petals in the Pannepøt.  Put another label on it and I wouldnt complain but I was rather disappointed by the Pannepøt it is a pretty nice beer but it is a far cry from the regular Pannepot.  Commercial description above says "is produced to express the brewers gratitude to all the Danish beer amateurs".  No surprise it made its way to North-America, they must have sold like 4 bottles total of this beer to the 40 Danish ratebeerians.

Reviewed 12/24/2008 (bottle):

Pours a clearish reddish brown color body. Suspended particles. Small off-white head. Dark fruity aroma, spices. A nice Belgian aroma. Somewhat musty, maybe coriander or something. Sweet spices, very aromatic. Dark fruity taste, plum and dark grape. Soft mouthfeel. Some smokiness present too. Very tasty, not too overwhelming.

Pours dark brown with copper hues and thin tan head. The aroma is fruity with prunes, dates, dark grapes, ripe cherries, dark German bread, a bit of molasses and alcohol. The taste begins both mildly malty and fruity with prunes and plums before a bit of fruit tartness and mild yeasty spice pick up midway and to the finish.

Thanks JoeMcphee for the bottle. Strong aroma of liquorice, spices and syrup. Dark amber colour, hazy appearance with a brown brown bread head. Rich flavour of roasted malt, liquorice, syrup and spices. The beer is delicious. a little earthy with hints of vegetables, rather odd but still good all the same. Rich smooth finish. A very interesting and delicious ale.

courtesy of retorp.
2006 bottle.
Thanks for opening up this amazing brew.
Pours hazy brown with frothy brown head.
Aroma is fruity -  dark cherries and plums with caramel malts.
Taste cherry like  giving the beer a very smooth wine like touch. Sugary - candi like mouthfeel.

Gets better with a few sips, complex and interesting.

I like this brew but its not as full bodied as the Belgian version. A little lighter but the great flavors are still here. Had this one side by side with the Belgian version and there is a difference. The awesome earthy flavors are here along with the spice and fruity flavors the yeast pulls out of the grain. A great brew and worthy of  its time on the table.

Dark brown brew with beautiful longlasting beige head. Aroma is very complex and is very Rochfort 10 like. Caramel, malts, nuts, candi and some coffee are the major aromas. the taste is like bread, peanutspread, caramel lots of rich malts and some well hidden body heating alcohol. In some way this beer reminds me to Westy 12. Great beer but I like the original better.

2006. Nice dark brown pour with some off-white lacing from the thin head. Aroma is quite mild, raisin, nuts, syrup, tobacco. The flavor is excellent. The flavor begins with dark fruits, plums and raisins, along with some very mild licorice. This is complimented by a vanilla character that ties everything together very nicely. About midway through, an awesome maple candy quality comes into the picture and makes for a very long, very sweet finish. The mouthfeel is like velvet. Very good beer.
great belgain strong dark ale...super great dried fruit nose and great complex malty and fruity goodness....one of my favorite belgian dark ales

20081130  11.2oz bottle and I forget where I got it but it wasn’t local.  Maybe Capone’s.  Nearly opaque dark maple syrup color with medium, lasting, even head of uniformly sized medium foam.  Aroma is rich, spicy (savory), and seasonal with notes of nuts, roasted squash, plump raisin, vanilla, and rum.  With the chill and onset of winter, this beer is a fine choice on a dreary day.  Flavor is an interesting amalgam of standard Belgie strong ale flavors but also some sweet American influence, with temp perhaps a touch too sweet, and a long savory finish again reminding of caramelized roasted foods.  Medium-full palate is fully appropriate and strong alcohol is mostly unnoticed except for the nice buzz.  Good beer.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2009 2006 vintage. Another Struise gusher. Usual tactic of easing the cap off and standing it in a Hoey glass to catch the lava flow of suds. Pours mahogany with a blossoming yellow-beige head; unearthly foam sculptures collapsing to a slick in minutes, in a variety of glasses. Aroma up-the-nose liquorice stick, cinder toffee, yeast extract, sweet (straw)berryish fruits, plum. Mouth creamy, sticky, slightly burnt once its really been standing a whilebrazen liquorice, candi sugar, faint cocoa. Not really getting any obvious spicing. Bit of vanilla, stone fruit, prune in the aftertaste. Roasted malt traces, maybe. Alcohol nicely buried by sugar and liquorice. Sweetish and unsubtle, touch of peaty malt. Pretty standard, liquorice-driven Dubbel-like flavours turned up a notch. Missing the bite of hops or yeast, but hugely drinkable. Nice beer. 747315 
(Re-rate). 2006 again, to take the taste of a Leroy Stout away. Robustly malt-accented aroma evoking Germany more than Belgium with noseful of sticky raisin, demerara, licorice and malt loaf. Warm of booze humming softly with fruit loaf and muscovado; liquorice detectable but alcohol (flavours) not. Wholesome malty sipper mellowing with age into a murderously sessionable hybrid of dubbel and doppelbock. At 10%. The devils.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2013 Bottle. Hazy dark brown beer with a nice beige head. Malty creamy aroma, raisins, dades, biscuits, yeasty ,spicy, citrus, pears, chocolate and plum, milky, tobacco, smoked notes, licorice, chocolate. Fruity spicy flavor, creamy, yeast, prunes, dades, plums, caramel, chocolate, vinous notes, woody, tobacco, smoked notes, vanilla, clove, banana notes, warming alcohol. Full bodied and with a great complex finish.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2009 Bottle from Hopduvel. Pours dark brown and thick as oil with a small brown head. Kandi sugar nose makes me anticipate a first sip eagerly. Aromas are woods, earthy, oily, dark fruits, sweet and roasted licorice. Very complex but very good. Alcohol warming lingers for a while. To be drunk slowly.

Bottle. Deep sweetness. Caramel and toffee with fig notes, pears, and light chocolate. Some alcohol presence. Cloudy mahogany with a patchy off-white head that leaves spotty lacing. Piercing sweetness with good balance. Nice caramel finish, a bit of alcohol and dark fruits. Thin but silky palate. Alcohol shows up more with warmth.

11.2oz bottle. Poured a very dark brown with a nice light tan head. Yeasty aroma, slightly sour smelling. Mmmm that is good. Alot of dark frutiness in there, a little alcohol in the finish. Very warm and very good, especially on an overcast gloomy day.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text:
Bottle 33cl.
Pours a clear brown/copper colour with a normal size head and low carbonation.
Smell is spicy, fruity, fresh and also has some traces of malts there.
Also vaguely some coffee and caramel.
Taste is of burnt malts, chocolate, caramel and coffe.
Perfectly balanced and a great strong ale.
bottle from hop duvel, ghent. red dark heavy beer, complex palate. good nose

2006 vintage
Pours dark brown with ruby edges. One finger tan head leaves a thin collar with little lacing. Raisin, fig, anise, and tobacco on the nose, with other scents that are hard to pinpoint. Flavor is a bit fruitier, but is nicely balanced with the spice and earth notes. Big bubbled carbonation leaves the finish a bit too dry, but it is quite drinkable.

A red dark amber to brown ale with a thick light moka head. A nice licorice malt with light fruity esters, alcohol warmth. In mouth, licorice predominates with light white sugar, plums and dark fruits, a bit lighter than expected but overall, a nice experience. Enjoyed in bottle at Kulminator, Nov. 2006, with Joris and Carlo.
Pours dark brown with thin beige head.  Aroma of dark fruits.  Taste of raisins, figs, and plums.  Nice caramel sweetness as well.  Smooth mouthfeel.  Good beer.

I asked for this beer at Bier Circus in Brussels, and the bartender told me that they didn’t stock it because the brewers were not real brewers or words to that effect.  However, I found the beer at Beer Mania, and real brewers or not, I found both this at the Old Fisherman’s Ale to be quite good beers.

Poured a dark brown after exploding out of the bottle onto the counter and floor.  Minimal head despite the overcarbonation.  Aroma was complex - malty, sweet, with dried fruit notes and lots of slightly roasty maltiness accented by cherry notes.  Full mouthfeel hit me first - you pucker a bit like a red wine full of tannins - the flavor is some coffee and dried fruit.  I thought it tasted a bit like apricots and dried cherries.  Delicious.

I would highly recommend this beer.

11.2 oz. bottle.  Pours a dark caramel to brown color with a medium lasting beige head.  The aroma is caramel malt, fruity like you find in many Belgians, spices, moderate sweetness, alcohol and a hint of banana.  The flavor is more sweet dark malts up front.  Caramel, dark fruits (raisin, cherries), spices and alcohol.  I think the alcohol is more noticable than the regular version.  The balance and complexity don’t seem to be on the same level as the regular version either.  This is a solid beer, but I prefer the regular better..

2008-10-??. Hazy veryd ark brown body with a good sized tan head. Sweet alcoholic aroma, sugars, dark fruit. (7+) Sweet flavour, dark sugars again, lightly scorched caramel. Lightly tangy fruit notes towards the finish, very light alcohol presence is quite restrained. (8+) Smooth medium bodied palate. (4+) Really quite good. More please! 2006 Vintage Bottle from Premier Gourmet, Buffalo

2006. Deep, dark purple body with a rich, well lacing off-white head. Plum, chocolate, rum, oak, and much more in the nose. Heavy phenols with loads of dark fruits. The taste is very potent, with lots of molasses, plums, dates, raisins, honey, spice, and tons more. A really great brew, and Im sure would cellar nicely.

Bottle as an extra from Emacgee.  Deep lightly hazy amber in color with a medium to large light tan head.  Aroma of raisins, somewhat earthy, caramel, spice and yeast.  Taste is caramelized malts, raisins and figs, musty and spicy yeast, earthy .  Full bodied, finishes on the sweeter side with lingerng fruit and spices.  Although I liked the original more, this was still a very nice beer.  Thanks Ethan!

Sampled at EBF08.
Hazy brown. No head.
Soft and smooth.
Some dark sugar and nutty hoppiness.
A bit fruity and sourish.

33 cl bottle - 2005 vintage; pours glowing , orange-brown with tan head; not as dark as the GR; drinks smooth with a slight tartness; lots of belgain candy; crisp and of course on that struise sweet side; not nearly as good as the regular version; flavors of spice and dank fruit are on the mild side; the rich texture is there, but i wasn’t very impressed with this
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are fruits, caramel, spices and malt. Some alcohol in finish.

Glistening reddish-mahogany with a small, creamy, short-lived white head. Sugary sweet nose of fruit (berries), caramel, cocoa, and little alcohol... very nice. Full bodied, well-integrated flavor thats riddled with fruit, some caramel, and a little alcohol. Long-lasting in berries. Though not as potent as the regular version, this stands on its own, especially with the delicate fruit.

Bottle.  Poured out of the top when I popped the cap.  Poured a hazy amber color with a huge head.  Aroma of sweet malt and fruit.  Flavor was horribly metallic.  Couldn’t find any other notes because the metal taste was so bad.  Disappointing.
