Tap SB&WF-08 - Unclear ruby amber colored beer with a small dense head. Aroma is sweet malty with strong notes of caramel and ripe fruit. Flavor is very malty and sweet with notes of cherries and caramel. A warming full bodied beer. Very well made!

Brown color with a modest dark beige, a bit fizzy, head. Some fish food swimming in the dark pool. Caramel, dark fruit and herbal hops in the aroma. Dark fruit cake flavors, with dates, raisins, sorghum, walnuts, currants and candi. Herbal finish and rather dry into the linger. Lots of flavor, but not a great deal of depth. Strength is not easily detected. An easy sit by the fire brew.

2006 bottle. Pours dark copper with creamy head. Aroma is spicy and malty. Nutmeg is most apparent, with dark roasted caramel and some pear fruit. Very big and malty body with high carbonation. Clean and malty sweet with christmas spices.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2008 Dark brown/red pour with tan head.  Aroma is of yeast, sugar, bubblegum, dried fruits.  Flavor is of the same.  Fizzy on the palate and very full bodied.  After taste is tangy and fruity and lingers.  Simply amazing brew.

Pours dark brown out of the bottle and settles into a dark mahogany in the glass.  The head is fluffy and off-white and dissipates fairly quickly to a ring with good lacing.  The aroma is sweet with dark fruit, plums and raisins, and a bit of candied sugar and roasted malts.  There are some spices in the aroma but very faint.  The taste is a little less complex than the original version with a little less spiciness and a heavy dose of grape sweetness.  There’s a little bit of cola flavor in there as well on top of a roasted malt base with some caramel tones.  The mourhfeel is medium bodied with a little less carbonation than the original.  There is a little less sour kick on this one and, for me, leads to a slightly more drinkable beer.  Either way, this is a slight notch below the original but a great beer on its own.

Bottle: Poured a brown to black color with a medium tan to beige head. The aroma is dark fruit, bubble gum, and some sugar. Taste is more of that dark fruit possibly raisin, with some sugar. Finish is dry and tingly. This lives up to the Struise hype for me!

pours a brownish amber with a thin tan head.
Aroma is enticingly sweet. Candy and brown sugar. medium malt, some dark fruit tones.
Flavour is a little lighter than I expected. Very well balanced. Initially sweet malt, some raisin and dark fruit tones. slight alc bitterness through the middle. Finishes very smooth.

Bottle pours a deep brown with a thin beige foam that falls immediately to a skim of fine bubbles around the rim of the glass.  Aroma of dark fruit, sweet malt, raisin, brown sugar with an earthy & spicy element.  Flavor is initially rather intense brown sugary sweetness with more dark fruit, figs and raisins.  As that fades, dates & plums with a very faint wisp of alcohol and a very light tangy sensation like grape/apple skins.  Finishes clean with a moderately thin palate and lightly carbonated.
fantastic, it has high malts, caramel and toffee. this beer would go great with a hearty beef dish.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2008 The aroma is sweet with dark fruit, brown sugar, malt, and leaves. The appearance is light brown/red with an average head. The flavor is like the aroma. The palate is thin. This is good but not great.

Bottle tasted at Uber Tavern.  So I have not been able to do the vertical test with the darker Pannepot, so I feel a bit blind in this rating.  Regardless, I picked up many of the same notes from the cousin in this beer, just with a much rounder and less potent presence.  Still chocolatey, mildly roasty and sweet, plum still exists, even a bit of banana.  Lots of spice thrown in the mix.  Mainly, its almost the same to me, just without the punch.  Excellent beer!

33cl bottle at home: Very deep and dark hazy chestnut brown, almost black. Bubbly medium dark head collapses somewhat quickly. Aromas of dark malt, brown sugar, and raisins. Coffee and tree-bark add a nice earth note. Dark spices run underneath the sweetness. A bit of aniseed. Alcohol is easily roused from the glass. Starts out quite sweet in the mouth. Moves to sugared mocha latte for a second before roast and alcohol break things up a bit. Sweet caramel malt. Alcohol soaked prunes come and go in the middle. Something lightly tangy, for lack of a better word, plays with the alcohol and sugar. Towards the end there is again prune but this time with alcohol and a touch of molasses. A touch of oxidation perhaps on the end too? Full mouthfeel with an odd dustiness on the tip of the tongue. Very nice beer, but I prefer the original pannepot.
Pours dark caramel with no head. Nose is toffee, caramel, dried fruit. The flavor is the same with a strange tangy fruit finish.

Side by side with the good other, thanks for sharing Yaniv.  Hazy brownish red with almost no head.  Sweet and round caramel.  Dark malt character.  Figgy sweet dark fruit.  Raisins and small prune.  Full creamy rich body.  Big full sweet figgy date riains.  Big dark malt, big alcohol, but not boozy.  Very quad-like.  some chocolate, small roast.

Fantastic beer.  Another bottle from Uber Tavern taken to go this time.  OPens with a light nose of brown sugar and alcohol.  Color is cloudy, dusty brown - very interesting to watch.  Plenty of sediment, too.  Looks like it was oak-aged.  Flavor for me was very clear: caramel, butter, salt, and violets up front into green raisins, red wine, hints of oak and figs to finish.  Really quite something; due to its consistency, probably easier drinking than its darker cousin.

Picked this up at WLV Liquors. Pours dark reddish brown with thin light tan head. Nice aroma of spices, caramel, toffee, candied suger and dark fruits. Flavor is wunderful with caramel, sweet malt, suger, dark fruit, spices,  toffee and a touch of chocolate. With out a dought the best BSA that I have ever had. No yeast notes which makes this brew so good. Very complex and has some nice barley wine qualities with out hops. Hides alcohol very well. What a beautiful brew. Cant wait to try regular Pannepot.

Thank you to ajm for splitting the bottle.  Poured a murky brown/amber with a thick head of tan foam and noticable sediment at the bottom of the glass.  Plenty of alcohol and brown sugar on the nose.  Loaded with cinnamon, caramel, and butter.  Quite a treat.

330ml Bottle:  Sweet aroma.  Smells vinous, with notes of candi sugar, dark fruit, grapes, caramel, and malts.  Poured medium brown/dark ruby in color with a small, dense, beige that diminished.  Cloudy.  No lacing.  Flavor is medium sweet.  Tastes of candi sugar, yeast, light spices, alcohol, dark fruits, raisins, and port wine.  Medium body.  Oily, then chalky texture.  No carbonation.  Sweet, fruity finish.  Very drinkable.
Very murky brown color. Instant aroma of dark fruits. Excellent mouthfeel of mild chocolate and heavy spices. Small hints of alchohol linger. Deliciously balanced.

Brownish color with a medium head.  Aroma is sweet and brown sugary - lots of belgian malt and smooth fruit essence.  Flavor is really nice with some light spice, sugar, and dark & sweet fruits.  Not quite as good as the regular Pannepot, but a solid beer nonetheless.
Excellent beer, very complex, rose wine like beer. Great beer, will come back to this one time and again.

Bottle: A dark mahogany ruby color with an almost crimson hue. A light head, light carbonation and obviously light lacing. The nose is lighter than I expected; some basic chewy fruits, fig, cherry, juniper and some yeast. The flavor is a bit more of what I wanted, some chewy rye, light metallic note, but a sweet and savory ride with a hint of fruit and bitterness in the tail. Very little alcohol notes. Excellent.
UPDATED: MAY 20, 2011 33cl, brew anno 2009, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex, balanced, cloudy, good head, very good brew

An interesting take on one of my favorite beers.  Beautiful aroma of cocoa, dark fruits, licorice, roast, ad wine.  The only real difference I can detect from the original Pannepot is a less pronounced chocolate character and a more pronounced dark fruit character.  Regardless, an amazingly tasty beer.

bottle.  pours a dark brown with a 1/4" tan head.  dark fruit aromas... so smooth over the palate.  a true pleasure to drink.  extremely soft from front to back... the fruit notes come alive on palate.  plums and raisins are most present.  wonderful malt character.... overall an extremely well balanced and smooth beer.

2006 Bottle at Haket. Pours a dark brown colour with a pale head. The aroma is very fruity - overripe plums, dried fruit, milk chocolate, some liqueur. Very complex. The flavour is sweet,complex and very fruity with notes of overripe plums, dried fruit, milk chocolate, spices and some bitterness in the finish. Yummy!

Dark brown with a disappearing tan head. Even if i’ve drank just 2 bottles of this one and several of the "straight" one, i rate  Pannepøt some decimals more, because I’ve founded less licorice in it and lot more berries and fruits and malty sweetness, ’though a bit ethilic when poured. Chocolate and spices complete the whole, along with several other things i’m sure i can’t detect. Full sipping body, a pleasure.

Bottle, at cgarvieuks, with Stella, the kids, and Traci. Really great tasting Craigthanks! Esp nice of you to pull this one out to share with me, even though you’d had it already. Deep brown, nice layer of tan head. Peppermint, dark resiny chocolate and mahogany aroma. Sweet resiny caramel flavor, milk chocolate, hints of spice around the edges. Just a little lingering sweet. Not sure if I could tell this from Pannepot blind, but that’s not a bad thing at all.

Bottle.  Prune/raisin/cherry plus soy sauce with hints of cinnamon and vanilla.  Murky orange-brown color with a moderate head.  Sweet dried fruit (cherry/apricot), white pepper and astringent alcohol flavor.   A bit rougher than regular Pannepot.  Nice strong beer.

11.2 oz bottle. Pours a murky brown with a ton of foam.  Lacing all over the glass.  Strong aroma of dark fruits, spice, brown sugar.  The taste is slightly sweet, with raisins, dates, plums, and a bit of spice.  Very malty.

12oz bottle from a recent trade.  thanks to whoever that was!.... dark milk chocolate brown pour with an almost toppling thick light brown head.... fresh pungent ripened fruit minus the in-your-face spiciness offered by the US version.... flavors of sweet dark ripened fruit which was very much sweet and malt dominated.  still a very nice full mouthfeel with somewhat of a metallic aftertaste.....nice but i still very much prefer the US version.

33cl bottle obtained at West Lakeview Liquor in Chicago.  Pours a cloudy red/brown, after a geyser of foam opening the bottle.  Aroma strongly of figs, spice, and brown sugar.  Taste sweet, slight spice, and slightly acidic.  Creamy and smooth mouthfeel.  Very nice beer!

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2014 First rating33 cl bottle at Café 3 Små Rum, Göteborg.On June 9, 2008.BB 05-11, 2006 vintage.Not gushing, but slowly coming out on its ownAt least I think this is the one, it did read Pannepøt on the label, but also "Old Monks Ale PNP No. 5"Clear beautiful dark red color, small light brown head. With a nicer looking and bigger head it would have been stunningly beautiful. Sweet, spicy, lactic, yogurt scent. Spicy, phenolic, metallic, lactic, smoke, band aid taste. Fizzy mouthfeel that grows in the mouth. Low bitterness.6/4/5/2/11=2.8RerateOn March 15, 2014. Thanks to RobertGBG and thomat! Bottle.2006 vintage "Pannepeut".Hazy dark brown color, small dark brown head. Yoghurt, sweet scent. Sweet, alcohol, metallic taste. Metallic, grainy aftertaste. Fizzy mouthfeel, medium to low bitterness. Some ash aftertaste too.6/3/7/3/12=3.1

bottle. I dont think this went over well at the tasting but I thought it was darn good! Very ruby red color. Aroma of raisin or dark fruit. Creamy and yeasty with a hint of the 10%. A Belgian strong ale that I can get behind for sure.

Bottle recommendation - Poured a dark reddish black with a tan simmering head.  A rich strong grape aroma.  On the Pallet there are hints of coffee-dark roast, coco and an earthy grape sweetness.  Some slight odd sourness which may have turned me off a little.  For all the hype Im going to need a re-taste of this.

Another gift from Mes, and another belting beer. Lovely. Creamy flavour with a load of dark spices, fruit and other flavours bunged in. Alcohol present but compliments the taste. A pleasure to have in my pie hole. Cheers again bro.

Bottle. Had it right after a Pannepot, and hardly compares outside of the name. Dark fruits abound, spices, alcohol, pretty average body for a Belgian Strong. Lacks the creamy body and rich flavors of Pannepot. My whole rating probably shouldn’t be based on the comparison, but suffice it to say it’s a solid Belgian Strong that’s worth a go.

Bottle.  Pours a light cloudy brown with a small tan head (lighter body than Pannepot and the head is not as creamy and thick).  Aroma mostly of light fruits, spices, and spicy crisp apple.  Flavor of Belgian yeast, spcies, light fruits.  It tastes so fresh!  Not as complex as the Pannepot but I like the lighter fruit presence.  Palate is not as creamy.  I think I preferred this to the Pannepot.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with a fizzy beige head. Fruity aroma, with melon, raisin and honey. Medium body, smooth, but a bit flat. Sweet malt flavor, honey, caramel, and fig. Ok, but not great.

2006 bottle from psprings...  cloudy opaque mahogany/reddish brown color with a light beige head and some lacy trails. aroma of golden raisins, dry yeastiness, spice, light alcohol, orange peel, chocolate, earth, light acidity and roasted pears. on the sweet side but not too bad. its got to hide the 10%... the flavor is pretty much the same as the aroma with the addition of dried dates and sweetened green verjus. tart, dry, yeasty finish lingers a bit. medium body but a bit more than medium body...

From Voldby, DK.
Bottled, 260608.
Dark brown with brown head. Aroma complex of dried fruit, malt and hop spices. Flavor of sweet caramel malt, raisins, alcohol (well hidden) and a solid hop bitterness.

Yeah, I definitely remember the original being a pretty different (and better) beer.  This one is good, but not nearly as complex or entertaining.  Some prune and vanilla aromas with a slight musty aspect to it as well.  Flavor is raising, molasses, and prune again.  It leaves a bit of a disorienting roasted malt/alcohol flavor on the back of your tongue.  Pours dark purple color with a nice off white head and some really entertaining lace.

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2011 2006 vintage.  The beer pours to an extremely dark ruby body that looks black with a 1 inch tall frothy beige head.  The aroma is extremely fruity and yeasty.  Dark fruits of dates and figs meets a heavily estery yeast and plantains.  The flavor is an extremely yeasty sugary malt bomb.  Candi sugar, light brown sugar, estery yeasts, and light plantains.  The palate has a long lasting sweetness, coating mouthfeel, and is sticky but not syrupy.  Silken.  A good beer. 7, 4, 8, 4, 15 = 3.8.

2008 Pannepeut vintage bottle picked up in Belgium.  The beer pours to a blackish ruby body with a nice beige head.  The aroma is fruity, yeasty, and has a subtle black patent or other charred malt.  Dark figs and candied dates with definite sweet sugar cane.  The flavor is yeasty and malty.  Similar to a nice Abbel Dubbel, but this has a subtle charred malt among the plantains and brown sugar.  I can imagine the monks drinking this elixir while doing their own home brewing.  Sweet and silken.  Alcohol content is well masked.

Had this at Mess 20-06-08  in the company of Mes, Ang and Loz, many thanks Mes for your generosity   The aroma is faintly alcohol with some soft vanilla ice cream that has also been liberally sprinkled with spices. The colour of this is a murky pond water brown colour, a bit like a puddle actually with a thin off white film for a head. There is a soft fudge chewiness the alcohol sits back then kicks in briefly reminding me of a lovely old port, some demera sugar, oohh this is lovely and feels fantastic in the mouth.  I cannot wait to crack open the Pannepot. Cheers Mes!

2006 Bottle thanks to Bigmmartin. Pours a dark ruby body with a medium light beige head. The aroma is quite like sour cherries along with a ton of brown sugar and ripe fruit. The taste is full of many flavors heaps of dark fruits and perhaps strawberries, caramel and brown sugar, sweet milk chocolate, oh this is a treat. A very creamy and full mouthfeel that I love. Very good.  Sweet, and full, no notice of the alcohol except a general warmth. Just so damn good. Struise kicks ass again!

2006 bottle. Fruity, sweet and musty  the hallmarks of a nicely crafted Belgian strong ale for me. Dark body, hazy, with off-white, fizzy head that slowly diminishes. Nice aroma of overripe fruits, especially plum and banana, toffee, chocolate and raisin. Just a hint of cellar mustiness. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly bitter and lightly acidic. Tastes of cookie, caramel, brown sugar and sweetened prunes. Long finish. Full body with a velvet texture that turns sticky in the finish. Lively carbonation and moderately alcoholic. Very enjoyable though a little too sweet to want more than one at a sitting.

bottle at tashis thanks to mes and reakt. very harmonious start. this smells lovely, and looks great. but its somewhat unrefined compared to the pannepot. very sweet and very bitter, not much in the middle and rough round the edges. dont get me wrong, still a stunning beer. but maybe im a bit struise-spoilt...

750mL bottle shared by iowaherkeye in Jan. 2007.

Brown color with a beige head and decent retention.  Smell is of brown sugar, plums, raisins, and caramel.  Taste is slightly tart, has some tastes of pears, caramel, toffee, and some dark fruits too.  Medium bodied with a heavier than medium body.  Thanks for sharing this, Joey.

Tasted it at the Proefzolder Picobrewery Alvinne. A dark red/brown colored beer, with a beige head, which dissapears quiet soon. An aroma of light chocolate, several sweet notes and a bit spicy. The taste of dar caramel, a bit sweet of raisins and prune. Also a bit spice.

Beautiful dark beer that is very fruity and extremely, overwhelmingly crisp. Huge head that filled the glass after two ounces were poured but settled quickly. Tons of brown sugar, cane sugar, sugary alcoholy liquers, and super sour green apple and plum skins. Lots of overripe plum ripe body flavor. Just awesome, dont know why this isnt rated higher, and cant wait to try the Pannepot for sure.

330 ml bottle, courtsey of yngwie. Small beige head rapidily reduced to ring of foam.  Dark mahogny, low carbonatied body. Aroma has a vinous charachter, dark tinned fruits, toffee, and a scent of alcohol. Notes of yeast and cellar. Taste is light sourish malts, a plummy fruitiness, and a note of brown sugar and spices. Full-bodied. Malty, spicy, sugary finish. Reliable and tasty, but not outstanding.

11.2oz bottle sampled alongside its cousin, Pannepot. 2006 vintage. Not as aromatic as its cousin. I smelled subdued cherry and toffee mostly. Not terribly boozy. Poured a clear ruddy brown color. Head was two fingers high and off white with good retention. Only a bit of lace was left behind on the glass. Medium bodied, moderately effervescent, and slightly sweet. Dark fruits dominated the flavor, but there was also some champaign, apple, and clove. Tasty. Despite having the same alcohol content, it didnt seem as overtly boozy as Pannepot.

11.2 oz bottle: Near black pour with a pillowy beige head that settles into a suitable finger-thick head.  The nose offers a great balance of yeast and malt.  Phenolic banana and apple balance well with a healthy dose of burnt sugar, sweet chocolate and plum.  Big, chewy mouthfeel with soft carbonation.  Raisins and plums hit the tongue first, with a second wall of malt offering burnt cookie and dark chocolate.  Finishes chalky with residual cocoa and fudgey notes.  Good stuff.

Bottle courtesy of psprings.  2006 vintage.  Pours a opaque chocolate brown with minimal head.  Nose is toffee, dark fruits, molasses and alcohol.  Palate is sweet with raisins, brown sugar, vanilla and a touch of salty chocolate in the finish.  Lighter mouth feel.  Pretty complex brew that hides its alcohol nicely.  Thanks Paul!

My bottle (12oz) shared with HogTownHarry -- courtesy of gunhaver. 2006 vintage. Pours a hazy deep copper-brown with a small diminishing frothy off-white head. Aroma of lightly sour fruit, caramel malt, brown sugar, spices and dusty yeast. Flavours pretty much the same: Lightly sour fruit with spices, brown sugar and caramel malt. Thick and syrupy. Alcohols totally hidden. Good stuff, I could pound back several of these -- easily.
Bottle (2006 vintage): pours a murky, brownish-red with just a few whisps of head, strong aroma of alcohol and spices, taste is malty with plenty of spices, no sign of the alcohol.

2006 Vintage: Slightly thick head which dissipates slowly, spicy aroma and mouth feel, cinnamon is apparent. Chocolate is present, candy, maltiness, candi sugar, bit of caramel. Not as complex as the Pannepot Number 4 I think and I prefer the other one.

Thick dark brown pour with a thin light tan head.  Very intense spice aroma - sweet cinnamon and nutmeg.  Similar spicy flavor.  The spices remind me of many Christmas beers.  Its port like and strong, but the alcohol is not overpowering.  I think I would have enjoyed this more on a cold winter day.

Tashis house, 28/05/08. Bottle courtesy of Mes and Reakt. Pours a murky brown with a   malty aroma that manages to be both salty and sour. Chocolate malt, oranges, toffee and hops all vie for your attention and the spicy notes keep the candy sweetness in check. Smooth on the tongue, but rather unbalanced and "to & fro" for my liking.
Pours a dark brown with a good sized flufy tan head.  Aroma of candi sugar, belgian yeast, caramel.  Taste is the same with maybe a hint of dark fruit. Good stuff.
UPDATED: JUL 22, 2008 Pours a darkish brown with a nice size tan head. Aroma is caramel, candy sugar, and Belgian yeast. Beautiful flavor, nice and sweet. Creamy palate. Excellent.

2006 vintage 11.2 oz. bottle  (purchased at Keg Liquors in southern Indiana: Clarksville) into sniffer with most of bottle conditioning yeast left behind.  First thing first, I quickly bought this thinking it was the PannepOt; oh well, lets give it a try.  Pours dark brown amberish with a nice off-white head.  The head stunned me because it was shaping up to be a normal big puffy beer head, but then it started fizzling loudly like a sodas, receding pretty quickly. Very typical sweet Belgian aroma with hints of cherries and sugar.  Flavor includes sweet malts with cherries (somewhat metallic altogether) with a grain flavored finish.  There seems to be much more complexity on the finish than the initial flavor.  The alcohol is hidden very well.  It is heavy on the stomach but soft, a bit fizzy, and medium to light bodied on the palate.  Overall: I tend not to be a Belgian man due to the general sweetness of the style, but this is quite pleasurable; I wouldnt have more than one in a sitting though, because this bitch is still a bit too sweet for my taste; worth a try though, although I wouldnt buy it again at 7-8 dollars per single.

Bottle (330ml).  Shared by blankboy.  2006 Vintage.  Cloudy deep brownish-red with an smallish frothy off-white head.  Sweet caramel malt aroma, thick sweet yeast, dry hops, floral pungency, not much alcohol.  Taste follows, dry, sweet, dry hopped, subtle with hints of candy, chocolate, raisins, appleseed and wildflowers - and wheres that 10%?  Somewhat thick, astringent ---- not a world beater, but well made and damned tasty.
I really like this one. It reminds me of Rochefort 10, if i am right. This is for me belgish beer.

From 12 oz. bottle (2006) bought at Bruisin Ales. Has a mild cherry skin aroma, with rich dark fruit, alcohol vapor, mild brown sugar, and some citrus rind and muskiness. Light funky hoppy character with a bit of spicyness. Dark muddy brown body topped with a thin foamy light brown lacing head. Medium-heavy watery body with medium carbonation and light alcohol warming. Starts with watery, unsweetened fruit juice, with notes of plum, fig, lemon rind, and tea. Dark candi sugar with a vinuous tart-sweet warming. Mild spicy character in there, too, but not easy to discern which spice. Funky yeasty tastes in there, too, with a thin but warming finish - almost like a dry sherry. After is sweet and bready. Overall, a nice quaff.
(Bottle at Cambrinus, Brugge, on 2008-05-22) Deep dark brown. Medium sized. dense light tan head. Malts and salty liquorice in nose. Full palate. Sweet caramell in taste. Some liquorice. Nice.

06 vintage. Served at room temp. Pours a thick brown color with a syrup like consistancy and a medium sized yeasty head. WHen opened this bottle was a gusher. Nose is spice dark fruit, sugar, caramel, milk chocolate and booze. Taste is very sweet and feels great in the mouth. I wish there was a little more complexity to the taste but everything that is there is very nice. Great beer.
Bottle. Dark fruits and dark sugars in the nose. Fairly clear brown body, small tan head. Brown sugar dominates the start, with dried fruits and mild bitterness. Hides alcohol pretty well. Nice.
Bottle from Mystery swap 3.0. Pours an amber colour with a hugh off-white head. Aroma of dates, anise, and caramel. Taste is sweet malt, dates, and brown sugar. Has a semi sweet finish. Very nice!

2006 bottle served at 52*F. Pours with a largish, rocky, light brown head covering an extremely dark brown body. Aroma has notes of spices, cinnamon, chocolate, pepper kernels, alcohol and apples in it. Taste is strong, rich ahd savory, with yeastyness, spices and some madera like qualitys. Alcohol is well hidden, and adds a nice punch about ten minutes into drinking it. Creamy mouthfeel. A pretty good brew for how far it has travelled.

2006 bottle from WLV. This was not really what I had anticipated. The aroma seemed to be lacking to me. Some cocoa, caramel and soy, a little barnyard, actually. Taste was better, once I got some of the astringent carbonation out. Looked really nice with deep red amber color and big bubbled off white head. Overall a bit underwhelming, but still a nice beer.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2009 2007: A totally different beer. Flavour typical of the area and recalling the Westvleteren 8: raisings, tasted bread, brioche. An improvement on the original for me. Lets hope the recipe stays.

2005: Darkish beer with a not too thick foam and not extremely dark. Complex aroma dominated by malt and caramel. The taste is rather nice of cocoa, spices and fruit even if with a light texture and bitterish finishing.

scura buona schiuma non abbondante ma fine e persistente sentori di caffe cioccolato leggero vinoso frutta secca spezie credo cannella decisamente morbida bevibilità eccezzionale  poco attenuata leggermente speziata forse cannella finale lievemnte luppolato persistenza media
dark in color.  solid head.  aroma is spicy and enticing.  Taste falls short of aroma.  A bit metallic.  a little disappointing...

Pours a lightly cloudy cola brown color.  A large, foamy, tan colored head settles slowly to a wispy, creamy film.  A sudsy wash mostly rejoins the body, with scant lines of lacing remaining behind.  The aroma shows tons of candy sugar, caramel, fig and dark spice.  A wave of tannic fruit, including overly ripe red apples, lends depth and a certain sourness to the nose.  Flavors are basically the same, with caramel covered figs and apples showing quite sweet.  A touch of spicy, floral hops lend some balance, though this one still falls well short of the median on the bitterness scale.  Medium-full and creamy, the body slides down incredibly easily, leaving a lingering sweet and sour coating on the tongue.  Drinks quite nice, but this just doesnt hold a candle to the regular Pannepot.  There is an intangible magic in that brew that this one doesnt capture.

Geproeft in Rusteel Gullegem. het aroma heeft een zoet fruitige aanzet met zurige ondertoon. De smaak is wat zoetzurig, heeft een prachtig mondgevoel en heeft een aangename zoete (beetje banaan) afdronk.Dit zeer complex bier waar bij de suikers het verschil maakt tussen pannepot en pannepeut.

Bottle. 2006 w/Brian K.  Traded from the motherland.  Pour dark brown with amber hues.  Strong spiced nose, not much else detectable.  Flavor is that of spices, nutmeg, licourish, and caramel.  Spied finish.  Solid beer.

06 vintage. Pours a murky brown with a thin tan head. Noticeable yeast floating. Aroma is mostly raisin. Tastes of earth, yeast, plums, and sweet dark fruits. Palate is semi sweet with a earthy dry finish. Very tasty. Thanks Matt.

2006 bottle.  Pours a tan brown and is somewhat translucent.  Lacing is light.  Aroma of sweet malt, fruit, spice, and booze.  This is somewhat like a barleywine.  Taste is of spice, fruit, sour fruit, malts, and light booze.  Finishes dry with little bitterness.    Mouth is full with some carbonation, maybe a little on the syrup side.

bottle served in a tulip. pours a deep brown color with a thin tan head. nose is full of spices and alcohol. flavor is very sweet with brown sugar and toffee being the base flavors with hints of fig, nuts, and cinnamon. alcohol is well hidden in the taste and only appears as a bit of warmth. quite good and like the rater before me I am now very interested in trying the real deal.

33cl bottle. Poured a deep brown with slight haze, highlights of auburn and orangey-gold, and a thin, light tan head. The aroma was sweet and malty - toffee, caramel, alcohol, and subtle touches of spice and fruit. The flavor follows the nose: lots of toffee and caramel in the malt flavors. The beer was very malty and had a fairly high degree of residual sweetness. The beer was mostly clean, highlighting the malts over all else. There were some esters around mid-palate: soft and dark fruit and very subtle notes of tart fruit and spice. The finish had a low degree of bitterness with a full, caramel malt finish. The mouthfeel was thick, but velvety and decadent - not syrupy and cloying. There was a decent bit of carbonation - which was surprising considering how little head poured up. Overall, this was a very tasty beer and hid its alcohol content extremely well. I definitely had this version ("ø" vs. "o"), but Im looking forward to trying the other one now (its rated higher and is supposedly available in the area...).

Bottle 2006 Vintage:  Pours a muddy brown with a wispy beige head and light bits of lacing.  Nose is fruity and rich with caramel, dark fruits, spice, and a light hint of chocolate.  Flavor is full of dark fruits, chocolate and spices.  Cinnamon and cloves stand out, but there is a nice blend and balance of spice.  Nice feel and good vibe to this brew.

2006 bottle. Lot D, C, CC.  A subtle beer that seems to have been born in an Old World bake shop. On the nose: dried figs, dried apricots and spiced apple cider. Each morsel begins with velvety foam and creaminess and ends with almost no bitterness. The acutal taste is  a blend of  grape juice, prune juice, dates and toasted almonds...which vanishes all too quickly.     

Audio Pairing: "In The Meantime" - Spacehog
Honey in there.  Hides the alcohol well.  Fruity.  Dark amber in color.  Good beige head.  Fruits, dark fruits in the taste.  Some caramel. Apricots, pears.  Smooth mouthful.  Good beer.

12ozer, not sure where this one came from.   Shared with bikesandbeer and others. Pours brown brown orange with a off white head.  Nose is big and fruity and plum like.  Taste is sweet, ruddy, deeply fruity and full of caramel.  Ive been saving this bottle and I have to say I like it, I havent done it side by side with the others, I could, but why drink all that good beer at once.  Very very nice.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2015 750 Bottle at home ... Deep red brown ...sweet deep fruity malty nose ... wonderful mouthfeel ... Lors of sweet caramel ... plums and bready... little coconut
bottle at home ...2006 drunk 08-2011 dark brown ... thin lacing ... soft sweet plum and raisin nose... dark roast ... dark sweet roast ... toffee and green raisins ... little bready ... soft yeast ... dark roast ... dark fruits ... 

 bottle at home ... 2006 drunk oct 2012(oh opps i think this is Panneepot(i had some misslabeled ones) ... dark brown ... lightest head ... deep blackcurrant fruits ... rich sweet ... big plum nose ... dark malts ... big rich fruits .. dark malts ... little licorice... rich malts ... mellow smooth 4.3

 bottle at home .. drunk Sept 2014 ... 2010... depp brown .. thin tan lacing ... soft fruits ... dark malts ... heavy malts ... dark fruits ... dakr juicy malts ... heavy malts ... soft fruits ... dark fruits .. sweet juicy roast ... dark berries ... its cracking even after all those years4.3

bottle at home 2006 version July 2015 ... deep brown ... thin tan lacing ... soft sweet wine berries fruit nose .. soft raspberry nose... big berries nose ... soft toffee fruit... jjuicy malt ... 4.3

12 oz bottle. dark brown pour with a small brown head. Swee,  malty, spicy nose. Taste is sticky, sweet palate, soft carbonation, full body, a bit alcoholic, easy drinking. I liked this better than the Pannepot regular.  Reminds me of Westy 8.  Very nice beer.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: 2006 bottle picked up at South Bay Drugs. In the nose, I find a spicy blend of yeast as well as a sweet malt aroma. The flavor is heavy with sweetened malts that taste sugary and sweet like a malt non-alcoholic beverage. The appearance was an opaque pitch dark brown with small foaming on top.

2006 bottle.  Murky reddish brown color with a thin beige head that shrank to a lasting whisp on the surface.  Big fruity sugar nose with some dark caramel notes.  Tons of ripe, juicey fruit flavors with plum, apple, raisen, plus clove and cinnimon spices. The alcohol comes to the fore as it warms.  I almost get smoke in the end.  Luscious mouthfeel.  Really very nice.

The beer was brown with a small amount of off-white head and amply carbonated. In the aroma I detected malt, mild oak, fruit, and spices. In the flavor I detected malt, mild oak, fruit (raisins?), spices, and alcohol. It was smooth and thick with a heavy mouthfeel.

2006 Vintage. Bottled purchased at PP Bottle Shop in Carlsbad. Dark brown color with a floaty beige head, doesnt seem as sticky as regular Pannepot. Caramel, toffee and strong raisin aroma with alcohol. Fruity flavor similar to Pannepot, but it seemed that the palate is lacking something. Big Belgian yeast note that is character to this type of brew. Really tasty stuff, but I think Id prefer the original.

Bottle during Maxs 72 Hour Belgian Beer Fest. Dark brown pour with a small tan head. Nose is exquisite - dark fruits, caramel, choco notes yeast and candi sugar. Taste is creamy malts, chewy caramel, dark fruits, soft custard, light dusty yeast and candi sugar. Body is so creamy and chewy. This just goes down with ease. Medium-full overall feel with a creamy carbonation. Ends with more dark fruits, caramel, sweet malts, custard, cocoa, and powdery yeast. Awesome stuff!

330 ml bottle from South Bay drugs. This is the 2006 vintage. Poured a murky roan-brown color with a small beige head. The nose displays dark fruits; plenty of raisins, dates, plums, prunes and some dust. The flavor is similarly very fruity with Belgian yeasts rounding out the taste nicely. The mouthfeel is smooth and creamy. The finish is long with lingering plums. Overall: A well concocted brew, but I was expecting more complexity . Still I will drink again without hesitation.

*i liked it ok, would not buy it*

aroma: mild.. some candy some booze.. a touch of a strawberry fruitroll up.. i think.   app: red rootbeer.. nothin to neat. flavor: not bad not great. its a good belgian for someone that is not in love with the style. no flavor really jumps out. there are a bit of red berries, but not to much. palate: wish it was more velvety.  OA:  its good, was wishing for more.

33 cl bottle, 2006 vintage, via one of my Danish traders.  Pours a dark amber body with some small floaties churning about among vigorous carbonation.  Nice creamy beige head.  The nose is intensely fruity with great Belgian yeast and a little alcohol.  Plums, figs, candi sugar, smells wonderful.  It tastes fruity and very sweet with a hefty dose of alcohol and earthy yeastiness.  Lots of banana on the lingering finish.  Very smooth and well rounded.  Mouthfeel is perfect, creamy and thick with a slight clinginess and perfect soft carbonation.  Overall, pretty damn good, maybe not quite as good as the regular version, but still quite good.
Hazy brown colour with large beige head.Aroma of nuts and dry fruits nice note of caramel and slight tosted aswell.good mouth feels and all to a great beer.

Big thanks to GMCC2181 for sending this one my way. I was a little hesitant to give it a shot because I saw "Belgian Ale" and "brewed with spices" and kind of got worried, as Im not too keen on either. However, this one really did it right, and I enjoyed it. Similar to Barley Islands Sinister Minister, in a very good way. Pours brown, with an amber hue. Very sharp and nice spicey notes that never dominate. Almost like a brown ale with bite. The aroma is somewhat weak, but I think it was meant to be subtle, which it achieved. Was missing that certain "something" that would really make this one something special, but kudos to them for trying, and lots of kudos for sending this one to me so that I could find only my second Belgian that Ive really enjoyed thus far!

Brandon, Fl. - Kingdom Liquors, 11.2 ox bottle. Pours a dark chestnut brown  with almost no head. Aroma of raisins, moist baked brown bread, and sweet cherries. Flavor has some chocolate notes, faint molasses, candied sugar, caramel, and a brief wisp of alcohol. Blended well together, meant to savor through the evening. Went well with a tray of cheese and crackers. Succulent mouthfeel, thick and full. An excellent ale and a surprise find.

From Enjoyit via trade.  Thanks Svend!  The pour was slightly turbid and brown.  Some lighter hints of copper and ruby, but basically pours dirty brown with a scant off-white head.  Caramel, tart fruit, malt and light yeast in the nose.  Unfortunately I got something weird at one point that smelled like shellfish that was not nice, but it didnt persist, maybe Im crazy.  The flavor was roasted, spicy malts and thin yeast that quickly transitioned into tart fruit that was reminiscent of grapes/raisins.  The mouthfeel was nice and medium bodied.

Whats the difference between this and the non-Danish market one? I dont know. But this tastes like Belgian goodness to me.  Lots of caramel. Dark. Were watching Hells Kitchen, Season 4, begin, and all I can think of is how this show has become a cartoon. The producers must look for people who cant cook. A stay at home dad? Amateur entertainment.  But this beer....this beer...it is pure taste. Nothing amateur here. No cartoon. Very nice.

(2/27/08) Bottle at Cambrinus in Bruges. Dark brown color with a small beige head. Spicy and caramelly aroma. Spicy flavor (too spicy) with with a lot of caramel, licorice and some fruitiness. Medium to full-bodied and lively carbonation. Not really balanced but still decent.

Bottle vintage 2006. Pours dark brown reddish with nice light brown head. Aroma is fantastic. Malty at first then comes sweetness from dried fruit like raisins. Like opening a door to a candy store. In my mouth it explodes with a herbal taste surrounded by dark fruits and roastiness. Long finish. Brilliant stuff.
Nice smooth dark srong ale.  Enjoyed the slight yeast complexity behind the largely smooth malt dark base.

Bottle shared by Crosling.  Poured a hazy caramel brown color with a thin beige head that left some lacing.  Spicy malt aroma with light hints of fruit, plum and grape mostly,  and light hops.  Lightly tart entry with some light bitterness leads into a spicy (clove mostly), fruity finish with some citrus and raisin.  Smooth on the palate with some bite on the finish. Became better as it warmed, something I will have to revisit.  Thanks again Nick.

Bottle from MrBendo.  Pours opaque iced tea brown with a little bit of brown head.  Wow!  Wonderful aromas of grapes, sugar and spice, and chewy chocolate and caramel candies.  Im not as enamored with the flavor.  Pretty spicy.  Clove, and a bit of raisin and alcohol.  Medium body.  High carbonation.  Dry, malty finish.  Still a really good beer.

2006 Bottle. Pours opaque brown/black with a thick tan head. Aroma is sweet dark fruits. My god this is smooth. Great mouthfeel. Lots of dark fruit taste with a hint of alcohol. Some spice in there too. Really complex. Awesome beer.

Bottle: Nice dark brown color, small head. Aroma is sweet raison. Taste is caramel, raison, and dried fruit/spices. Sweet and some tart...The texture is medium but a little to much carbonation. I dont remember the pannepot having that much, I wish I did a side by side testing. Just off the top of my head I do believe the pannepot was better, but this beer was still good.

Notes from side by side with the Pannepot version. Murky brown pour with lighter and smaller head than Pannepot but with some lacing unlike the other. Aroma is sweeter, more caramally. Alcohol still present along with some cocoa and pepper, coffee. Flavor seems sweet and tart at the onset, but then the middle is a bit lacking. at first I liked this a bit more but it didnt develope the complexity of the Pannepot. The bubble isnt as sharp and the body is more creamy on this one.

Without tasting the two Pannepots side-by-side, it is difficult to determine if there are significant differences or if the change in rating is based on bias.  This, like its cousin, was a rich dark leather with solid tan head.  Aroma is dark fruits and brown sugar.  This one seemed sweeter than its counterpart, but it might be my imagination.  Again, the alcohol is well hidden and overall its an enjoyable drink!!!

Pours very black with a beautiful inch of smooth, tan head. Aroma of wine soaked plums and yeast. Very complex flavor. Lots of fruit.. plums, figs, prunes. Lots of spices too, too many to even name... but they hide the alcohol very well. Nice creamy texture with a smooth malty finish. Very good beer, i think i need a few more for a complete insight.

(Bottle, Monks Café, Stockholm, vintage 2006) Dark brown colour with frothy, pale brown head. Malty, spicy, powerful nose with dried fruit, raisins and prunes. Malty, spicy taste with notes of dried fruit, raisins, spices (nutmeg, cardamom, dried coriander), caramel, toffee and liquorice. Spicy, malty finish. Medium to full body with balanced alcohol notes shining through. Lovely beer!

Pours murky mahogany with short-lasting head.  Aroma of pine, caramel, apple cider, plum, raisin, and nice clovey cardamon spiciness.  Flavor is nicely sweet with dark fruits being played up quite a bit, balanced by some nice caramel malts and lingering cinnamon spice as well as some musty yeast.  Had I not tasted some metalic notes, this would have rated a 9 for flavor.  Nice full body and lively carbonation.

Bottle. I must say that this and the Pannepot are becoming favorites. The beer pours brown with a small off white head. The aroma has pine, wood, spices, caramel all there to be enjoyed. The flavor is sweet caramel with the spices adding a nice touch. Finish ismoderately sweet and creamy. This is a beer that reminds me how good beer can be. Maybe a bit sweet for some but I think of this as a great desert beer. I love it.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2008 Pours dark reddish brown with thin frothy tan head that doesnt last long at all.  Aroma is Tobacco and alcohol with other earthy notes.  Flavor is complex with dark fruits...plum and molasses, some spice as well.  Reminds me both of a barley wine and a port.  Nice and warming with the 10% abv.  Apples in the finish.  A really interesting beer. .

Poured a reddish brown with a one finger tan head. The aroma was sweet, portish, dark fruits, molasses, a light spice, a tad meaty and smokey. The flavor was roasty and smokey, sweet plum and dark fruits, light warm alcohol. The palate was full and warm with a soft carbonation.

750 ml bottle, vintage 2006. A cloudy dark ruby beer with a medium sized but disappearing light brown head. The aroma is very good, fruity, with notes of caramel, berries, dark fruits. Some winey hints too. The flavour is sweet, powerful, with a light touch of acidity and a hint of warming alcohol. It has the expected spiciness and fruitiness (berries). Strong bodied, lively carbonated, quite long finish with light bitterness. Maybe a bit filling, but rich and complex. A delicious beer.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2010 [Bottle] (06 Im almost positive) Pours murky mahogany with a thin fine beige head.  Does smell a bit like sherry, but the aroma isnt very strong comparatively and Im getting a little bit of metallic.  Rich sweet molasses and very nutty.  I didnt know if I could tell the difference, but this seems very much more straight forward than Pannepot and more vacant in body.   I also get a little metallic aftertaste from this.  This is still really really good stuff, but after having first tried the Pannepot....=p  This stuff mellows a bit after 15 minutes or so of air.  
[Rerate - another 6 months has moved the flavor from a 8 to a 9] 8.4.9.4.17 . . . . . . . . . . . . [2007 bottle B4EE]  Okay, this beer seems to have changed a bit, either that or I dont remember what it used to taste like =p.  Aroma is straight Westy yeast, super plummy, sherry soaked tea cake, fruity molasses, uh..yup.  Flavor follows, very plummy, westy yeast, seems more attenuated than before, less driven by the molasses flavor and more by the plummy yeast, the sherry soaked cake flavor is 2nd to the yeast character, nice plummy bitterness towards the finish, nice and fresh, bit of warming alcohol on the finish.  Ive got a bottle of 06 left I should open soon to compare, bit of cola towards the finish.  Body is just a bit milky but other than that nicely attenuated with nice carbonation.  Ill leave the score, except maybe a 9 on aroma instead of flavor.  Mmm opened up quite a bit more, both aroma and flavor, intense rum cake and sherry flavors, rich but well attenuated, raisiny.   . . . . . [2006 bottle that Ive hate since early 08) C-C-BB.  Pours a dark milkdud color, richly syrupy brown with a frothy light tan head... yummy, this one gets a 5! Maybe the 07 as described above is actually closer to the 06 than I remember.  The aroma on this is loaded with sherry.... basically smells just like sherry, o that is insane.... no real off putting oxidation notes, loads of vanilla that I never remembered, and birch... smells just like birch, maybe more birch than sherry.  Flavor is way less plummy (bitter) than the 07 and has a smoother brown sugar and birch like flavor, seems to have less depth than it once did, more homogenized sugary goodness now, and flavor has some more of those typical oxidizing malt flavors that the aroma seems to be missing.  Big soda carbonation, bit sticky viscous, not as sophisticated in palate as I remember.  Very tasty and aged extremely well... o I wish I could go back and taste this 2 years ago again.  9.5.9.4.17 (quite delicious as it finally reached room temp and opened up.... endless.. endless amounts of dates, bread pudding, sweetness tapered off as well... fantastic.
Not as good as Pannepot i dont think, but still great. Aroma of ripe darkfruits, port wine and caramel, flavor is quite sweet, again mainly fruitsy, with alchohol as balance, very enjoyable!

Nowhere as good as the Pannepot. I was afraid I would not be able to tell the difference, but never fear. The difference is huge. Aroma was almost vinous but weak. Pour was a flat murky brown with no head. Taste was a little flat. This tastes more like an old ale. Stale malt with iced tea and caramel with a roasty but dirty aftertaste. Not terrible, but nowhere as complex as the Pannepot.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Tasted at 2008 Woodshop hosted by cquiroga. Free bottle from deftim13.  Thanks Tim!  Malty darkish amber color.  Tried side by side with the Pannepot, Panneput, and Pannepot Reserva.  Similar to reserva, and hair less sweet than grand reserva.  Very similar.  The reservas are a little better.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy darkbrown ale eith a big and foamy lightbrown head. Sweet tobacco aroma with notes of caramel and dark fruit. Tastes is lovely complex with caramel, chocolate, cherry and woody notes. Absolutely well worth a try!

Bottle, 10%. Slow gusher. Sweet malt aroma, slightly citric and vinous with roasted notes. Very dark brown colour with a red shine. Small light brown head. The flavour is very vinous and quite malty. Quite high carbonation. A sweet beer, but also with some alcohol balancing it well.

Bottle courtesy of Bu11zeye: Poured a deep dirty cloudy brown color ale with a large foamy head with great retention and some good lacing. Aroma consists of bubblegum ester with some candi sugar and some light spices. Taste is comprised of a sweet malt base which is well balance with some bubblegum ester and some light spicy yeast at the end. Very well balance with no apparent alcohol and a full body with great carbonation. I thought it was slightly less complex then the regular version but I would have to do a side-by-side comparison.

Poured from an 11.2oz bottle and served in a trappist glass.  This beer poured a dark, muddy brown with a quickly fading head of tan bubbles.  Not much lace.  The aroma of the beer was made up of dark fruit, caramel, molasses, candi sugar, dates, corriander, and cinnamon.  The flavor included caramel covered apples, dusty yeast, light spices, and a hint of alcohol.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied and lightly carbonated.  Highly drinkable considering the ABV.  Complex and tasty!

11.2 oz bottle
This is the only release of the Pannepot series that I have yet to try excepting the recent Grand Reserva (which I will have to track down when it hits the states).  Of the three I found this the best by the slimmest of margins.  Whereas the others are definite 3.9s this one is more like a 3.95.  Hopefully Ill be able to find another bottle to restock the cellar for a special occasion.
Aroma / Appearance - A one finger dirty white head rests on top of a sticky chocolate brown body.  There is evidence of carbonation but it is not very lively.  The smell of gingersnap cookies, caramel and molasses filled the area around my glass.  The difference between this and regular Pannepot seems to be the slightly more sweet character.
Flavor / Palate - A creamy coffeelike mouthfeel coats the tongue with chocolate and maple syrup.  Next comes molasses and cherry liquor on a wave of woodiness.  The alcohol is evident in a way that compliments everything.  The warming slightly sweet finish makes this an excellent release.

Bottle. Aromas of citrus, caramel and dark fruits. Very dark brown color with a tan head that rapidly ringed. Near medium body with very mild carbonation.  Almost a cola flavor, with dark fruits and bread. Its mildly sweet and extremely flavorful. The finish is lightly spiced with caramel and complex flavors. Quite unusual and extremely pleasant to drink.

2006 Bottle. Pours a nice amber brown with a small soapy head. Aroma of Citrus, Caramel, Malt, figs, Sour Apple. Very well balanced taste with hints of Brown Sugar, Malt, Cloves, Bread.......theres all sorts of taste in this one...too much to pick out. This is a surprisingly complex and smooth brew and you can in no way tell that this weighs in at a whopping 10%abv. Very well done Struise, very well done indeed.

Tasted directly after a regular Pannepot, it was hard not to draw comparisons between the two beers instead of describing this beer for what it is. Just that the regular Pannepot is so amazing probably pulled this score back a little too. Clear amber brown with a nice lacy tan head. The aroma came across as quite mild in body, but higher in spices.. with lots of vanilla, honey, citrus and caramel. Body is a touch drier and lighter than Pannepot, I think this brings the spices through a little more, and perhaps reveals a touch of astringency in the finish. I loved this beer, but not as much as pannepot.
1/18/08: Bottle. Mahogany colored body.  Nose of raisin, brown sugar and alcohol.  Sweet and sour flavor  fruit, sour apple, white grape, sugary malt and alcohol.  Long, tart finish.  #800

Thanks to miketd.  Dark reddish brown color.  Smell of malt, brown sugar, pepper, clove, caramel, hops, dark fruit, bread dough, alcohol and cola soda.  Taste of malt, brown sugar, pepper, clove, caramel, hops, dark fruit, bread dough, alcohol and cola soda.  Excellent brew!

2006 bottle. Sweet tobacco fermented aroma. Mahagony red body with decent head. Sweet red fruits, chewy licorice, molases, cough syrup quite a mix of flavors that actuall all blend together decently. Dry sweetness lingers for aftertaste. Good night cap.

Spectacular Christmas fruit cake aroma,with twinges of alcohol to tweak your nose,taste is a sublime fuity malty creaminess,with just the most satisfying aftertaste you can imagine, at least given that there is not much hop involved. As about a tantalizing of a beer ith any hint of fruit that Ive had the pleasure to try, Thanks Kingpin

2006 bottling: Dark mahogany. Thin but creamy eggshell head persists nicely with each sip. Cola, licorice, coriander, rum-splashed raisins, and hints of caramelized fruitcake comprise the solid but uninteresting nose. Lots of fruity esters as well. Teasing scent of cinnamon and cocoa. Mild note of doughy yeast. Tight and soft carbonation. Well-rounded acidity is gently embraced by a woody bite of licorice, chewy cola- and rum-like sugars, and a surge of alcohol which provides immediate warmth. Understated dryish maltiness accentuates the earthy spices. Well-integrated flash of aniseed (ester or actual spice?) comes and goes as its soon engulfed by plump raisiny esters. Sufficient sweep of dryness pleasingly cleanses the palate, though the core is a bit hollow and primarily dominated by a flabby fruitiness which fails to get much assistance from the malt. A dab of caramelized malt is faintly perceptible, and does add some structure to the body, but a liberal dose of Pilsner malt would better balance and complement the sweetness. As a result, it comes off as being fairly shallow. That said, the spices and esters are very poignant and bright. Finishes juicily fruity and soft, with a dusting of caramelized and strawlike malt which lurk beneath notes of rum, raisins, and hints of Juicy Fruit gum. Some minor adjustments are all this needs in order to be superb.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle. Pours with a dark brown color and a nice fluffy head. Aromas of molasses and bread, not much Belgian yeast character. Flavors of drak fruit, mulling spices and a bit of dark bread. Finishes with a farily strong alcohol bite. Different but good, very interesting.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2008 Bottled, 2006. Very hazy maroon-coloured, brown lasting head. Malty nose, raisins, alcohol, liquorice and dark fruit. Sweet malty flavour, raisins again, some fruity notes as well. Alcohol remains relatively unnoticed (only in finish). Great mouthfeel, long-lasting finish. Definitely good, but imho less complex and much sweeter than the regular Pannepot. Could improve greatly with aging i think. Im really curious what the oak aged reserva will taste like, too bad its so ridiculously expensive.

Shared at tasting with Fly, Dewbrewer, Humulone_Red and others.  Thanks guys!
Rich colored dark maroon pour with slight transluscence to it.  Bright fruity lemony richness on the nose.  Taste was sweet and smooth with dark brown sugary character.  Slightly drying at times, and a touch cloying at times as well.  Nice flavor of raisins and the alcohol was hidden exceptionally well.  Very enjoyable.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2009 12/31/07 bottle bought several weeks prior. Dark amber, very little head. Rather vinous aroma, yet fairly soft. Raisiny. Sour. Taste: Very raisiny. Too sticky sweet. Alcohol is well hidden.  737315-3.5

7/15/09 bottle bought 20 months ago. Lots of raisin, white wine. Its still a bit too sweet but I think its calmed down a little. Nice finish. 848315-3.8
Had at Ebenezers in Lovell, ME. I had this beer after the regular Pannepot. Very similar but seem to have a slightly more sour finish. Still a tremendous brew.

Pours bronze with a light tan soapy head.  The aroma has lightly sharp caramel malt, anise, cream, pepper and a plasticy element.  Medium body with nice semi-soft carbonation.  The flavor starts with lots of the aroma traits and is a bit on the astringent sides, especially on the finish.  As it warms the astringency goes way down and it gets much creamier and has a pleasant brown sugar taste.  This is a good beer, but not at all up to the regular Pannepot.

Dark brown with no head formation.  Aroma of brown sugar and some faint banana.  Flavors of sweet fruit, vanilla, caramelized sugar, and raisins.  A sweet, sticky finish taps this off.  A very enjoyable beer.

Bottled. Hazy dark brown with a thick tan-coloured foam. Well-rounded complex aroma of brown sugar, licorice, nutmeg and over-riped banana. Full flavour of fudge, coconut, brown sugar, crystallized banana and wood. Long warming finish of fudge, caramel, licorice, oranges, spices and alcohol.

I was not blown away nor did I think this was THE most awesome beer ever, but having said that will add that a beer with flavours that I can pick out from a tasting with 21 beers sampled leaving a lasting impression that was MOST enjoyable is indeed something. Not sure that I could pick out the vast elements from the smorgasbord of flavours, but that was perhaps my favorite part - that there appeared to be so many, but melding so well in such tight harmony.
Thanks to  Charles for sharing.

11.2 oz bottle, 2006 vintage, from trade with Papsoe.  Pours a dark, copper-brown. A thin off-white head dissipated quickly except for a ring around the edge of the glass which produced some lacing.  Aroma of sweet bread and dark fruit.  Flavor of vinous and dark fruit with raisins prominent.  Spices and alcohol also present in the taste.  Mouthfeel is medium with slight bittersweet finish.  A pleasure to drink.

Pours a deep, cloudy brown color with ruby highlights into the trappist glass.  Scnets of plums, raisins, yeast and malt dominate the nose.  The first taste offers several flavorful spices, with caramel, malt and some dried fruits.  Excellent mouthfeel with a strong alcohol finish.  The 10% shows itself more as the beer warms.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2009 2009-12-29, vintage 2007, 8-4-8-4-16=40Dark brown color; the generous and fizzy head reduces quickly, a thin creamy layer is persistent. Intense aroma, malt, caramel, lighter liquorice, star anise, cinnamon; pepparkaka indeed. Strong mouthfeel, with powerful malt and caramel flavor, sweet; delicate but evident spice presence; low bitterness but quite high alcohol perception. Very good, if you like spicy and sweet beers. Probably at its peak.2007-08-06, vintage 2006, 7-4-7-3-14=35Hazy dark brown color; thin creamy head. The aroma is not too strong, with some caramel and malt, late liquorice. The body is quite thick, oily, sweet; with basically caramel flavor and a quite strong presence of sweet liquorice. There is a light alcohol perception at the end. The bitterness is medium-low, otherwise I would recommend to store it for longer. Im not fully convinced by this one (maybe because the sweet liquorice aftertaste still sticks in my mouth).

Bottle sampled. Pours a deep copper color with a small tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, raisins, caramel, and a hint of molasses. Flavor of caramel sweetness, dark fruit, roast, toffee, and some belgian spices. AWESOME BREW

Brown and thick.  Smells like cherries and dates.  Complex, yet light on the palate, I get tastes of cherries, then sourdough bread, followed by raisins and ending with a slightly bitter sweet finish.

12 oz. bottle.  2006 vintage.  Pours a dark leather with almost no trace of head.  Aroma of maple syrup, nutmeg, warming alcohol.  Flavor is sweet, some caramel, carrots, and alcohol.  Finish is malty with a hint of licorice.

Pours deep brown into a tulip.  Tan micro head leaves spot lacing as it slowly recedes to skim surface.  Apricot and pear aromas.  Sticky sweet figs, pear and pit fruit from front to back with a malty, slightly alcoholic burn in the finish.  Definitely a sipper.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2007 Clear deep amber in colour, small but lingering tan coloured head, light lacing.  The aroma is quite rich, lots of candied sugar, fruit cake with only some light alcohol.  The flavour is quite sweet, lots of fruit - cherries mainly - some malt, chocolate, smooth and rich.  Creamy mouthfeel, medium body, mild carbonation.  Finishes long, smooth and creamy.  Incredible beer, quite warming.  No noticeable alcohol.  Quite complex, excellent balance.
330ml bottle from the <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/new-york target=blank>Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, New York for $5.99.
Purchased on August 20, 2007 and opened on November 2, 2007.
Vintage 2006.

11.2oz bottle.  Pours reddish brown with significant red hues when held up against the light.  The head and visible carbonation on this one are drastically less than what Ive experienced in all my bottles of the regular version.  Head retention is also much less in this one, the off white head quickly diminishing to some foamy swirls right on top of the liquid.  Aroma is quite nice and similar to its brother - raisins and other dark fruits, candy, sugar, vanilla,  the idiosyncratic blue cheese, a tiny dab of chocolate.  Wonderfully complex smell.  Soft mouthfeel reveals flavors of sweet fruits and that same sugared coffee aftertaste of Pannepot.  Its hard not to keep comparing this to the other version but what do you expect.  Besides the appearance I cannot distinguish this much from my memory of the original, though Im sure a side by side comparison would reveal a lot more.  Still this is world class.

2006 From Greens in Atlanta
Pours a dull brown with a fleeting off-white head.
Cold, the aroma is caramel-raisin. As it warms, some alcohol appears        .
Very smooth bodied, that leaves a velvety coating on the tongue. Caramel. spice, anise flavors come through .  Hops are way in the back in this one.
Strong, malty.

Bottle purchased at Liquor Max in Loveland, CO.  Pours hazy brown with a small, rocky, off-white head, diminishing with spare lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, caramel), average hops (flowers, grass), average yeast (barnyard, earth) with notes of light alcohol, pear, wood, and coriander.  Full bodied, sticky texture, lively carbonation, and a bitter finish.  Average duration, light sweetness, moderate acidity and bitterness.

2006 Bottles from Sliffy and GenoG.  Thanks!  Pours a healthy dark brown with a  perfectly formed off white head that shows no sign of fading. Nose is nutty and sweet, dates, figs, a little bit of hops, and some spices. Very sweet smelling. Strange flavor. Creamy mouthfeel with a flavor of dark fruits, chocolate, vanilla, a bit of alcohol.

Pours a slightly hazy brown with a thin white head. Aroma is of dark fruit, yeast and slight spice. Taste is complex, with alcohol well hidden. Dark fruit, yeast and earthy/wood flavors, slight citrus sourness on the finish. Definitely a different beer from the other version.

11.2 oz bottle, dated 2006.  Pours a murky brownish tea color with a thin white head that quickly diminishes to a thin film.

The aroma is sweet brown sugary malts, figs, and a little wood.

The flavor is sweet caramel malts, some dark fruits, earthy yeast and some spices with a light grassy bitterness at the finish.  The alcohol is present at the finish, but not overdone.  The mouthfeel is medium to full with soft carbonation.

Overall, a nice dessert type beer.

11.2 oz bottle.  Murky chestnut with a light but holding tan froth.  Toffee, cinnamon and cloves with a touch of alcohol.  Taste is more grapey than the regular version and thinner without the same creaminess.  Woody currants, figs and candied orange peel.  Clean finish.  I was surprised how much this differed from the non-ø.

11.2 oz, 2006 bottle.  Foamed when uncapped.  Pours a deep garnet with a fizzy disappearing head.  Nose is very fruity, all types of berries and banana, mild spiciness.  Cinnamon, nutmeg, dark sugars on the palate, a little thin and flat but nice and silky; finishes with a spicy yeast that lingers.  Quite nice

2006 bottle.  Really nice malty aroma, sweet with overly ripe fruits and a bit of candy sugar and sour cherry.  Caramel and raisin and a bit of christmas cake, and more apparent alcohol than the original version.  Pours a near-opaque red-brown with a scant beige head.  Taste is rich and sweet but never cloying, lightly bitter and faintly sour, more to round off than anything.  Medium, quaffable body (but who would want to?) with notes of an herbal, slightly medicinal brown sugar, and tea-ish leaf extract.  Spruce?  Would be excellent in candy block form.  Smooth, densely malty feel, aftertaste is dry and slightly herbal with a flash of something reminiscent of juniper.  Spicing is, on the whole, very subtle and refined.  In contradistinction to the original waft (and even in the main whiff it had diminished), the alcohol is nowhere to be found in the mouth - perfect integration!  Stylish and classy, but not up to the standard set by the original - what exactly is the difference in Danish taste thats being brewed to?

Yet another bottle shared by puzzl (uberthanks!).  Poured dark brown with no head at all, which was quite striking compared to its Belgian counterpart.  Aroma was incredibly sweet, full of sugar and dark fruits.  Taste was full of caramel and spice, though I wished there was more for me to pick out.  Pretty sticky mouthfeel and finished sweet and spicy.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2007 An odd, tart, minerally aroma, full and rich with maple and pomegranate. No head on the pour, interesting next to the enormous head of normal pannepot. Purple grape and thick, sweet flavor, ending with a tingly bitter fruit note. Tasty stuff. 

Compared to normal pannepot, not near as sweet, and definitely has a hop note which is not noticed in the regular. A bitter, kind of drying aftertaste and aroma. Not as refined, but sitll very enjoyable.

Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense

Comments: I presume the most helpful rating is a comparison with the regular version. This felt, if possible, perhaps even sweeter, in a juicy way, perhaps an impression caused by the lesser presence of darker malts, toasty and bordering roasty which have a balancing effect in Pannepot. It also feels less long and dries out quicker. Excellent, but not the decadent treat it seems.

Bottle 2006 sampled 11/16/07.
Opens with a lot of CO2. No gushing. The pour is a challenge with all of the CO2. Huge lasting white frothy head. The aroma is huge caramel backed by vinous sherry notes, dark fruits, and barnyard character. A rich lush body that is made more drinkable by the high level of CO2. The flavors are instantly sweet caramelized malt and dark cabernet. The wild yeast characters of the beer make the vinous character come out in full force. The finish is sweet and satisfying with a ever so light dryness once the fluid has left the mouth. A great Belgian dark ale.

Bottle - 2006 vintage.  Dingy brown pour with a smallish head and a strange ammount of carbonation clinging to the side of the glass.  Aromas are wonderful.  Dark fruit (especially fig), brown and candi sugar.  Flavors are not as complex or heavy as Pannepot, but this is very nice.  The sweetness is there as well as the dates and fig flavors with a touch of alcoholic warmth and some spices that linger a little.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: fruit, yeasty, spice aroma. Murky brown, with nice head. Sweet sipping beer. Burnt fruit, candy. Alcohol, dry finish, slight bitterness. Enjoyable to try, but not really my bag.

(Thanks to radiomgb.)  330 mL bottle from 2006.  Its translucent ruby/orange/brown, if thats possible, with little head.  The aroma is sweet, with dried candied fruit and candi sugar being prominent, and there is the slight aroma of alcohol.  The taste is much the same, although it does not seem out of balance.  You can detect dark honey, sweet fruit, spice, and a slight alcohol burn, with a little bitterness in the finish.  The body is very full.  Sweet, but a very good beer.

Bottle served quite warm (maybe 100 minutes out of the fridge) but not quite room temperature.

I opened this one to celebrate the birth of my   first niece earlier this evening. Its exceptional. The pour is dark, dark brown with a modestly-sized rather coarse and sudsy head. (Despite the inelegant description, it was very pretty and almost deserves a 5 for appearance.) Aroma has a lot going on: molassas and nutmeg, apple and raisin. Theres even more going on in the flavor, to the point that it almost seems to be a hodgepodge at first sip - though as one enjoys instead of analyzing it leaves little to be desired.  Caramel apple with hints of sour oak, chocolate-covered toffee, again the nutmeg and mulling spice, dried plums. Hops are way in the background. The mouthfeel is exceptionally creamy, again nearly cloying at the first sip but mellowing as one goes forward to this exceptionally creamy milkshake showing exactly no hint of the 10% in heat, only in density. 

I dont want to analyze; this was a beer to savor and a beer that was hard to drink slowly. Wonderful.

330ml bottle.  Pefectly formed creamy mocha colored head on top of a dark purple and garnet colored body.  Heavy fruit scented yeast esters in the nose: dates, plum, walnut, sweet.  Flavor is similar, amplified by a really pleasent creamy soft palate.  A bit too sweet and spicy (chemicals) up front, and over the middle its more of a artificial candy sweetness, like jolly ranchers.  Ends on a down note, with a lingering coating of this same artificial-like sweetness, but also with a lighter nut and fruit (trail mix?) note.

Bottle: Muddy brown, hues of burnt caramel, moderate to thin off-white head, dies quickly, lacing is sparce. &nbsp Wonderful 

combination of licorice, dark pitted fruits, nutmeg, cinnamon, ginger, and all-spice. &nbsp This smells so good! &nbsp Has a minor pumpkin 

type flair. &nbsp Sweet malts on the tongue, almost candyish in nature. &nbsp Dark pitted fruit, spices, just wonderful. &nbsp Doesnt 

appear to be all that thick, and in fact seems somewhat watery for a Belgian. &nbsp However, the alcohol is very well hidden. &nbsp One of 

the easier 10% beers I have ever drank... wow! &nbsp I do find it odd that it does feel almost thin. &nbsp Carbonation is low. &nbsp Quite 

different from Pannepot. &nbsp Flavorful finish, licorice and dark pitted fruit. &nbsp On the sweeter side, but because its not heavy its 

not cloying at all. &nbsp Similar in flavor profile to Pannepot, but just not there in mouthfeel or body. &nbsp Still delicious tho!

Pours a dark brownish ruby with a medium creamy/bubbly tan head that left lacing.  Aroma of caramel, dark fruits, toffee, Belgian yeast, fruity, a mix of various spices, earthy and a touch of alcohol.  Flavor of nuts, dark fruits, roast, toffee, a mix of spices that are nice but hard to narrow down, earthy, bready and Belgian yeast.  On the dry side which really helps pull this beer together.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is malt, hop, licorice. Flavour is sweet, roasted, caramel, licorice, hop, alcohol, coffee. Very nice beer.

Bottle poured a cloudy dark burnt orange with a minimal amber head. Aromas of carmel, fruittiness and spices. Palate was light bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, toffee, lpum, raisin and spices with a smooth lightly sweet finish.

The 330ml brown bottle gives up its deep murky brown treasure, which produces a tan head that fades rather quickly, leaving a thin covering upon the glass. The aroma of plums and spices stands out amongst the cotton candy sweetness, caramel, and a smattering of bread dough and fusel alcohol, bit of oak like sourness also breaks through, what a treat for the schnozzle. Front is decidedly sweet, grain presence perfect, bit of burnt toast and a hint of bitterness at the back, mouth feel almost full. Finish benign in its acidity, hops light but noticeable, alcohol well disguised, thats scary, very dry, reminds me of the 7 year old Samichlaus I sampled the other day, this brew is a real tummy warmer, and also gets a Whoa Nellie from me.

Bottled. Thanks to ekstedt. 
Dark brown colour, with low pale head. Nutmeg dominates the aroma, not that its too much, its just very prominent. Caramelly sweetness play first violin as always with Pannep.. beers. Better balance here though, not all too sweet with nice touch of spices. Bit of nutmeg in flavour as well, low hoppiness is noted towards finish, ie hoppier than its brothers.

Bottle (33 cl) from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen, Denmark. Cloudy brown with small beige head. Fruity and caramelly aroma with spicy notes of nutmeg and earthy hops. Light to medium bodied with low carbonation. Sweet in the beginning, low bitterness.

Bottle, 33 cl. Dark brown, clear, a minimal head. Full body, creamy and soft carbonation. Aroma of plums and raisins, chocolate and coffee. Long sweet and spiced finish. Hign on alcohol - in the good way :-)

Bottle at Kulminator.  Very dark brown beer with a thick tan head.  Great aroma, dark chocolate, raisin and strong toast/molasses.  Very fruity aroma with some cherry, berries and pineapple.  A bit of leather and soft plummy character.  Seems less sweet and more chocolate/malt accented than the regular pannepot.  Earthy and fruity at the same time.  Soft and malty with loads of cinnamon, nutmeg, and allspice.  Great balance and complexity.  Lovely beer.

Bottle.  Pours a deep brown color with a beige head.  Aroma is coffee with hints of cinnamon, chocolate, and caramel.  Taste is cinnamon up front, dissolving into chocolate, coffee, and slight caramel sweetness right at the tip.  The alcohol is pretty noticeable.  I prefer the original Pannepot (I gave it 5/5 afterall) but this is an excellent, excellent beer as well.
33 cl bottle. Hazy orange color. Big, beige head. Fruity/floral, sweet, malty, yeast, hops. High alcohol is well hidden. Very balanced and nice beer.

Bottle. Brown, quite clear body, with a beige head. The nose starts quite coffee-ish, then theres roasted malt, dried fruits and caramel. The flavor has coffee, roasted malt, caramel and something reminiscent of carrot cake. The body is maybe a bit thin, and quite sticky. Nice one, but I definately prefer Pannepot. (070914)

Pours dark reddish brown with a mostly receding tan head. Aroma of brown sugar, cherry, caramelized wort, cypress. Taste is sweet malt, cherries, winey fruit qualities, pine, vinous chocolate. Mouthfeel is full bodied, with a dry alcohol thiness and lush carbonation. Very delicious.

2006 bottle from tytoanderso; Nose of banana, vanilla, caramel, and dark fruit; clear rusty brown with a medium beige head; flavor sweet brown sugar, caramel, fig newtons, and light spices. Not as complex and spicy as my favorite Pannepot which I had to sample alongside this one. Great but not superb!

draught at Ølbaren, copenhagen. murky amber, medium, lasting head. aroma reminded me of weizenbock - rotting banana, whiteboard markers. quite sweet, some caramel, apple, light spiciness and a touch of sourness. plenty of interesting characteristics but perhaps a little lacking in depth
Dark brown, with a thin head that dissipates quickly.  Rich malty aroma, with a strong alcohol aroma.  Heavy body, with a sweet malt flavor.   Very smooth but, not as complex as marketed.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: dark brown with red highlights.small light brown head that leaves some webbing on the glass.very nice aroma of oatmeal cookies,chocolate,all spice,cinnamon,alcohol,and raisins.the flavor boats what the aroma brought to the table,plus some cocoa,and metal.

Bottle huge thanks to beeranarchist. Against a normal pannepot. Aroma is vanilla, with lorads of raisin candy sugar, dark fruits, vanilla bean. Taste is sweet dark fruits, raisin, slight roasty character. Alround a super complex ale thats very tasty, however not pannepot.

Pours a cloudy chestnut brown color, almost no head.  Aroma is grainy, maple-syrupy sweet, and herbal.  Very little alcohol on the nose.  Palate is medium-bodied.  The taste mostly sweet with the herbal notes coming through on the finish, fighting through the syrup.  A bit of sour on the finish almost.  Seems sweeter and a bit less thicker than the regular Pannepot.

Bottle. Pours hazy dark mahogany with beige head. The aroma is whisky, black cherry, sweet caramel, little bits of clove and anise. The flavor is very fruity right off. Lots of black cherry, plum, white wine, figs. Then some spiciness and bitter chocolate kick in. It gets spicier and woodier toward the finish. It ends with some alcohol, wood, and caramel. This is quite a tasty brew.

Pours a nutty brown with descent cremecolored creamy head.   Nose is big time spice a little dark fruit mixed with a descent aroma of alcohol.  Flavor wise the spice again is dominate.  This beer really reminds me of a great pumkin beer.   Maybe the greatest pumkin beer ever.

Jesus, this NEEDS BRETT!!!!  Fuck, put brett in this beer or I will.  
Taste is slightly sour, caramel, sweet.  Very, very nice. I freaking like this beer.  very thin, watery body, but not overly, just eminently drinkable.  10% no way!  Starts to pick up some heat in aroma as it warms.

Pours a copper color with a tan head.  Aroma is of dark fruit, toffee, and spices.  Flavor is of dark fruits , toffee, spices, yeast, and a decent alcohol warming on the finish.  Pretty impressed with this brew as well as the regular Pannepot.
This is an interesting one. Its a little funky, but not sour in any way. Theres a lot of dried fruits, dates especially. Theres a bit of toasted nuts and a heavy sweetness. Its a little sticky.

Appearance: Pours a hazy, dark brown body with a small, light beige head.

Smell: Sweet-smelling, candied fruit aroma of cherries and figs. Strong notes of treacle. A jigger full of spiced rum.

Taste: Sweet, bready toffee maltiness laced with sugary treacle. The fruits carry over from the scent and join the sweet mixture in a taste like melted lollipops. Soft cinnamon spiciness. Subdued yeast character. Very sweet, candyish finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-full body. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: I enjoyed it. As for you, well, I hope you like your beers sweet.
Hazy brown with medium head. Aroma has toffee, fruits and malt. Sweet malty flavor with overripe fruits ,toffee and a warming alcohol in the end. Not as good as the original.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2008 Pours brown in color with little to no head that is gone after a few moments.
