Smell is very rich, dark fruits and some alcohol as well. There are some raisins making there presence known as well. 
Wow, this is a good beer.  Incredibly complex and smooth.  Theres a bit of sweetness in the taste.  Mouthfeel is medium, but it basically dances in your mouth then runs down your throat.  Perfect amount of carbonation, almost perfect on the mouthfeel.  This is a pure enjoyment to drink.
Hazy brown color with a small milky head and lots of lacing. Aroma of spices, sugar and alcohol. Flavor of spices, sugar and dark fruits. Creamy body and very warming.

Bottle thanks to kleyland; poured a ruddy brownish-red color and not much head.  Aroma of spice, caramel, brown sugar/chocolate, alcohol and dark fruit.  Flavor was really good and complex.  Much of the same flavors as found in the aroma.  The spice presence was done perfectly; not overly spiced at all.  Slightly sweet as well.  Nice, smooth palate.  Very enjoyable.

Bottle, courtesy of Moejuck. Strong aroma of licorice and yeast. Muddy brown pour with a medium beige head. Flavor of spices, licorice and yeast. The body is light to medium with a liquorous texture and gentle carbonation. Very good, but the yeast is a lot more present than in the regular version where the spices and licorice had more room to express themselves.

2006 bottle.  Pours a rusty amber color with a medium beige head.  Aroma of figs, banana, plums, prunes and nutmeg.  Taste is slightly spicy with hints of nutmeg, figs, prunes, plums, candied malts and yeast.  A lighter less sweeter and less spicier version  than the original Pannepot.  Excellent !!

2006 Bottle. Gusher!!!


Deep brown body with a nice head. Aroma is of plums, figs, dried fruit, oat bread, salami. Taste is really subtle and smooth with all the taste of the other Pannepot just with out all the spice. The plum, dried fruit really add a very gentle like flavor and a smooth creamy mouthfeel make this so incredibly easy to drink.I honestly can not taste any alcohol, thats how smooth it is. I can see how others may feel a little let down compared to the other version, but this one is well crafted!

courtesy of fiulijn - pours a hazy ruby-brown colour under an elusive beige foam; malty, woody and spicy (nutmeg) aroma with notes of dried fruits; full-bodied, very sweet and slightly sticky, a decent bitterness but not enough to balance the high sweetness; long sweetish and malty finish with more dried fruits notes lingering

Thanks to Papsoe for this great beer (via Kaggie97/Zinister trade). Very nice brown beige color with good head. My favorite aroma...very dark fruits, beligan yeast, malts, candied sugar....yummy. Taste is very medium bodied creamy with all the above and a touch of bitter coffee ends. Love it.

It poors a nice beige head and the beer is dark brown. The aroma is of figs, prunes, candis, malt and a bit of alcohol. The flavor has prunes, alkohol, malt, candis and a bit of coffee too. The palate is creamy and good lasting.

I must admit I was very disapointed - I had just taste the Pannepot oaked version and this was not good compared to that. Not nearly as complex and well-balanced!

Thin, tan head around the sides of the glass only.  Nice aroma - roasted sweet potatoes comes to mind.  Heavy, wintery fruits are also there.  Very full flavored, filled with raisins and plums and prunes.    The higher alcohol is very well hidden.  It is very thick and meaty.  Great mouthfeel.  I quite like this beer.

Hazy burgundy pour, with a small but lasting off-white lace - the aroma is a bit like a subdued version of the "regular" pannepot - some earthy, fruit skin tartness in the foreground, with a lot of wintery spices, chocolate, figs and plums far in the background - dubbel-ish musty tart flavors up front - some plum and black cherry, with a moderate caramel sweetness quickly afterwards - a strong alcohol warmth quickly develops, and lasts far through the finish - this warmth compliments the subtle spice notes - not nearly as sweet or heavy as pannepot, which is what sets this beer apart the most - not exactly pannepot light - think of it as a companion beer for warmer days, and a darn tasty one at that.

Pours a cloudy rusty red-brown color with an offwhite beige head.  Slightly lighter than regular Pannepot, with slightly less head.  In comparison to the regular beer, this has less licorice spice in the aroma, with a more pronounced toffee, pears and plums.  Not as much chocolate, but theres something reminiscent of oatmeal cookies.  Taste is tangier with lots of toffee, nuts and caramel, with spicy fruity plum notes.  Finishes at first with pears, followed by a rich hazelnut coffee flavor.  I felt that this beer was smoother and creamier than the original but not quite as "dark" in flavor.  Just as good as regular Pannepot.

11.2 ounce bottle in Gulden Draak Tulip.  Dark reddish-brown black with enormous (too big) rocky brown head and lace.  Aroma of anise/licorice, roasted chocolate and more spice.  Smooth creamy chocolate raisiny flavor with mellow spicy finish.  Medium-full bodied medium-low carbonation.  Deserving of the hype; this is an awesome beer.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2007 Milk chocolate brown color, spicy/hoppy/malty nose, sweet toffee/raisin flavor, somewhat heavy cloying finish that shows off the alcohol well when warm.  Really damn good beer that tends to leave you wanting more.

(12oz bottle) Sampled at the Post-Great Canadian Beer Festival 2007 in Victoria on September 8th, 2007. Courtesy of Oakes. Mahogany brown and dissipated white head. Nose of burnt brown sugar. Very sweet with a lasting smooth malt finish. Very good.

Brown colour with a Tan head. A somewhat complex aroma of raisin hops and malt hits the nose as soon as I poured. The taste is sweet with oak, raisin, maltyness, licorise and a bit of alcohol. The body is a bit cloring but full, creamy and very delicious.

bottle: pours a chocolate brown with a small tan head. aroma of spices rich caramel malts and sweet dried fruits. flavour is very spicey with dark fruits and smooth rich malts. finishes very well with some more spice.very enjoyable and easy drinking. there is also a taste of candy sugar.

Thanks go to tytoanderso for the bonus bottle. Pours hazy orange/brown with a medium head. Aroma of dark fruit, brown sugar and a bit of yeast.  Yeast comes out heavier in the taste, with the raisins, brown sugar and a little bit of peppery spices. Alcohol is fairly well covered. Very good brew. Not as good as pannepot.

Slightly hazy brown.  Aroma of brown sguar, dates and light caramel.  Sweet, with hints of date, raisin, chewy malts, dark fruit and chocolate.  Not as rich nor stylish as the regular, but quality brew.

2006.  murky brown with a small film head.  large bubbles stay on the sides of the glass.  fruity, estery aroma with notes of caramel.    flavor has notes of bready malts, plenty of dark fruits(blackberry, plum), a little caramel, and maybe a touch of vanilla.  dry.  full bodied.  lightly sour.

Pours a deep brown body with a dinkus tan head that vanishes rapidly.  Its got a fruity aroma - dark berries, prunes, dark cherries - along with burnt malt and a touch of caramel.  Kind of flat.  Sweet tasting, fruity still, with that ever present burnt flavor.  Mayhaps a splash of coffee here, too.  Throughout the strong alcohol content remains well hidden.  Not bad.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Lakeview Liquors, Chicago, IL<font size=-1>

Bottle shared at CapFlus tasting after GCBF. Cloudy copper with a warm head. Alcohol and toffee. Very sweet. Hints of coffee and peat. I did not get the salt water or licorice I tasted in Pannepot. Not blown away by either.

Rated "blind" back to back with Pannepot. Both were 2006. Comparitively, this (the first drank) had much less of a head, but both had similar body and neither seemed overly carbonated. Chewy mouthfeel, I taste a bit more fruit and less of the spice of the other, with alcoholic sweetness a but more evident in this version.

bottle - Pours a crystal clear deep ruby red color with smallish light tan head that quickly dissapears. Aroma is loaded with sweet caramel, dark cherries, bit of ash, blackberries, vanilla, cream. Flavor is fairly sweet, bit of caramel, vanilla, cherries, faint tartness, with a mildly sweet finish. A very nice brew overall.
Brown, with a tan head. Aroma is sweet malt, dark fruit, and a bit of spices. Flavor is spices, malt, dark fruit, alcohol and some banana. Medium body. Good, but not as good as the regular Pannepot.
Bottle from Capones. Pours amber\brown with sweet aroma of maybe plum. Malty flavor with fruit. It is smooth but not as good as regular pannepot.

Fairly thick mahogany pour with a glassy orange edge.  Still and silent.  Let to sit a very long while, producing only a quiet aroma of green apples with cinnamon and sugar.  A thin mist of farmhouse stink, and a touch of strawberry.  Tastes dry with dense sweetness.  Tart blueberries, bakers chocolate, temporanillo, and banana.  Subtle brown spice.  Not especially challenging.  Fruit character leaves a bit of a thin impression, and a bit of sprucy bitterness stumbles in.  A small seed of oxidation blossoms slowly in the finish, which is long and degenerative.  The cardboard smack has a coating of dark, mildly alcoholic sweetness.  Smooth.  Solid.  Thanks, Lou!

Very fizzy out of the bottle, pours brown with foamy head.  Malty, fruity to smell with aromas of pepper, chocolate, figs and dried fruit.  The flavors are similar to the smell only a little more rounded and pronounced.  There is a drying, spiced finish which has a good amount of carbonation.  This brew has a nice balanced flavor, and a good texture, while disguising the high alcohol content well.  Nice beer.
Brown, no head.  Caramel, with brown sugar, spice, and light alcohol in the aroma.  Taste is a distinct spiciness, dust, grapes, light alcohol, caramel, seems a little oxidized.

Pours a nice slightly cloudy auburnish brown, with a nice tan head.  Super spicy nose and sweet malt with a hintof ripe fruit and pear.  Very sweet , but not as much of a depth or complexity of the regular pannepot.  Nice, but not as nice as the original.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text:
330ml bottle (Pikkulintu, Helsinki)
Dark brown. Sweet alcoholic aroma. Full-bodied sweet malty taste in the mouth, but too alcoholic and unsubtle.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2008 Courtesy of Mgumby.    I had wanted to try this beer for quite some time.  Pours a deep brown color, with glints of burnt orange around the edges.  Aroma is very fruity with a tea -like undertone that I find very enticing, similar to a jasmine or even an oolong tea.  The flavor, while excellent, just fails to live up to the hype.  Not as much going on as the original, much less complex.    I like the beer, but still prefer the "regular" Pannepot to any of the other versions.

11.2oz bottle.  2006 bottle. Aroma:  Bready malt, yeast, raisins and bananas, toffee, pumpkin pie spice, alcohol.  Some light chocolate as it warms.  Appearance:  Dark red/brown in color.  Light ivory head was full and creamy/foamy with great retention.  Beautiful lacing.  Flavor:  Bready malt, caramel and toffee, yeast.  Raisins, cherries, and bananas. Coriander and cinnamon.  Light chocolate.  A slight sourness throughout.  Alcohol is present throughout, but not hot or unpleasant.  Sweetish finish with some caramel and fruit carrying over.  Palate:  Medium-full bodied.  Moderate carbonation.  Nice alcohol warming over entire mouth.  Overall:  Regulat Pannepot is my #2 ranked beer, so I was excited to try this.   Great beer, but just didnt seem to have the depth or complexity as the regular version.  Still, this is an exceptional beer.

Bottle. Dark mahogony brown with a very little light brown head. Spiced, plum.fig rich malty aroma. Fruity (berry, raisin, fig) flavor with malt and some nice backing spicy yeast. Lingering fruit and spice with a bit of earth. Medium body. Alcohol present if searching, but well integrated and in background.

11.2 oz bottle. Fairly clear dark brown color with red highlights and a small creamy tan head. Fruity, yeasty aroma with notes of brown sugar, coriander and fresh baked bread. Mildly sweet malty flavor with some cinnamon, coriander, molasses, pumpernickel bread and a warming alcohol finish. Not nearly as sweet as the Belgian version I sampled a while back, but also a bit less complex in its lavor. Nice creamy texture.
Brown of color with a off-white head.  A spicy aroma with notes of cinnamon, cloves and caramel. A flavor with sugar, spice, alcohol, dark fruits and tobacco.

Pours a dark brown color with a small  white head.  Compared to Pannepot, the head is almost non-existant.  Aroma is sweet, slightly spiced, reminiscent of a cola.  Great body, laced with cherries and sweet milk chocolate, like a silky dessert.  Sweeter than Pannepot, and a touch less complex.  The aroma is less aggressive, as well as the variety of tastes.  Still, a great find.

Name: Pannepot Old Fishermans Ale - Danish Version
Date: 03/12/2007
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting

hazy dark brown, 
lots of rich fruity spiced aroma and a touch of sweetness, 
big rich fruity malt flavor, lots of dark fruits, spicy esters add nice balance, light hint of alcohol, rich chocolate to balance and complement the fruit
-------- />
Name: Pannepot Old Fishermans Ale - Danish Version
Date: 07/22/2007
Mode: bottle
Source: roadtrip
Vintage: 2006

clear dark brown, wispy beige head, 
rich dark fruit aroma with hint of plums and raisons and only the slightest sweetness, 
lots of ripe fruit flavor on a solid milk chocolate base, just enough sweetness to bring out the fruits, a touch of alcohol and spices add complexity
the danish version is more of a dark Belgian with the fruity esters vs the american version that is a rich chocolate porter, is the yeast the difference?

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 16/20
Rating: 3.9/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: **4

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy deep brown/amber with a small light tan ring of a head that leaves little lacing. Aroma of cherries, caramel, spices, and rum raisin. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium full mouthfeel with a mild amount of bitterness and well hidden alcohol. Very good.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Purchased from Beverage Castle in Tampa. I adore the Pannepot, now its time to try the Pannepøt. Is the difference in these two brews just a little line through a circle? Nope, this is a very unique beer from its cousin. Pours thick, cocoa colored. Creamy head, and a fair amount of lacing. Aroma, like the Pannepot, is very fruity and spicy. But unlike the Pannepot, I get some chocolate notes, and pomegranate, too. Same with flavor: more chocolate and "sweet" taste to it than the Pannepot. Brown sugar, caramel, chocolate, cinnamon. A rich beer, but smooth and gentle. I could drink a lot of these.

An excellent beer.  Dark brown, thick and heavy like the others.  Like a first rate Trappist Abbot Ale.  The spices are there still.  Aroma has lots of malt, a hint of brown sugar, a little fruit.  Great, sweet flavor that is reminiscent of the regular version, but sweet as it is, it is not as sweet and sticky as Pannepot.  Lots of sediment in the bottle, it has a grittiness that I really enjoy.  I look forward to giving it a try with some age.  I feel really lucky that a beer brewed for the Danish market is available in Minnesota.

[Bottle] Pours red with a light tan head.  Aroma is banana and very spicy (cardamom I think) sweet.  The taste is similar to the aroma with a hint of alcohol in it.  Smooth with a very long, somewhat dry finish.  Medium mouthfeel.  A well done beer, but not quite as good as I remember regular Pannepot or Reserva as being.

(bottle, thanks Olso2116) Pours a dark amber with a light tan head.  Nose is very fruity with banana, some peach, as well as some brown sugar.  There are also some hints of spice too.  Flavor is caramel initially which then yields to a very dry finish, similar to a dry white wine, with a little bit of a yeasty flavor.  Not as fruity as I remember the regular Pannepot being, but good nonetheless.

That beautiful brown color Ive come to expect from the Struisse Pannepot line.  Sweet malt and spice in the body.  Excellent molasses taste.  The cardamom nose really opened up as I drank.  Smooth finish.

Akevitt, you beautiful bastard.  Thank you for sharing!  Brown color with a thin head.  Sweet malt and spiced aroma with cardamom the standout.  More sweet and velvety malt flavor, slightly salty and actually a bit of sourness towards the close.  Maybe some oakiness as well.  I think this version is a little less spiced and fruity than the "normal", but it seems more balanced and velvety than the Reserva.  In any case, all three are incredible.  God bless these brewers!

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2007 2006 Bottle, Sampled August 2007
Pours with a mix of tightly beaded froth topped by larger bubble bath sized foam, both which add up to an initially three finger thick, creamed amber color; the head leaves a touch of lacing on the sides of the glass as I work my way through this beer.  The beer is a drab mix of dark amber and brown notes, but shows a beautiful, brilliantly clear, ruby-red color when held up to the light.  The aroma is an interesting, rich-leaning, mix of earthy spices, rich-concentrated fruits and dusty darker malt notes.  Aromas of prunes, figs apricots, caramelized apples, hints of cherries and fresh cut sweet / tart plums make up the concentrated fruit portion of the aroma.  These notes are boosted by malt notes of caramelized grain, brown sugar, and sugar glazed, browned bread crust.  The earthy spice notes add a subtle balancing note with touches of allspice, clove, cardamom, fenugreek .  Hints of warming alcohol towards the end mix with the fruitiness to sort of give this a brandy-like edge.  Really the fruit character (which strangely was the third thing I noticed after the spice notes and malt) is the dominant note in the aroma.

Rich enough to coat the mouth with a little bit of stickiness.  The alcohol and some spice-like notes cling to the palate adding a spicy, slightly astringent almost woody note that lingers on in the mouth after the beer has passed down my throat.  This beer is definitely sweet, but there is so much going on here that I am always distracted by other flavors and sensations before I think too long on the sweetness.  There is that woodiness that I mentioned (definitely noticeable & distinct to my palate, though somewhat subtle) and this pairs with a really subtle not that is almost peat like (a mix of salt, umami and smoke).  Soft spice notes of cardamom, nutmeg, sassafras, birch, perhaps a touch of licorice and a bit of pepper in the finish are all noticeable at times, but all are soft enough to actually keep me guessing at what might be the spices & what is from the fermentation character; this is of course the sign of a beer that has been spiced properly, as I dont want to be hit over the head by spices in a beer, but instead want them to add a nice, yet subtle backdrop that always keeps one guessing.  I definitely like how this beer feels so rich, but does not become cloying or sticky.

I am not sure of the difference between Pannepot and Pannepøt, but they are certainly different.  This beer seems to be a touch sweeter, and not nearly as aromatically fruity as Pannepot.  Ill definitely have to do a side by side of these two to explore them a bit more in depth.  As the beer warms up it loses a touch of sweetness, yet strangely notes of brown sugar and even molasses become evident.  Still that woody, almost peat like, spiciness is quite noticeable and it starts to mix in with a touch of warming alcohol towards the finish.  Definitely another really tasty offering from the Struis Brouwers.  I cant wait to crack my bottle of Aardmonnik!

Bottle. Pours a rich, thick brown with deep amber highlights. Aroma of dark fruits, brown sugar, molasses, toffee, loads of spices and some alcohol. Wonderful dessert beer presence on the tongue: sweet, sticky caramel, some spices, gingerbread... This ones fairly complex and it hides the alcohol quite well. Fairly rich and chewy mouthfeel. Finishes with a hint of hops and some nice spice notes.
Not as complex as the Pannepot but very close. Pours dark brown with off white head. Aroma of fruit and spice. Nice fruit flavor with a spice finish.
I purchased two bottles of this from liquidsolutions.com. I enjoyed sharing this one with fordest and toncatcher while playing poker.

Bottle from Capones.  Turbid burny umber pour with 1-finger off-white head.  There were ruby notes through direct light with this, and the lace remained forever.  The aroma was a pinnacle of olfactory delights, featuring brown sugary figs, cherry, caramelly malt, spices, berries, chocolate, and gingerbread.  The palate was rich, complex as hell, very unique with all the berries and figgy fruits floating around all over the taste buds, plus some brown sugary spices and dark chocolate notes.  This one was excellent.

(33cl bottle) Small beige head atop cola-brown body.  Aroma is sweet, raisin, sherry, some anise, caramel, light fusel.  Taste is sweet, raisin, caramel, vinous/bourbon, some fruit cake, light burnt, anise.  Sticky full body.  Alcohol quite noticeable, yet pleasant.  Seems like a poster child for the concept of dessert beer.

Thanks to slob.  Pours dark brown, thick and murky.  The head is small but the lacing is sticky.  Aroma is assertive and assualtive on the nose.  Sweet dark bread and raisons, sweet candi sugar, but a strong spiking alcohol and overly sweet aspect as well.  Taste is just off-balanced with the right pieces of sweetness, breadiness but in the wrong proportion.  Ends of too sweet with too thin of a body, with the subdued carbonation not helping out this imbalance.  Some heat on the back of the throat and a sweet-alcohol aftertaste. This just ends up as the little brother to the amazing regular Pannepot.  11.2oz bottle, De Ranke thinned and stretched goblet glass.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Thanks to akevitt for sharing.  Bottle, pours a deep red-brown with light brown head.  Sweet aroma that is slightly fruity and spicy.  Smooth, medium body with a light belgian ale taste.  Has a nice malty taste with a sweet aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours an amber-copper body with a small white head. The aroma is fruity with roast caramel and sweet cereal. Fullish malts with fruit, toffee, chocolate, and caramel notes. Well balanced, well developed complexity. Never sugary or alcoholic.

Sampled from 12-oz bottle at Cellars Wine & Spirits in St Paul, MN. Pours a dark brownish amber brew with a fast dissolving off-white head that laves behind a ring and some lacing. Aroma of dried dark fuits, caramel malt, spice and a touch of apples. Taste is medium bodied, lightly carbonated, smooth and creamy with flavors of caramel malt, sweet apples and dry spices. Finish is slightly bitter with a dry fruity aftertaste.
Seems a bit thinner than the regular Pannepot.  Aroma is fruit and caramel with iron and minerals.  Nice, but not great.

Respectable dark brown color with a very short lived white head.  Flavor is somewhat sweet from the malt with a hint of brandied cherries and a somewhat bitter finish.  Certainly a nice beer but not in the same league as its counterpart.

Bottle from Cracked Kettle. Dark brown colour. Sour nose. Fruits, tight lacing, quite sour at the end too. Caramel and sweet bread flavours. A big bottle and the alcohol content is barely noticeable (but there nonetheless.)

330ml bottle thanks to Padrefan98.  I was very excited to try the best-beer-in-the-worlds little sister.  And I wasnt disappointed.   Sweet aromas off the brown and ruby beer with a great head.  Some cherry and some dried fruit.  More of the same on the flavor.  Chocolate comes through as well.  Wonderful.

Small white head, good retention that leaves a very nice lace behind. Deep amber colored brew with a ruby glow. Nose is gently spicey with faint cinnamon, dark fruits, earthiness and a hint of licorice. Med/full bodied with a tight carbonation. Dark fruity flavors, raisin a hint plummy, medium sweet malts, caramrelly, spices not as evident in the flavor, along with some cola notes as it warms up. Near dry, fruity finish. Alcohol is well hidden. Bottle procured @ Statelineliquors. Thanks Robert!
Bottle sampled. Pours orang/brown with a fluffy beige head. Aroma of fruit, caramel, spices, and yeast. The flavor is sweet, smooth for 10%, fruit, spices, caramel, and dough. Good brew.
Bottle. Almoust black body. The head is offwhite and lasting. Aroma is complex. Fruity, sweet, malty, peppry and raisins. Flavor brings dark fruits, sweetnes, coffe and raisin.
Flaske. Dameversionen af Pannepot ;) Mere rød i farven og med en mere afdæmpet smag. Men meget lækkert.
Beer night with Dedollewaitor. Malty, breadsy nose is a whirl of caramel, Medium body thats bitter, sweet, and a bit spicy.

Pours a dark chocolatey brown color w/ a rather shy froth. Head retention is fair and reduces to a fine silky canopy w/ a thin lace. Aroma is weak w/ mild, sweet malts and some spice. Full nectar w/ minimal, soft and creamy effers. A fat malty backbone supports a complex array of flavors from dried fruits to sweet cakebread and molases. The sweetness factor is better than moderate and possesses a mild acidity felt around the lips. Nuances of peach, pear, banana, kiwi, plum, cherry, raisins,  w/ slight melon and cocoa. Its slightly spiced w/ licorce and holiday spice. The finish is long and sweet w/ a decent peach pit bittering component. Leaves an acidic tingle on the palate. Overall: sweet w/ a complex flavor profile but not balanced at all.
Dark brown with an off white head. Slight roast, fruits (figs & raisin) Complex. Warmth - nutmeg & liquirice. Long finish.... Fan-tas-tic!

2006 bottle and side by side tasting with Pannepot.  Pour is a dark reddish brown with a small quickly diminishing tan head.  Aroma is dryer and more dark fruit than Pannepot.  Chocolate and spice in the nose.  The aroma had a definite difference, but the flavor are more similar.  Again this beer has more dried fruit and a slight taste of funk that is not in Pannepot.  Chocolate, plum, caramel, and a little breadiness.  Very good, but as most people are saying Pannepot is slightly better.

Courtesy mgumby10. Hazy multi brown. Small dense tan cap. Similar aroma to Pannepot, less roasty and chocolatey more herbal, floral, and spicy. Brown version of Pannepot- less roast and chocolate, added brown sugar and caramel with a boost in the herbs. Full body, soft, smooth. Easy to drink. Solid.

Pours a caramel brown with a small light tan head.  Smells of sweet fruits, with dark malts and caramel.  Definitely fruitier than the normal Pannepot.  The flavor isnt as sweet and fruity, but its definitely there.  It doesnt taste too far off from the regular version.  i was expecting more fruit.  Definitely spicy and malty.  the caramel was quite evident and it was sweet on the palate and the finish.  I got some fruitiness in the aftertaste.  Maybe not quite as good as the original, but still very good.

Pours a very dark brown that allows very little light through.  A large head dissapates quickly and leaves no lacing.  The aroma is chock full of Belgian candi sugar plums, and raisins.  The flavor is muddled.  While there are notes of dark chocolate, apple, grape, and a bready chewiness.  None of the flavors are distinct, however.  It seems more like a mashup of some tasty stuff.  The true saving grace of this beer is the mouthfeel.  Silky smooth and no bite whatsoever despite the 10% ABV.  Overall this is a beer that could be so, so good, but just isnt that far above average.

Very dark mahogany pour and a very thin layer of foam that stays. Aroma of candi sugar, mollasses and dark fruits with a hint of chocolate. Taste is dark fruits, caramel sweetness, candi sugar, brown sugar, mollasses, floral hops. Bready notes in the background lead to a cloying fruity sweetness. Some chocolate notes in there as well as it warms with more fruits coming out and floral notes. Great mouthfeel and with little head the carbonation is actually very good. A very well made beer a lot like St. B 12. I dont know why but I just love the flavor and being so complex is very hard to describe.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2007 Bottle at stateline courtesy of Robert! Color was muddy reddish light brown, decent head and retention. The aroma was light chocolate and dark fruits, citrus, not many spices picked up. The flavor was grapey chocolate and molasses, some dark fruits, smooth bready yeast type finish with each sip, enjoyable, yet with not nearly the same depth as the regular Pannepot. With 10% alcohol, why not crank up the flavors more, is this really that much more drinkable? (Will do them both side by side before too long). The mouthfeel was light, creamy, finishing with a light yeasty bite. Thanks, Robert. Re-rate, 9/07 w/ bfeld, very much the same experience, a little more nuttiness mixed in there.

This bottled brew from a rating party at Dark Lord Day from Mike Sprinkle poured an extremely large sized head of all foam brown colored bubbles that were long lasting and left behind a opaque typically carbonated light brown colored body. The aroma was brown malt dark malt and mild vinous. . The flavor contained notes of vinous dark malt and brown malt. A wonderful best in class brew.

2006 Bottle from Rivers Bend. Poured reddish/brown color with an average light brown head that lasted with good lacing. Complex  dark fruit, citrus, caramel and alcohol aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture. Full complex sweet flavor with solid fruity sweet finish and a small bite of alcohol. Good standout brew.

The only way I can describe this is if you had the other Pannepot, this would be Pannepot Light. Coffee, molases, fruit, toffee, silght chocolate on the nose. Fruit, toffee, chocolate, sweet malt, carmel, and molases on the palate. Finish is light, but lingers. Very good.

Bottle. I prefered this to the Pannepot because there wasn´n t the same heavy licorice taste. Dark brown with little head. Aroma bubblegum, fruit, cheeries, brown sugar. Taste sweet malty with a hnit of licorice in the background but not dominating.

DARK brown, dense pour with a massive tan, cloud-like head.  This beer is beautiful to look at, possibly the perfect looking beer.  Aroma of cranberries, nutmeg, roasted malt, cherries and brown sugar.  Creamy mouth feel that has flavors of sweet malt and a balanced fruitiness to it.  Thought I picked up on some fig in there as well.  Finishes with a slight burn.  Very pleasant.

33 cL bottle. Pours deep dark brown with a small bronw head leaving a nice lacing. Sweet and yeasty aroma with dark chocolate and caramel malt notes. Sweet dried fruit flavour with a soft caramel malt base. Over much more soft than pannepot.

Available at the PIB 2007. Im finding the Danish and American version hard to compare because this beer really changes character a ton as it ages, gaining a big fruity spice character. The more sweet oaked flavors step aside to make way for a more Anchor OSA-like beer, focusing on a warm spiced beer flavor. The Danish version was a much newer bottle so it wasnt a spice monster yet, still young in its life it shined with a nice oaked sweetness, caramel, cherry, and licorice finish.
Lazy head in a ruby/copperred appearence with notes of "barley", oak, dry fruits, sherry, yeast, alcohol and stickyness. A nice and welldone pøt.

Near black colored, medium sized beige head. Licorice dominates in aroma, alcohol almost too much present. Even some syrupy and vinous-berry tones there. Medium to full bodied. Flavor is also strongly licoricy with sweet touch, some oaky tones come up. Aftertaste is warm with obvious alcohol, still not as much alcohol as in aroma.
[2006 bottle] Dark brown with a large but not lasting head. Sweet aroma of red berries and liquorice. Sweet, warming, spicy (anise, liquorice) flavour with a light touch of smoke.

Bottle version 2006 "Old Monks Ale". Pours a clear deep brown colour (the first pour at least) with a very lively fizzy small light brown head. Lovely sweet woody caramel spiced alco dark fruity aroma. Nice soft yet well filling mouthfeel. The flavour is really great, surprisingly soft roasty maltiness and caramel with good dark fruits like prunes, raisins and plums along with spices, some oakiness, slight liquorice and well hidden but alcohol. Long lasting dry bitterish-sweet soft roasty finish. Perfect! ...Second pour.....hazy brown indeed with a good a mount of yeast...even more profound flavour with the spices really sticking to the tongue. Such a good tasty brew.

2006 bottle, tasted July 2007. Unclear dark brown with a red hue. Firm off-white head. Very unique aroma, unlike anything from other brewers. Notes of cherry, anise, licorice, nutmeg, ginger, bisquit and even a hint of bourbon. Its the strong cherry/anise combo that sets it apart.
Flavour is sweet and dominated by spices, anise in particular, with a malty aftertaste. Hops are discrete, and alcohol is well hidden. The velvet mouthfeel is perfectly carbonated to just prick the mouth gently.
Compared to Pannepot (and I did just that in one tasting), the anise is too dominating here.

poured into tall tulip.  sweet yeastie aroma, and taste, nuttiness comes thru to a sweet finish, darn good stuff, very carbonated, starte pouring out the freshly popped bottle, oh what a mouthwatering memory, give me more.
Bottled (2006 vintage). Deep amber colour, mediumsized beige head. Aroma is gingerbread mainly. Flavour is the same along with some yeast, licorace, alcohol and caramelmalts. Pleasant!

Bottles thanks to tever and sk8viking!  Poured a deep, murky brown with delicate rising bubbles and a 1/2" creamy beige head that stuck around perfectly while I took a shower.  Aroma took a sweet and seductive approach with spicy plums and raisins followed by waves of dusty yeast and dried caramel... tails off a bit after the initial impression.  The flavor begins with caramel and slightly burnt raisins and is followed by strong peppery spices and dusty yeast.. mild bitter herbal hops as accents.. warm, spicy finish.  Warm and enjoyable on the palate, but never established a solid flow.. syrupy and heavier-bodied at first, with a jerky transition to the spicy and bitter back-end.  Certainly a solid brew.
Bottle. Chestnut color with an off white head. Light malty and burnt caramel aroma. Sweet full body with spices, nuts, burnt caramel and light raisin. Hoppy light dry aroma. Good one.

Bottled 75 cl (2006)
Thanks sayravai, very dark nut brown color, creamy cappucino head. Nose is not so strong, but I can trace tar, licorice and coffee. Smooth mouthfeel. Quite sweet, even syrapy - sweeter than "normal" Pannepot. Some licorice, dark fruits and candy sugar. A bit same than with Pannepot - way too sweet to be really on top.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2007 (Bottled, 0.33l) Murky dark brown with a medium, creamy, tight, tanned and lasting head. Very sweet-malty, nutty aroma with dried fruit. Sweet and grainy-malty, slightly rye-puddingy flavor with mild spiciness, some yeast and a faint hint of tartness. Medium-bodied, quite low-carbonated, smooth palate. A pleasant and malty, but too sweet brew for its kind.
(Bottled, 0.75l) Lost my rating due to error with my browser. Oh well... what I was about to say was, that this was not quite what I expected: pretty sweet and sourish, with even some alcohol present - especially in the aroma. Not on par with the ratings, but of course it may have been a bad bottle, too.

Chestnut colour with a foamy tan head. Fruity, light tart and yeasty aroma with some caramel sweetness and hints of nuts. Chocolate and alcohol sweet flavor with fruity and yeasty notes. Dry, fruity finish with a dusty edge.

Bottle. Like the other Pannepot products this is a beer with relatively high light brown  creamy head and black boty. Coffee and caramel is dominating but again this is a complex mix of fruits and spices. Still round and pleasant. High alcohold percentage suite the beer in an almost perfect manner.

Hazy brown beer with soft carbonation and with a great creamy beige foam. Aroma is very Trappist like, Bread, soft sugar, soft spices, nuts, sweet sherry, dried figgs, caramel malts and soft hops. Very different than the other pannepot versions. The taste is again very much Trappist like. Soft caramel, malt snuts, some well hidden spices, honey, bread and some interesting hop bitteres to end with. Cellar themperature is ideal to enjoy this great and tastefull beer.

Looks like caramel sauce, with a cloudy caramel orange appearance. Theres probably something in that, because it certainly was sweet with a real sugary taste, sort of.... caramelly. Full flavoured, but not as strong as youd expect from a 10%er. Long lasting and quite satisfying though.
Verry nice and complex beer. Tasted already different versions from 3 different brews. Really a splendid beer

Bottle at Copenhague beerfestival 2007. Pours a brown beer with a lasting creamy head. Some coffee, choco-malt aroma. Very well balanced, sweet and mild bitter at the same time. The maltyness carries the alcohol and so well hidden. Long finish of hops, malts and some alcohol.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2007 From a 750mL Bottle.  Generously shared by Dillon at the 2nd Annual Woodshop Tasting.  Tasted side-by-side with the 2006 Vintage Pannepot.  Slightly hazy, ruddy amber colored pour with a thin layer of off-white head.  Aromas of fruity yeast esters with a hint of red berry and a bit of leathery prune-skin spice.  A light caramel maltiness is complimented by a yeast character that suggests raisiny fruits that are much darker than the color suggests.  A hint of herbal spice lingers as well, suggesting crushed coriander.  Medium bodied, crisply carbonated mouthfeel.  Pheonlic, yeasty flavors that are similar to Pannepot, but the malt body is not, as this beer is caramelly crisp and lacking the smoke and chocolatey malt of the sibling.  A bit of light fermented fruits brings out most of the malt body, coaxed by the yeast tones.  Alcohol well hidden.  I love this yeast strain.  What a delicious treat!

Bottled. Beer is very murky medium-brown with a small, white, vapory, mostly and quickly diminishing head.

The aroma is malty with a moderate note of toasted grain, trace of caramel; Hoppy with a light minty, herbal note; Yeasty with a trace of dough; Miscellaney include light notes of tropical fruit, alcohol, wood, moderate corriander and a trace of cinnamon.

The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter with a moderately warm, moderately sweet finish.

The body is full, the texture is velvety and the carbonation is soft-to-still.

Bottled. Dark amber coloured. Unclear. Light brown head. Ripe fruits, sweets, yeast and light spice in the aroma. Quite full. Flavour of yeast, sweetness, some ligourice, light alcohol, spice and loads of fruits. Is medium to full bodied. Spicy and yeasty end. Not as complex as the regular pannepot, but still quite a treat.

A side-by-side comparison with the regular Pannepot:
-The fluffy head is as impressive in both glasses, but the murky brown mud of the Pannepøt is not nearly as appetizing.
-The nose of the latter lacks the spicy, floral sweetness which tantalizes the nostrils in the regular version.
-Bready yeast dominates the flavor profile in Pannepøt, as roasted maltiness, earth and licorice sweetness fly about.
-Coriander milkiness is perceived, but not cleanly.
-The finish is quite dry instead of being a continuation of the complex malt-spice interplay which I am used to.
-Although a very good ale, this is simply not as cohesive and transcendent as the fantastic Pannepot.

Bottle; 2006 vintage.

2006 bottle sampled on 3/12/07 thanks to tever: Pours a slightly effervescent copper with a big frothy light tan head.  Aroma of dry, earthy, bready caramel malt with a touch of spices.  Starts full and sticky earthy caramely with a touch of fruity esters and a drier toasty malty finish.  Pretty complex, but not quite as good as the regular Pannepot.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2008 Bottle.

Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting.
Body is murky dark brown, bottle conditioned.

Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, cookie, chocolate), with notes of overripe banana, candy/brown sugar, and orange peel.

Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic.
Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.

Medium to full body, velvety/syrupy texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic.
It has some nice stuff going on, but overall, isnt as close to being as nice as the regular Pannepot.

Very strange: Now Ive had this version and the Reserva without ever having tasted the original Pannepot. For that I can thank beer festivals and the general unavailability of Struise beers in Brussels. Anyway: This was on tap at the Waregemse Bierhappening. Brown with gold highlights, lasting head. Some coffee, choco-malt aroma. Well-balanced sweetness and mild bitterness, surrounded by maltiness. Alcohol is only noticeable. Awesome balance in the finish with the hops, malt and alcohol. Really lasts too. Just an excellent beer.

Pours a cloudy brown with a lacy tan head. Full sugary body with moderate carbonation. Full taste and aroma with lots of fruit, caramel, nuts, maybe some cherry. Id like to do a Pannepøt/Pannepot side by side rating one of these times.

On [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Waregemse Bierhappening. Dark brown with a light, yellowish head. Served a bit too cold to fully enjoy the caramel aroma. Rich caramel maltiness, but well-balanced with good bitterness. Soft as velvet, lighter body than expected. It is a good beer, no doubt, but more like a Gouden Carolus than a Pannepot. In other words, enjoyable and hiding its strength well.

Cloudy dark brown/amber with a large-bubbled head which faded rapidly and left a veil of foam with the strangest patterns, like staring at the surface of the moon while on acid. The aroma was sweet and malty, with layers of spice (amongst which were liqourice, cloves, vanilla & cinnamon), bready yeast, dark fruits (plums, figs, raisins, but also strawberries), molasses, brown sugar & honey, and a lot more. Sweet taste with a complex malt profile that shifted accents throughout, starting out honey-like sweet, with strong caramel & vanilla, and ending up more liqourice-like sweet & tangy with fruity rum-soaked cherry and slight yeastyness in the long finish. The hops were subdued but provided a nice edge. There was also some citric sourness, which was very welcome. The mouthfeel was rather lively, and full-bodied. A large beer, with great malty complexity.

33cL bottle, vintage 2006, courtesy of tever.  Thanks, Tom!  Pours a murky, medium brown center with yellow edges; khaki-colored head with pleasant lacing.  Layered aroma, showing yeast and cinnamon bread; plenty of esters and chewy malts.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: esters and cloves upfront, supported by a creamy maltiness (banana bread and brown sugar); light citrus bitterness at the periphery; a bit too much alcohol pokes through for my liking.  Otherwise: dense, layered, and satisfying.  Medium, yeasty and chewy malt finish.

750 bottle at Jbru´s. Strong ripe banans, spices, vanilla aroma. Deep, very deep, almost black garnish color with some ruby hues at the borders and a creamy, yellow-tan head. Sweet, raisiny, rummy, molasses flavor with a slight smoky finnish. MF is medium to full, warming and fulling. Deep, complex, Belgian Dark Strong Ale.

A Mes rate: 33cl bottle at Chris O’s extravaganza. A rare treat. If I had not tried the regular version this would have blown me away. As it is, its just not quite as good as Pannepot. Just a little too much sugar and not quite enough spice. That said, another stunning beer from the men who can do no wrong for me right now. Like Hansel, just SO hot right now.

ChrisFest  Sweet and light and quite fragrant. Very enjoyable and easy drinking. Would have enjoyed drinking more but Phil_L picked up my glass and poured it away because he was losing an argument with me.

Aroma is spicy and pleasant.  Outrageous head and steady nearly insane carbonation from openening. Sticky sparse lacing that separates int fading lines.  Smooth and mellow surprisingly so as the 10% is muted and well hidden.  Warm aftertaste.   A lovely brew sent by the beer fairy.

Bottled at Chris_O Fest March 2007.  A hazy brown coloured beer which suprisingly gushed a massive amount.  The aroma is sweet with candy sugar notes.  The taste has good malts and plenty of sweet candy sugars.  Lovely alcohol notes.  Not as tasty as Pannepot as the extra sugars make it feel a little gritty.

Much thanks to egajdzis for breaking this out so we could do a side by side comparison with the original version, which faired differently...

Appears a hazy, dark amber with a light beige head that slowly fades into a mild cap. Lots of streaky lacing is left all around the glass. 
Smell is of dark brown sugar, mineral water, caramel, ripeened dark fruit, nuts, & mild anise notes.
Taste is of the mentioned aromas with a mineral water flavor that reminds me very much of the Westy brews.
Mouthfeel is full bodied, mineraly, with caramel and brown sugar. 

This version was much better than the original version IMO with not even close to the amount of spices as the other version had. This one was also lighter in color.

Bottled.  Cloudy dark ruby, minimal head. Concentrated aroma of ripe fruits and caramel. Sweet and very malty, desne and compact. Full bodied. Though sweet its never cloying instead its warming and complex with flavours of strawberries, caramel and banana cake. A very well made sipping beer.

Bottle shared courtesy of egajdzis (thanks!). 2006 Vintage. Poured a deeper amber color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of dark fruits, caramel, toffee, and some yeast. Tastes of caramel, toffee, citrus, and some licorice. It was interesting to have this along side the export version. The other was a lot darker and had a ton of spices in it compared to this one. I much prefer this one over the other version.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2009 Poured a reddish amber color with a small, off white head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of caramel, toffee, anise, yeast, and nuts.  Taste of sweet caramel, toffee, light roast, cocoa, nuts, smoke, with a bit of citrus, and light alcohol as well. Chewy mouthfeel, and tons of less spices than the Pannepot.

Bottled. Aroma is very strong, banana, licorice, vanilla. Dark brown color, light brown head, good lace. Sweet, increasing flavors, banana, caramel, licorice, too much to mention. Sparkling mouthfeel as first, then very alcoholic and gets dusty in the finish. Very flavorful, very complex, gotta love it.

Poured a lightly hazed dark copper color with a medium beige head.  Semi-sweet malty aroma of caramel, light yeastiness and spice.  Caramel malt flavor to start.  Spicey middle and a sweet caramel finish.  Notes of apples and pears.  The very end brought out some spice and bubblegum.  Tingley mouthfeel and a medium to full body.

This is a vintage 2006 and I enjoyed it in the summer. The beer floods out of the bottle upon opening, but I have my glass ready. Its a dark, nut-brown color with a huge, creamy and nice head. The aroma is malty and smooth with notes of dark fruits and spice - and its very, very harmonic and makes my mouth water and I cannot restrain myself any longer. The flavour - OHH-LA-LA, immediately the taste buds get the pleasure of this beer they send a message to the brain: Hello, hello - anyone at home??? Waky, waky: A new beer among the top-10 Belgian beers.... It has notes of dark fruits: raisin, plum, sweetness, candy sugar, caramel and spice and a hint of coffee or perhaps its chocolate. Its very complex and extremely well-balanced and the alcohol is very well hidden. What a nice one - sighhh - sheer pleasure...

Bottle.
Hazy orange brown coloured with a beige head.
Aroma of yeast, fruits and spices with peppery and flowery notes and notes of liquorice.
Flavour of fruits, liquorice, spices and yeast with notes of alcohol and flowery notes.

Thanks to the Atlanta crew for sharing.  Cloudy brown, bit light tan head.  Nose is fruity yeast, caramel, spices (clove, etc)  Flavor is caramel, yeast, clove, alcohol, butter.  Tingly hops in the finish.  Creamy body.

Bottle. Had this side by side to the regular Pannepot at the Sydney Gathering and, yes, its quite different. This was quite sweet, as the regular Pannepot is, but this seemed much more sugary, with a rougher, raw and yeasty mouthfeel, lacks the smoothness of the reguler Pannepot, and finishes shorter. Some subtle spiceyness and noticable alcohol.
Amber, brown coloured brew. Sweet nice aroma. Taste is not perfect, but still nice. Fruity.
Bottle. Hazy amber. Thick head. Rich sweet palate, hints of plums. Estery banana dominates.  Alchohol is fiery however and detracts from a higher grade. A little disappointed.

Bottle thanks to drewbeerme.  We put this up to the regular Pannepot to compare the two.  Pours murky brown in color with a tall head that fades down.  Nose of sweet sugars, plum, cherries, yeast, raisins, and a little alcohol.  Delicious aroma.  If the flavor matches this, this will be an amazing beer.  But it doesnt quite get there.  Cherries, oak, red fruit, molasses, a hint of alcohol.  Long lasting molasses and fruit flavors.  This is a very tasty beer but when i sip from the regular pannepot, the ø is put in perspective, and I wonder, why would the danes want this good beer over that amazing beer?  hmm ...

2006 bottle. Sampled side-by-side with Pannepot. Ruby brown with  a moderate sized, creamy off white head. Much different appearance than the Pannepot. subltle aromas of malt and brown sugar. Smooth, creamy mouthfeel. Big malt flavors with some raisins and warming alcohol.

2006 Vintage from Slob.  Thanks, dude!  Pours a beautiful and antiqueish brown, with healthy head of light mahogany.  Aromas of cinammon and nutmeg permeate the air from the time of the first drop leaving the bottle.  Very egg-noggish, indeed.  Flavors of strong cinammon and nutmeg coat the tongue, leaving traces of egg nog as it dissipates.  Full and coating mouthfeel that leaves no taste bud untouched.  Fantastic brew.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Got this from footbalm. Dark cloudy brown/amber color. Nutmeg,plum,yeast,molasses aroma.  Big fluffy tan head. The taste was sweet, smooth, and spicy with a nice alcohol finish. Lots of dark fruits and yeast going on here. This beer has taste that I have not tasted in other brews before. Thanks, Eric.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2007 Pours a cloudy amber with a thin lacing on the glass.  Smells perfumy and wild with lots of crassy/hay countryside elements.  Taste is citrussy and boozy with lots of flowal undertones.  Surprisingly drinkable for a beer thats 10% ABV.

330ml, dated 2006, huge thanks to tever for sending this rare gem. sampled next to regular pannepot. pours an unappealing murky brown with off white head. the head was really nice and lasted which saved the appearance from being a 2. nose is really nice with lots of plums, yeasty, brown sugar, and nutmeg. some alcohol is present in the nose. flavor has of plum, nutmeg, nuts,  bready, not overly sweet. mouthfeel is silky, creamy, and rich. long palate, that finishes dry with alcohol warmth. this beer seemed more watery, yeasty, less spices, and more noticed alcohol than the regular pannepot. this got blown away by the regular pannepot.

Courtesy of Styles
Bottle:  The aroma is yeast, fruit, plum, grape, candy sugar, a hint of chocolate, and alcohol.  It pours a cloudy orangish-red with a small off-white head.  The flavor starts with plum, yeast, and a hint of grape.  The finish has a hint of flowery bitterness, faint orange peel, and a touch of alcohol.  I prefer the "o" version, but still very tastey.

Killer cloudy orange/amber with some brown at the edges. Slowly diminishing head of patchy but creamy light beige bubbles, in clusters. The aroma has an overall orange citrus feel about it, though no real hoppiness. A cacophony of perfumes springs forth from the glass, mainly lavender and chamomile. Caramel malt is aplenty in the nose. This is all rounded out with a sugariness that reminds of (baked brown)icing on top of pound cake. The flavor is definitely thinner and less interesting than Pannepot. It just doesnt have that invigorating puzzle piece. More noticeable alcohol and candi sugar, alongside big tangerine fruitiness. Semi-drying finish of commendable length and potency. The palate is creamy and smooth but I feel now that while this is excellent, its only half the brew the other version is. Im very appreciative for the opportunity to try this, thanks Joe.

This seems signifigantly lighter and fruitier, in aroma and color, than the original version.

Delighted to have an opportunity to taste this side by side with the original Pannepot at a group gathering. Theyre both spectacular beers. One thing bothers me. Ive sometimes wondered how much the order of beers in a tasting affects your impressions of each. That seems particularly relevant here as my conclusions run slightly against the grain - a marginal preference for this special edition over the original. My main criticism of this was the sweetness, which bordered on excessive. However, the original, which we sampled immediately after, seemed even sweeter. Is it sweeter or was that impression simply a consequence of drinking two sugary beers in a row? In other words, if the beers had been reversed, would this one have seemed even sweeter? Hmmm... Ah well, bugger it, you can only rate them as you see them. This one was cloudy brown with a dollop of crema. Theres a hint of vinyl in the aroma plus caramelised sugars, dried fruits and a faint lambic sourness that I didnt pick in the original. Lovely creamy palate. Oodles of sweet chocolate, toffee and a lip-smacking funky sour finish. (Bottle courtesy of Papsoe - thanks Henrik. RateBeer Sydney Jan 07 gathering)

Parralel tasting of the Panep(/)ots at the eve before LCRBM. Main differnce lies in that the 
old original is spicier and has a richer "darK flavor whereas the latter is somewhat fruitier.

This beer is absolutely delicious. Thanks to tever for getting it to me.
It pours apple cider brown with an off white head. The flavor has a mixture of brown sugar, plums, and other fruit.

Bottle (Sydney Summer Gathering 2007): A very nice choice for a cool autumn evening, I think. Cloudy amber with an off-white head. Not really much going on the aroma - some slight dusty malts, but nothing identifiable. However, in the mouth this is extraordinary. Thick, sweet toffees over chewy highly spiced clove and caramel. A delight.

Full bodied, strong and malty, but I found the caramelised sugar flavour off-putting. Fairly spicy aroma follows onto the palate, unfortunately this aroma reminded me slightly of my armpits, so it wasnt really pleasant to drink something hinting of this character...

Bottle  Hazy, brown body.  Creamy, light brown head.  Excellent lace.  Looks lovely!  Lightly malty aroma of caramel, raisins, a little bit of liquor.  (Unfortunately) not as heavily malty as the normal Pannepot.  Lightly bitter, moderatetely sweet flavour.  Ok flavour, but again not as complex as pannepot. The flavour lacks the strong malts as well.  So overall I think I can say the Pannepøt is way softer than the Pannepot, but still has some of its complexity, but more subtle (both in aroma and in flavour). Give me the Pannepot!

Bottle. Tasting 12-01-2007 (Søren, Peter, Carsten). Wow this one was great! Love to taste the Pannepot. Jeppe please get the Pannepot home :-) Large frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting. Excellent lacing. Body was kind of murky with heavy particles and a ruby like color. Aroma was very complex with notes of caramel, chocolate, coffee, nutty, rye bread, banana, plum, date, licorice and brown sugar. This actually reminder me a lot of a good port wine. Great stuff. Full bodied with a sticky texture and an average carbonation. This was so well balanced between the bitter and sweet flavor. Finishes quit nicely on a sweet note that lasts. Incredible beer and one of the highlights of the evening.

Thanks a lot to iowaherkeye for sharing this at a tasting! He recieved it in an international trade. The body was dark amber with a large khaki colored head. The aroma was cherries, chocolate and caramel. The nose was very sweet on this one. The taste was toffee, tea and subtle apples. There was also a nice hay note. There was soft carbonation for the very nice mouthfeel. Another great version of a solid beer.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2008 2006 Vintage: Much more floral and lifted than its cousin. Violets, dancing blue berry and soft sweet licorice. Low fizz.  Not really in the class of the stable mate but still very good.

October 2006 3.7pts: Medium brown and thin flat white coffee style head. Cooked aniseed and fruit cake on the nose. Expressive and powerful. Heavy palate with alcohol evident, together with a very nice coffee flavour.  Palate is thick and powerful, although lacking some finesse. (e3.25 @ t Brugs Beertje)

Muddy golden with a nice head. Some sweet flowery hops meet you first then a vinious note and finally a complex blend of maltiness and yeast. Taste is sweet with a vinious edge, making it instantly drinkable. Not as heavy-going as the original Pannepot.
2006 pours with a huge head off white to slightly brown. deep dark body I can barely see light through it. mouth feel is very smooth with only a hint at carbonation almost to sweet though.

dark brown almost blavk with a gray head. Smells like pumpkin spices. Wow, this is lively on my tongue with active carbonation. Allspice and coriander abound in this. Nutmeg lingers with some brown sugar. A bit eggy.
5 6 6 3 14

Indeed I was thinking it was the regular Pannepot. It turns out to be the Panneput. You have to put them somewhere. Aroma is very fruity (dried fruits/red fruits) and malty. Cloudy, dark coloured with a lasting , nice brown head. Taste is sweet , very fruity, some spice, some wine. Im gonna age some of this stuff.

Bottle erupts in a fountain of foam once the cork is off. Small white head; reddish brown body. Sweet licorice and banana aroma with strong, sharpish spice notes. Touches of bubble gum. Spicy tobacco-like licorice taste with chocolate notes. Dry, yeasty aftertaste. (0.33l bottle.)

I dont know whats the difference with the other brew, but skortila managed to obtain a big bottle of this (probably just thinking it to be the regular pannepot). But taste was the same to my opinion: sweet, dried fruits, malts. Delicious again.
Bottle. Amber colour with a huge mostly lasting creamy off white head. Rich aroma and taste of malts, fruits and spices. Alocholic finish. Good palate.

33 cl bottle. Lots of carbonation, a real geysir this one. 
Lovely smell of spices. Tastes of candy sugar and banana, a bit sticky. Too sweet to get top marks from me, but an interesting beer.

(750ml bottle)  Pours a dark brown body with a moderate tan head.  Aroma of coriander, raisins, marshmallow, plum, cocoa, vinous, and other fruits.  Flavor of toasted malt, fruit, and caramel with a creamy finish.

330 ml bottle. Dark reddish brown. Gusher. I ended up with the glass with no head, but the other two glasses had a small off-white head. Sweet sugary aroma with notes of almonds ad a lot of banana. Sugary sweet and malty. Lacks much of the complexity of the 2005 vintage. This one is monotonous and sweet.

(Bottle 75 cl) Slightly hazy orangey brown with a dense, creamy and quite lasting, beige head. Soft, sherry like aroma. Full body with sweet caramel and some fruit. A quite warming alcohol. Nice all right but I had expected a much more subtle complexity. Probably will improve with aging. 241206

75 cl bottle. Dark amber colour with a nice white head. Aroma of light caramel, malt sweetness, little sour and alcoholic. Wonderful and well balance flavour of dried fruit, sweetness and hints of caramel and sourness. Ends up with a warm finish from the alcohol, a very good and nice belgium beer.
Nose was søur cherry and a dusty bubblegum.  bit of cørriander.  Darker brøwn with a high carbønation.  Slightly søur in the mouth.  Flavøur is very spice with a sweet cherry plum.

unfortunatly I think that this beer may have been a bit oxidized or it just has flavors that Im not really used to.  I thought the aroma was pretty funky with some woody notes as well as licorice and spice.  it poured a really dark brown with a tremedous and beautiful head.  Flavor had many dark beer elements mostly licorice.  beer also had nice spicy notes.  quite pleasant, but I have had much better.  good active palate.  nice beer, but I expected better

Pour is brown with a big bubbled brown head...smell was tremendously deep and spicy...very "wintery" smell...anise, pepper, dirt (pleasant dirt), light funk, prunes, licorice...I have to revisit this one because the taste really threw me for a loop...there was so much going on as far as flavor...licorice, pepper, sweet candy, cocoa, pumpernickel, salt, rye bread...as I said, I am perplexed...my initial reaction to this is to call it a trainwreck of flavor...but not a trainwreck of bad flavors, they were all nice, but seemed to be "busy" in the mouth...
Dark brown pour with huge bubbly tan head.  Coriander among other spices on the nose.  Palate is slightly sticky.  Flavor is sweet candi sugar.

Chestnut brown with orange reflections, very stable cream-coloured beer. Earthy, leafy and some chocolate. Alcohol & higher alcohols, little point of acidity. After some time, an aroma of fresh herbs. Chocolate flavour, immediately taken over by a very rich malty, alcohol-dominated taste, sweet-sour alike with a complexity, very difficult to obtain, displaying a rich, velvety MF, and of course very full body. Only bad point is, warming up, the appearance of an excessive liquorice flavour. Very nice, and indeed not the same as the Pannepot (without Danish runes). But still excellent...

Shared by sliffy at columbus tasting 3.0.Aromas of sweet malt and some spice.Pours dark brown with a beige head.Some dark fruits and yeast stand out in the flavors.Medium body with a warming alcohol finish.

2006 bottle... Mostly clear mahogany ale with a large, frothy, off-white head. Good retention. Malty, breadsy nose is a whirl of caramel, port, brown sugar, mild licorice and subtle, earthy pine. Malty, vinous flavor delivers gobs of brown sugar, caramel and cookie dough with lesser notes of sherry, grapefruit and espresso. Hints at licorice, but maybe its just the power of suggestion from the aroma chiming in. Alcohol is pretty well-hidden. Full-bodied and almost syrupy with prickly carbonation. Finishes hoppy-crisp, then gently sweet with a pinch of salt. Thanks goes out to my friend, C.K., for bringing this back from her European travels. I was expecting the same Pannepot I tasted over a year ago. Nice surprise, this one!
Pours a murky dark amber with a beige head. Malty with caramel, dried fruits, yeast and a hint of chocolate. Full bodied. Also hints of spices and earth. Slightly vinous. Dry finish.

Shared by Sliffy!  Sour, funky, and malty aroma (this is going to be good kinda aroma).  Very murky brown in color.  Medium palate with low carbonation.  The taste is dominated by caramel malt, but has some good yeast flavors behind it and a hint of funk.  Wonderfully complex beer.
Bottle. Amber brown colour with a big off-white head. Caramel malty, fruity, brown sugar aroma and taste, sweet. Medium to full body with a sweet finish.

A novelty of licorice and great beer, with candi and carmel and brown sugar. Very smooth and a treat to the palate. Brownish colour. Aggressive carbonation Unique and worth trying, but a sweet novelty nevertheless. Thanks Mr. Madsberg, delivery from Denmark.

Mild chocolate aroma with some orange and probably some fresh hoppiness. I even sense some nice green apples there!

Thick, beige head over a dark, reddish brown body. Spicy nougat gives way to smokey coffee as it warms. Complex, yet easy drinking, class act.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2007 Apr 07 Bottle @ Staminee de Garre, Brugge. Caramel mild spices and bread. Seemed sweeter this time and not so drinkable. 3.5

Nov 06Bottle (from Bitter Virtue, Vintage 06). Foamed over slightly when I opened this but managed not to lose much. Deep brown colour with a thick lasting head. Aroma is quite subdued but pleasant with toffeed fruits, light spice, malts and hints of chocolatey coffee. Continues along a similar theme in the mouth with more intensity, suprisingly no that sweet, although the sweetness is there it is quite restrained and silky smooth. Slight earthy hop in the finish which rounds it off nicely. Very drinkable for its strength but full attention needs to be paid to get the most out of this. 3.8

Bottle, 33 cl. First time saterday with Davy and Glenn (Alvinne) yesterday again at home. Dark brown with a thick, moussy, bubbly tan head. Some dark sugar, light sugar too in the nose. Theres roast and nut and caramel the finish grows dryer. A complicated beer. 
But personally like the aardmonnik moe.

2006 bottle picked up at the brewery in May 06. Very gushy when I opened it and had to have the glass ready. Beautiful mahogany/ruby clear clour with thin off white head. Ive had this younger, so I was interested to see what another 6 months in bottle would do. Malty fruit and some bananery esters on aroma.  Some brown sugar as well. Some vinous fruit.  Some of the distinctive vinous fruits in mouth with some coffee actually. Well carbonated. Finish has some hot alcohol and spicey hop. Fruits become more syrupy and intense as the mouthfeel progresses. The carbonation gives a prickling to the tongue. I prefer the 04 and 05 vintages. Flatter and thinner flavours. Still a good beer, but lacks the former perfection

Deep nutbrown color with creamy beige foam on top. Nose is sweet, nutty and fruity with a warm and complex spiceyness. The taste is not a sweet as the regular Pannepot and lies more in the line of the Trappists. The taste is nutty, honeyed and filled wits dry abricoos, figgs and toches of spices like cinnamon and nutmeg. Afthertaste is complex and warming. Alcohol is present but well incorporated in the beer. Very nice and to me very different than the regular Pannepot. From a 75cl bottle, I concidder myself very lucky to have 5 more bottles of it in my cellar.
Very high CO2, slightly turbid iced tea body. Nose-sweet, alcohol, bready, yeasty. Taste-yeasty, sweet, bread dough, medium sweet, alcohol, honey, chocolate, spicy, dusty, fig, light raisin.

a magnificent aroma which filled the room when we poured this out of the 750ml bottle. Aroma of spices, malts, caramel, apples, dry fruits, simply awesome. Palate is a tad spicy with a malty cocoa chocolate finish. To my surprise this is incredibly balanced and well masked, and not over sugary. A world class belgian!!

Bottle at CTV3, shared by sliffy, thanks! Pours amber with a short off white head.Aroma of canided fruit, light hops, some spice, yeast, and carmel malt. Flvaor of floral hops, yeast, spices and malt. Medium body thats bitter, sweet, and a bit spicy. I was very glad that I got a chance to try this one, though Ithink the regular Pannepot is a little more solid.

With only a few years in the commercial business its somewhat difficult to imagine how the brewers at Struise were able to produce the paragon that is Pannepot. Even harder to imagine is what they will concoct for us next and whether it can possibly get any better. In any event, the excitement generated by this beer is genuinely deserved, and heres why. A rusted hue pinched with the slightest touch of garnet reflects the deep and meditative temper reinforced by its inspired subtitle "Old Fishermans Ale". The still cream that floats above sheds a sheet of dentelle glazed across any glass it touches and meticulously cemented like thousands of minuscule barnacles. I have little seafaring experience myself, but Hollywood has me picturing a man in a crusted beard looking twice his age and capped of a chapeau dark as the ocean, sipping from a chalice in the days sole moment of grace. As I return from my reverie, the beer facing me has not changed but exudes a complex pastiche reminding at once of the classical Trappists and the conversely avant-gardist brewers. Deep molasses and brown sugar reminiscent again of Struises Speculoos are jolted with banana, figs and plums. Cloves, pepper and coriander provide a balancing spice profile that naturally flows into a sylvan aroma of soil, artichoke and walnuts. Dense but sweet almost succulent, yet open, airy and dry at the same time. Theres cream, theres terroir, theres everything you would want - its abracadabrantly balanced. Pannepot transitions to the tongue very organically as its noses echo resounds on the palate in a flurry of roasted coffee and dark chocolate flavors. Cardamom and allspice are part of this orchestral composition that with warming evolves a flowery form of banana, and the juices of grape and cherry. The swallow unveils a long and complex aftertaste blending coffee, pepper, coriander, caramel and a touch of hops. Every bit of this beer is worth seeking out and shows yet another example of Belgiums young and talented brewers. Whats almost scary is how juvenile my bottle still was and the potential it showed for aging after only a couple months in my cellar.

A hazy mid brown coloured beer with a thick off-white head. A strong toasted malt nose with some dark fruits. A bit foisty, like damp cloth! The taste is bitter sweet, slightly sour, toasted malt again, fruity, plus a hint of dry spice. The finish is long and quite bitter. (Bottle - courtesy of Mark @ The Fox & Hounds, Heacham, Norfolk).

Huge thanks to Immy on this one!  From bottle, pours a murky brown with tan head.  Nose is candy sugar, figs and banana nut bread.  Flavor is soft, following nose with some alcohol spice and melon.  Palate is creamy with a crisp, lightly bitter finish.  Excellent.

Bottle shared at Columbus tasting 3.0 by sliffy! - Thanks! - Pours amber with a light offwhite head that stays pretty well.  Aroma of raisins, caramel, and some piney spicey hops.   Flavor is raisin, grapefruit, caramel, and some brown sugar as well as yeast.  Palate is quite smooth and soft in the mouth with good carbonation.   Nice brew!

Bottle thanks to papsoe: Copper color with an off white head. Aroma, spicy, caramel, floral hops, some yeast. Flavor, floral notes, some caramel, yeast, spicy hops, rich malts. Pretty nice beer. I saw the split and was quite pleased when I realized I had a bottle of this.

Bought in Grobbendonk. Yes, it was Pannepeut, not Pannepot. Roasted malt, licorice and salt in the aroma. Sweet flavor. Malty with licorice, raisin, alcohol salt and plums. Roasted malt. A heavy beer, still reasonably well balanced, therefore well made. Good stuff.

330, courtesy the fine bonus-beer-ing of Tever. Its absolutely impossible to overstate the complexity of this beer. Pours a murky, muddy brown with a thick, moussy, bubbly tan head. The nose seems to contain every tree fruit I know about, and some of the berries--plum, cherry, dark sugar, light sugar (Red Delicious apples), and a whisper of sour/tart citrus sugars, too. These fruity goodnesses persist on the attack, and to some lesser extent on the mid palate. Theres roast and nut and caramel in the inverse proportion--scarcely there on the nose, but they rise through the mid-palate convincingly. As the beer warms (alas, we poured it too cold), the finish grows dryer and dryer--shockingly so for such a fruitily sugary-smelling beer. I can;t for the life of figure out how they do it, sometimes. This is phenomenal and I wish I had a case of it socked away, at least. Thanks, Tom!~

Blev i sin tid rated i sammenligning med Pannepot, men kan da godt få en plads på min liste.
Mørk rød/brun farve, skummet forsvandt med det samme den blev skænket.
Duft af meget alkohol, tung sødme stadig af tørrede frugter. Ingen lakrids som i "Potten"
Smagen er meget domineret af rosin og svedsker og ikke så kompleks som "Potten". God fylde.

Rating #500! Thanks to my Danish Secret Santa, whoever you are! Bottle, 2006 vintage. Hazy golden brown with a tan head. Sweet, dark fruit nose, dried dates, prune, toffee, caramel, light spiciness. Smooth, rich mouthfeel. Flavor is more of the nose, but more emphasis on the toffee and caramel flavors, still fruity, some brown sugar. Absolutely fabulous!
Red/brown - disapearing white head. A lot sweeter than pannepot. No licorice, not as powerfull and fullbodied. more obvious alcohol. Hoppy. But still a very good beer.

Draught @ Ølbaren, Copenhagen. Dark amber colour with a longlasting off-white head. Malty fruity spicy aroma, some hints of dark fruits. Sweet malty fruity warming spicy flavor with hints of dark fruits. Malty warming and fruity finish.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2006 Bottle. Pours a beautiful brown-reddish amber (turn cloudy when the bottle is emptied) with a big beige/off-white head. Complex aroma: Red wine with notes of hops and yeast as well as slight notes of wood. A sweet fruitiness lingers in the vicinity of the glass. As it warms, plums take over. Flavour is sweetish with malt and hops. Notes of yeast and alcohol. Plums here as well. Finish is sweetish and malty and feels thick/sticky. Bitter  with slight notes of bitter licorice. Alcohol and notes of red wine. A bit too much carbonation. 18-10-06.

Looks brilliant, dark amber, unclear. Real soft lasting head. Aroma and flavor is full of malt, dark malt and dark fruits. Palate is a bit thin. Finish is bitter and warmning. Mine was spelled: "Pannepøt".

Bottle. Clear brown beer with a reddish note. The head is small, creamy and beige, and it lasts for a while. Aroma with tobacco, sugar, dried fruits and spices. Quite sweet, flavor of brown sugar, tobacco, dried fruits, grapes and raisins. Creamy and sweet in the mouth.

On tap at Ølbaren. Hazy dark golden in colour with a medium sized head. Very nice. Sweet and malty without being too heavy and sticky. Notes of bread, caramel, dark dried fruits and spices. Nice complexity.

Bottle, 2006: Pours hazy golden brown with a tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, caramel, prune and notes of banana and spices. Flavour of brown sugar, caramel, malt and fruit. Sweet/ sour and alcoholic finish. Enjoyable.

Bottle, 2006, plain shallow chalice @ the Delirium café, Brussels (served too cold so I took a moment to let it air). 
Poured a dull, ruby copper with a slight yeast haze and very fine carbonation. Head was a little limp to form and ended in a tight but flaccid and thin pad of tan that left minimal lace. Aroma was striking, unique and unfortunately not altogether integrated. Bits and pieces of old, musty fell fruit, wooded overripe berries, cough medicine, savoury figs and sultanas, aniseed and fresh crushed ginger, a little dark fudge and some candi that wafted continuously from the glass. Quite honestly interesting though. Comes together in the mouth. Big, creamy, malty and treacly thick palate. Carbonation is gentle but attacks all corners of the mouth heightening the flavours to full effect. Rich toffee, chocolate mud-cake, plum-wine and madeira, huge presence of dark fruits including ripe plums, blackberries and some tart cranberries and aniseed, and ofcourse a nice mellowing presence of infused alcohol that lifts it and manages to warm like an elixir. It is quite peppery, spicy and has a nice bitter edge that it peaks at before it drops off long with liquorice, deep malts and a little Benadryl, and some more savoury fruits in the aftertaste. This was a young sample, but it is oh so good. Flavours are raw and well defined yet they meld with such articulate perfection. The only mar would be its alcohol which as it warms becomes more aggressive and solvent-like, but with age I think this would mellow. I loved this and just hope that I can come across a few more bottles, a little more locally than half-way across the globe. Very, very nice slow sipper. (33cL, 10% ABV, BBE 03/10)

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2006 Draught  Pannepøt 2006  unclear golden (?!) small bubbled head; Deep, deep  complex nose with lots of white fruit: lots of peach, lots of fresh and dry apricot, fresh cane sugar (exactly the aroma you get when you chew a fresh stick of cane sugar, the combination of fresh raw sugar and bamboo, or cane sugar juice), but also a little of the bitter, sourness from dried fruits like fig; Super complex deep, deep body, very, very well balanced simply amazing, with perfect amount of carbonation; Finishing very, very, very long in a sweet and a little sour fresh way, again with lots of raw cane sugar but also peach and fresh ripe apple and again apricot. The slight sourness really fits the Pannepot. This one is maybe a bit to raw sugar sweet, but definitely the best of the Pannepots.
